CGI Extensions for the ClearSilver CGI Kit

Thomas J. Moore
Version 1.0 Revision 185
2010

Abstract

This document describes and implements a few enhancements to the CGI library provided by ClearSilver, in addition to what is provided by the Generic ClearSilver and GLib Module Build Support document.

© 2009--2010 Trustees of Indiana University. This document is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the `License'); you may not use this document except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0. Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an `AS IS' BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License.

This document was generated from the following sources, all of which are attached:

  1. $Id: build.nw 184 2012-11-26 09:02:05Z darktjm $

  • HTML Form Support Macros

  • CGI Parameter Parsing

  • Usage
  • Code Dependencies
  • Code Index

Introduction

The CGI kit included with ClearSilver works well enough for most applications, but some improvements could be made. First, like most CGI libraries, file upload control is inadequate: all uploads are placed in the same temporary directory (which bypasses per-user quotas, among other things), and the only provided callback does not get access to already-known CGI parameters or file attributes. Second, there is no direct FastCGI1 support. FastCGI allows the sharing of long setup times among multiple connections; for example, connections can be made to a database before the user ever connects to the web server. Third, there is no macro library for common form operations. This is probably for the better, since limitations in such a library tend to prompt either rewrite or convoluted workarounds. Fourth, there is no support for WebDAV2 request processing. This is normally done in a web server module, but there is no reason not to do it in (Fast)CGI.

In addition to the basic parsing enhancements and FastCGI support, a simple session management infrastructure is implemented, using either files or a database for session storage. This is then used to help implement authentication caching for the Central Authentication Service3.

<(build.nw) Version Strings>=

  1. "$Id: cgi-supt.nw 185 2012-11-26 09:12:11Z darktjm $\n"

<(build.nw) Sources>=

  1. $Id: cgi-supt.nw 185 2012-11-26 09:12:11Z darktjm $

<(build.nw) Common NoWeb Warning>= (U-> U->)

  1. # $Id: cgi-supt.nw 185 2012-11-26 09:12:11Z darktjm $

HTML Form Support Macros

Using macros to display widgets makes the HTML harder to edit with normal tools, and also makes it more dependent on the macro language. The conditional HTML is complex enough that the use of macros is worth the potential problems.

<(cs-glib.nw) CS files>=

  1. html_macros.cs \

<html_macros.cs>=

  1. <?cs <(build.nw) Common NoWeb Warning> ?><?cs

  2. <Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>

  3. # ?>

<(build.nw) Install other files>= [D->]

  1. <(cs-glib.nw) Install ClearSilver templates>

First, to start out a form, the form header must be printed.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. def:form(fname,hasfiles)

  2.   ?><form name="<?cs var:fname ?>" action="<?cs

  3.        var: CGI.ScriptName + CGI.PathInfo ?>"<?cs

  4.           if:hasfiles ?> enctype="multipart/form-data"<?cs /if ?>><?cs

  5. /def ?><?cs

For a standard text widget, only the variable name and default value are required. As with all of these macros, the CGI parameter value is retrieved from the Query variable hierarchy.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:text(varn,default)

  2.   ?><input type="text" size="32" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs

  3.     if: ?Query[varn] ?><?cs

  4.       var:Query[varn] ?><?cs

  5.     else ?><?cs

  6.       var:default ?><?cs

  7.     /if ?>" /><?cs

  8. /def ?><?cs

Repeated text widgets are the same as regular text widgets, but a sequence number is attached to the variable name. The hierarchy is expected to go one level lower, using the sequence number. The first widget (0) is actually just like a normal text widget.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:rtext(varn,seq,default)

  2.   ?><input type="text" size="32" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs

  3.     if:?Query[varn][seq] ?><?cs

  4.       var:Query[varn][seq] ?><?cs

  5.     else ?><?cs

  6.       if:seq == "0" && ?Query[varn] ?><?cs

  7.         var:Query[varn] ?><?cs

  8.       else ?><?cs

  9.         var:default ?><?cs

  10.       /if ?><?cs

  11.     /if ?>" /><?cs

  12. /def ?><?cs

Hidden parameters are just printed once for every available value.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:hidden(varn)

  2.   ?><?cs

  3.     if:len(Query[varn]) ?><?cs

  4.       each:v = Query[varn]

  5.        ?><input type="hidden" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs var:v ?>" />

  6. <?cs  /each ?><?cs

  7.     elseif:?Query[varn]

  8.       ?><input type="hidden" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs

  9.                        var:Query[varn] ?>" />

  10. <?cs

  11.     /if ?><?cs

  12. /def ?><?cs

File selection widgets do not have defaults. Even if the variable is provided by the CGI, it does not necessarily match a local file name.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:file(varn)

  2.   ?><input type="file" size="32" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs

  3.                                           var:Query[varn] ?>" /><?cs

  4. /def ?><?cs

Radio selections are checked if the CGI parameter matches the value, or if this is the default and the CGI parameter either does not exist or has no value.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:radio(varn, val, isdef)

  2.   ?><input type="radio" value="<?cs var:val ?>" name="<?cs var:varn ?>"<?cs

  3.     if:?Query[varn]["0"] ?><?cs

  4.       each:i = Query[varn] ?><?cs

  5.         if: i == val ?> checked="checked" <?cs /if ?><?cs

  6.       /each ?><?cs

  7.     else ?><?cs

  8.       if: Query[varn] == val ?> checked="checked" <?cs

  9.       else ?><?cs

  10.         if:isdef && (!?Query[varn] || Query[varn] == "") ?> checked="checked" <?cs /if?><?cs

  11.       /if ?><?cs

  12.     /if ?> /><?cs

  13. /def ?><?cs

Plain checkboxes always default to unchecked, as it is too hard to tell the difference between unchecked and missing. If a hidden value were added, it would be a little easier, but possibly inconsistent.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:checkbox(varn)

  2.   ?><input type="checkbox" value="Y" name="<?cs var:varn ?>"<?cs

  3.      if:Query[varn] ?> checked="checked" <?cs /if ?>/><?cs

  4. /def ?><?cs

Date widgets should really have a JavaScript calendar-based date selection button, but instead they are currently just plain text widgets. However, they are assigned an easy-to-identify class name to make adding the popup with dynamic HTML easier.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:date(varn, def)

  2.   ?><input type="text" class="datesel" size="12" name="<?cs var:varn ?>" value="<?cs

  3.     if: ?Query[varn] ?><?cs

  4.       var:Query[varn] ?><?cs

  5.     else ?><?cs

  6.       var:default ?><?cs

  7.     /if ?>" /><?cs

  8. /def ?><?cs

Submit buttons display the value as the button text, so the value cannot be used to determine the action. Instead, the parameter name is used. The label is the configuration value of labels.action, and the parameter name is action.action.

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:submit(action)

  2.   ?><input type="submit" name="action.<?cs var:action ?>" value="<?cs

  3.                                            var:labels[action] ?>" /><?cs

  4. /def ?><?cs

Finally, a facility is provided for showing or hiding various HTML divisions using a selection widget (aka drop-down menu). If JavaScript is not supported by the browser, then all divisions will be displayed. The selection widget itself should not be displayed, either, so it is rendered using JavaScript. The less-than and greater-than symbols for the HTML tags are also escaped, so that simplistic HTML parsers don't get confused. Note that only one division set, and one selection widget are supported per page.

In order to remain independent of web servers, this could be included entirely in-line. However, as a general rule, it is better to keep anything more complex than a function call in a separate JavaScript file to avoid quoting issues, and enable preparsing optimizations by the browser.

<JavaScript Files>= (U->)

  1. html_prefix.js \

<html_prefix.js>=

  1. function showdiv(divno)

  2. {

  3.   var mydiv, i;

  4.   for(i = 1; (mydiv = document.getElementById('div' + i)); i++)

  5.     mydiv.style.display = divno == i ? "block" : "none";

  6. }

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:optdiv_onload()

  2.   ?>showdiv(document.forms[0]._ignore.selectedIndex);<?cs /def ?><?cs

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:optdiv_start() ?><script language="javascript" type="text/javascript">

  2. //<![CDATA[

  3. document.writeln('\x3Cselect name="_ignore" onchange="showdiv(this.value);"\x3E');

  4. document.write('\x3Coption value="0"\x3E<?cs var:labels.optdiv ?>');

  5. document.writeln('\x3C/option\x3E');<?cs /def ?><?cs

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:optdiv_opt(n, v)

  2.   ?>document.write('\x3Coption value="<?cs var:v ?>"\x3E<?cs var:n ?>');

  3.     document.writeln('\x3C/option\x3E');<?cs

  4.      /def ?><?cs

<Generic ClearSilver HTML Macros>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. def:optdiv_end()

  2.   ?>document.writeln('\x3C/select\x3E');

  3. //]]>

  4. </script><?cs /def ?><?cs

This does require that yet another location must be chosen for installation. The HTML can still be kept generic enough for easy run-time override of the installation location.

<CGI Support Configuration>= (U->) [D->]

  1. # Location of JavaScript on the server

  2. #server_script_path = /js

<(build.nw) makefile.config>= [D->]

  1. # Installation directory for javascript files

  2. JS_DIR:=/var/www/html/js

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>= [D->]

  1. JS_FILES = <JavaScript Files>

<(build.nw) Plain Files>= [D->]

  1. $(JS_FILES) \

<(build.nw) Install other files>+= [<-D]

  1. mkdir -p $(DESTDIR)$(JS_DIR)

  2. cp -p $(JS_FILES) $(DESTDIR)$(JS_DIR)

<html_prefix.cs>=

  1. <script language="javascript" type="text/javascript" src="<?cs

  2.        alt:server_script_path ?>/js<?cs /alt ?>/html_prefix.js"></script>

FastCGI Support

FastCGI support is implemented using the mostly undocumented direct functions of the libfcgi API. The standard I/O overrides are better documented, but intrusively override many standard functions. There is no standard method provided by libfcgi to find the libraries and include files, so standard LDFLAGS and CFLAGS overrides must be used if needed.

<(cs-glib.nw) Library cs-supt Members>= [D->]

  1. cgi.o

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>= [D->]

  1. <CGI Prerequisite Headers>

  2. #include "cgi.h"

<CGI Prerequisite Headers>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. #include <fcgiapp.h>

<cgi.h>=

  1. /*

  2.   <(build.nw) Common NoWeb Warning>

  3. */

  4. #ifndef _CGI_H

  5. #define _CGI_H

  6. <CGI Support Global Definitions>

  7. #endif /* _CGI_H */

<cgi.c>=

  1. <(build.nw) Common C Header>

  2. <CGI Support Variables>

  3. <CGI Support Functions>

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>+= [<-D->]

  1. EXTRA_LDFLAGS += -lfcgi

Each FastCGI session is like an independent CGI program. This implies that no global variables should be used; instead, a master state structure is passed around.

<CGI Support Global Definitions>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. typedef struct cgi_state_t cgi_state_t;

  2. <CGI State Dependencies>

  3. struct cgi_state_t {

  4.   <CGI State Members>

  5. };

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>= [D->]

  1. cgi_state_t,%

The general program structure supported here is to perform global initializations before the main loop, and in the main loop spawn a thread for every incoming connection. The threads get the cgi_state_t structure for the current CGI execution. An initialization function is provided for the global initializations, and a generic main loop with a callback is provided for spwan loop. The callback is called from within the thread rather than as the main body of the thread so that cleanup is automatic. That means that the callback must be stored in the CGI state for the thread to call. In addition, a generic cleanup callback is provided; this should be overridden using a statically stored chain for each overrider to ensure that all cleaners are called. Calling from within the thread also allows the return code from the callback to be used; if an error is returned, that error is printed.

<CGI Support Functions>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. void init_cgi(void)

  2. {

  3.   <Perform global CGI support initialization>

  4. }

<CGI State Dependencies>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. struct cgi_state_t;

  2. typedef NEOERR *(*cgi_callback_t)(struct cgi_state_t *cgi_state);

  3. typedef void (*cgi_cleanup_cb)(struct cgi_state_t *cgi_state);

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. cgi_callback_t,cgi_cleanup_cb,%

<CGI State Members>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. cgi_callback_t callback;

  2. cgi_cleanup_cb cleanup;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static void *run_cgi_thread(void *_state)

  2. {

  3.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = _state;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr = (*cgi_state->callback)(cgi_state);

  5.   if(cgi_state->cleanup)

  6.     (*cgi_state->cleanup)(cgi_state);

  7.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  8.     <Display error from CGI callback>

  9.   }

  10.   <Clean up after CGI callback>

  11.   return NULL;

  12. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void run_cgi(cgi_callback_t callback)

  2. {

  3.   while(1) {

  4.     cgi_state_t *cgi_state;

  5.     <Allocate CGI state>

  6.     cgi_state->callback = callback;

  7.     <Prepare for CGI thread>

  8.     <Spawn CGI thread>

  9.   }

  10.   <Wait for remaining CGI threads>

  11. }

The most obvious global initializations are the memory pool for the CGI state structures, and the FastCGI subsystem.

<Perform global CGI support initialization>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. #if GLIB_MINOR_VERSION < 10 /* GMemChunk is deprecated */

  2. state_pool = g_mem_chunk_create(cgi_state_t, 16, G_ALLOC_AND_FREE);

  3. #endif

  4. FCGX_Init();

Rather than spawn a thread every time, which is what FastCGI is meant to avoid in the first place, a thread pool is used. The pool is generated in non-exclusive mode to prevent all of them from being created at once. GLib provides no control over how many idle threads to create initially. Only the maximum number of threads is configurable.

<CGI Support Variables>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. static GThreadPool *cgi_thread_pool = NULL;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static void run_cgi_thread_pool(gpointer data, gpointer user_data)

  2. {

  3.   run_cgi_thread(data);

  4. }

<CGI Support Configuration>+= (U->) [<-D->]

  1. # Maximum number of FastCGI threads

  2. #max_cgi_threads = 64

<Perform global CGI support initialization>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cgi_thread_pool = g_thread_pool_new(run_cgi_thread_pool, NULL,

  2.                                     getconf_int("max_cgi_threads", 64),

  3.                                     FALSE, NULL);

<Spawn CGI thread>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. g_thread_pool_push(cgi_thread_pool, cgi_state, NULL);

Keeping track of whether or not the threads are finished can be done several ways. The simplest is to just keep a count; in fact, the count can be retrieved from the pool. However, there is no signal associated with the pool's thread count, so waiting for the pool to empty is not possible. Instead, an integer thread counter is used, along with a lock and signal.

<CGI Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static pthread_mutex_t cgi_state_lock = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER;

  2. static pthread_cond_t cgi_state_sig = PTHREAD_COND_INITIALIZER;

  3. static int cgi_thread_count = 0;

<Spawn CGI thread>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  2. ++cgi_thread_count;

  3. pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

<Clean up after CGI callback>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  2. --cgi_thread_count;

  3. pthread_cond_signal(&cgi_state_sig);

  4. pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

<Wait for remaining CGI threads>= (<-U)

  1. pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  2. while(cgi_thread_count > 0)

  3.   pthread_cond_wait(&cgi_state_sig, &cgi_state_lock);

  4. pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

Allocating a CGI state from a pool requries locking. The thread count lock can be reused for this purpose.

<CGI Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #if GLIB_MINOR_VERSION < 10 /* GMemChunk is deprecated */

  2. static GMemChunk *cgi_state_pool;

  3. #endif

<Allocate CGI state>= (<-U)

  1. #if GLIB_MINOR_VERSION < 10 /* GMemChunk is deprecated */

  2. pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  3. cgi_state = g_chunk_new0(cgi_state_t, cgi_state_pool);

  4. pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

  5. #else

  6. cgi_state = g_slice_new0(cgi_state_t);

  7. #endif

<Clean up after CGI callback>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. <Free CGI state members>

  2. #if GLIB_MINOR_VERSION < 10 /* GMemChunk is deprecated */

  3. pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  4. g_chunk_free(cgi_state, cgi_state_pool);

  5. pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

  6. #else

  7. g_slice_free(cgi_state_t, cgi_state);

  8. #endif

Since FastCGI programs are so similar to regular CGI programs, they should be expected to fall back to normal CGI behavior if invoked without FastCGI enabled. To support this, a global flag is used to distinguish the execution types, as well as macros to select the appropriate input and output funtions.

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>+= [<-D->]

  1. #include <stdarg.h>

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. extern gboolean is_cgi;

  2. #define cgi_puts(x) (is_cgi ? fputs(x, stdout) : \

  3.                               FCGX_PutS(x, cgi_state->req.out))

  4. #define cgi_putc(x) (is_cgi ? putchar(x) : \

  5.                               FCGX_PutChar(x, cgi_state->req.out))

  6. #define cgi_status(x) do { \

  7.   if(!is_cgi) \

  8.     FCGX_SetExitStatus(x, cgi_state->req.out); \

  9. } while(0)

  10. #define cgi_raw_gets(x, l) (is_cgi ? fgets(x, l, stdin) : \

  11.                                      FCGX_GetLine(x, l, cgi_state->req.in))

  12. #define cgi_raw_read(x, l) (is_cgi ? fread(x, 1, l, stdin) : \

  13.                                      FCGX_GetStr(x, l, cgi_state->req.in))

  14. #define cgi_write(x, l) (is_cgi ? fwrite(x, 1, l, stdout) : \

  15.                                   FCGX_PutStr(x, l, cgi_state->req.out))

  16. #define cgi_getenv(x) (is_cgi ? getenv(x) : \

  17.                                 FCGX_GetParam(x, cgi_state->req.envp))

  18. #define cgi_printf(f, ...) (is_cgi ? printf(f, __VA_ARGS__) : \

  19.                                      FCGX_FPrintF(cgi_state->req.out, f, \

  20.                                                   __VA_ARGS__))

  21. #define cgi_vprintf(f, a) (is_cgi ? vprintf(f, a) : \

  22.                                     FCGX_VFPrintF(cgi_state->req.out, f, a))

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>= [D->]

  1. int cgi_puts(const char *str);

  2. int cgi_putc(char c);

  3. int cgi_write(const char *buf, int length);

  4. int cgi_printf(const char *format, ...);

  5. int cgi_vprintf(const char *fmt, va_list parms);

  6. void cgi_status(int stat);

  7. int cgi_raw_gets(char *buf, int length);

  8. int cgi_raw_read(char *buf, int length);

  9. const char *cgi_getenv(const char *name);

<CGI Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. gboolean is_cgi;

<Perform global CGI support initialization>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. is_cgi = FCGX_IsCGI();

  2. if(debug && is_cgi)

  3.   setbuf(stdout, NULL);

<Spawn CGI thread>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(is_cgi)

  2.   break;

Unfortunately, not all operations are possible in threads. In particular, if there is a need to change the process identity via setuid(2) or similar functions, POSIX threads will change the identity for all threads in the process at the same time. Older Linux versions were buggy in that respect and in fact provided separate identities per thread, and in fact may still do so via setfsuid(2), but programs should not depend on buggy behavior or Linux-specific functions that may not even be exposed in the C library.

Rather than maintain a separate process pool, it is expected that the callback will do a fork and wait for the subprocess to finish. A simple wrapper function is provided to make implementation easier. The wrapper will return TRUE if the child code is to be executed. It will not call fork for single-run CGI programs.

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>+= [<-D->]

  1. #include <sys/wait.h>

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. gboolean cgi_fork(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   pid_t child_pid = is_cgi ? 0 : fork();

  4.   if(child_pid < 0) {

  5.     cgi_neo_error(cgi_state->cgi, nerr_raise_msg_errno("fork"));

  6.   } else if(child_pid) {

  7.     while(waitpid(child_pid, NULL, 0) < 0) {

  8.       if(errno != EINTR && errno != EAGAIN) {

  9.         cgi_neo_error(cgi_state->cgi, nerr_raise_msg_errno("fork"));

  10.         break;

  11.       }

  12.     }

  13.   }

  14.   return !child_pid;

  15. }

Sometimes it may be useful to print strings escaped. Rather than allocating a string, escaping into that memory, and then printing and freeing that memory, these functions print their parameters escaped. These functions are not in any which way Unicode compatible.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cgi_puts_url_escape(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, const char *s)

  2. {

  3.   const char *e;

  4.   while(*s) {

  5.     for(e = s; *e && (isalnum(*e) || *e == '.' || *e == '-' ||

  6.                                      *e == '_' ||*e == '~'); e++);

  7.     if(e != s)

  8.       if(cgi_write(s, (int)(e - s)) <= 0)

  9.         return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "CGI Write");

  10.     if(*e == ' ') {

  11.       if(cgi_putc('+') == EOF)

  12.         return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "CGI Write");

  13.     } else

  14.       if(cgi_printf("%%%02X", (int)*e) <= 0)

  15.         return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "CGI Write");

  16.     s = e + 1;

  17.   }

  18.   return STATUS_OK;

  19. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, const char *s,

  2.                              gboolean is_js)

  3. {

  4.   const char *e;

  5.   int ret;

  6.   while(*s) {

  7.     for(e = s; *e && (isgraph(*e) || *e == ' ' || *e == '\n') &&

  8.                *e != '<' && *e != '>' && *e != '&' && *e != '"' && *e != '\'' &&

  9.                (*e != '\\' || !is_js);

  10.         e++);

  11.     if(e != s)

  12.       if(cgi_write(s, (int)(e - s)) < 0)

  13.         return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "CGI Write");

  14.     if(!*e)

  15.       break;

  16.     if(*e == '<')

  17.       ret = cgi_puts("&lt;");

  18.     else if(*e == '>')

  19.       ret = cgi_puts("&gt;");

  20.     else if(*e == '&')

  21.       ret = cgi_puts("&amp;");

  22. #if 0  /* &#34; shorter & more portable than &quot; - same for ' and &apos; */

  23.     else if(*e == '"')

  24.       ret = cgi_puts("&quot;");

  25.     else if(*e == '\'')

  26.       ret = cgi_puts("&apos;");

  27. #endif

  28.     else if(*e == '\\')

  29.       ret = cgi_puts("\\\\");

  30.     else

  31.       ret = cgi_printf("&#%02X;", (int)*e) - 1; /* <= 0, not just < 0 -> err */

  32.     if(ret < 0)

  33.       return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "CGI Write");

  34.     s = e + 1;

  35.   }

  36.   return STATUS_OK;

  37. }

For building strings, GLib provides g_string_append_uri_escaped, but no equivalent for HTML escaping. Actually, before 2.16, it does not provide either. Since for most uses, the default behavior is fine, no support is provided for reserved_chars_allowed or allow_utf8 in the reimplementation of g_string_append_uri_escaped.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. GString *g_string_append_html_escaped(GString *buf, const char *s,

  2.                                       gboolean is_js)

  3. {

  4.   const char *e;

  5.   while(*s) {

  6.     for(e = s; *e && isgraph(*e) &&

  7.                *e != '<' && *e != '>' && *e != '&' && *e != '"' && *e != '\'' &&

  8.                (*e != '\\' || !is_js);

  9.         e++);

  10.     if(e != s)

  11.       g_string_append_len(buf, s, (int)(e - s));

  12.     if(!*e)

  13.       break;

  14.     if(*e == '<')

  15.       g_string_append(buf, "&lt;");

  16.     else if(*e == '>')

  17.       g_string_append(buf, "&gt;");

  18.     else if(*e == '&')

  19.       g_string_append(buf, "&amp;");

  20. #if 0  /* &#34; shorter & more portable than &quot; - same for ' and &apos; */

  21.     else if(*e == '"')

  22.       g_string_append(buf, "&quot;");

  23.     else if(*e == '\'')

  24.       g_string_append(buf, "&apos;");

  25. #endif

  26.     else if(*e == '\\')

  27.       g_string_append(buf, "\\\\");

  28.     else

  29.       g_string_append_printf(buf, "&#%02X;", (int)*e);

  30.     s = e + 1;

  31.   }

  32.   return buf;

  33. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #if !GLIB_CHECK_VERSION(2,16,0)

  2. GString *g_string_append_uri_escaped(GString *buf, const char *s,

  3.                                      const char *reserved,

  4.                                      gboolean utf8)

  5. {

  6.   const char *e;

  7.   while(*s) {

  8.     for(e = s; *e && (isalnum(*e) || *e == '.' || *e == '-' ||

  9.                                      *e == '_' ||*e == '~'); e++);

  10.     if(e != s)

  11.       g_string_append_len(buf, s, (int)(e - s));

  12.     if(*e == ' ')

  13.       g_string_append_c(buf, '+');

  14.     else

  15.       g_string_append_printf(buf, "%%%02X", (int)*e);

  16.     s = e + 1;

  17.   }

  18.   return buf;

  19. }

  20. #endif

JSON encoding is provided already for strings, but converting to a string before writing to CGI output may be inefficient for large objects and arrays. For this reason, a function is provided to use the string version for the leaf values, but to output the object and array delimiters directly. This limits the total size of dynamically allocated string buffers. Since reading JSON from a CGI stream will never happen (CGI input is always parsed as CGI parameters), no equivalent input function is provided.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cgi_output_json(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, HDF *hdf)

  2. {

  3.   GString *buf;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  5. #define io_nerr_op(op) do { \

  6.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && op < 0) \

  7.     nerr = nerr_raise_msg_errno("JSON output"); \

  8. } while(0)

  9.   if(hdf_obj_child(hdf)) {

  10.     json_var_type vt = hdf_json_var_type(hdf);

  11.     if(vt == JSON_ARRAY) {

  12.       char c = '[';

  13.       hdf_sort_obj(hdf, comp_hdf_name);

  14.       for(hdf = hdf_obj_child(hdf); hdf; hdf = hdf_obj_next(hdf)) {

  15.         io_nerr_op(cgi_putc(c));

  16.         c = ',';

  17.         nerr_op(cgi_output_json(cgi_state, hdf));

  18.       }

  19.       io_nerr_op(cgi_putc(']'));

  20.     } else {

  21.       buf = g_string_new("");

  22.       char c = '{';

  23.       for(hdf = hdf_obj_child(hdf); hdf; hdf = hdf_obj_next(hdf)) {

  24.         io_nerr_op(cgi_putc(c));

  25.         c = ',';

  26.         g_string_truncate(buf, 0);

  27.         append_unicode_quoted(buf, hdf_obj_name(hdf));

  28.         io_nerr_op(cgi_puts(buf->str));

  29.         io_nerr_op(cgi_putc(':'));

  30.         nerr_op(cgi_output_json(cgi_state, hdf));

  31.       }

  32.       io_nerr_op(cgi_putc('}'));

  33.       g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  34.     }

  35.     return nerr;

  36.   }

  37.   buf = g_string_new("");

  38.   g_string_append_json(buf, hdf);

  39.   cgi_puts(buf->str);

  40.   g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  41.   return nerr;

  42. }

Any errors that occur should be printed to the user, but not with the standard error reporting mechanism. Instead, they should be reported via the CGI output stream. Unfortunately, that is impossible during initial setup for FastCGI programs, so a dummy NULL CGI state indicates that regular output should be used instead. If the CGI state exists, it is assumed that the call is from a NEOERR returning function, so the error is simply returned. This breaks usage in the mainline even though it never gets invoked, so DIE_IF_ERR is toggled from the error to a static 1 in the mainline. Once an error is returned from the primary callback, it is displayed to the user.

<CGI Message Overrides>= (U-> U->)

  1. #undef die_if_err

  2. #define die_if_err(err) do { \

  3.   NEOERR *_err = err; \

  4.  \

  5.   if(_err != STATUS_OK) { \

  6.     if(cgi_state) \

  7.       return DIE_IF_ERR; \

  8.     else if(!is_cgi) \

  9.       nerr_log_error(_err); \

  10.     else \

  11.       cgi_log_error_stdout(_err); \

  12.     exit(1); \

  13.   } \

  14. } while(0)

  15. #define DIE_IF_ERR _err

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. <CGI Message Overrides>

<CGI Mainline Variables>= (U->)

  1. <(cs-glib.nw) Common Mainline Variables>

  2. cgi_state_t *cgi_state unused_attr = NULL;

  3. #undef DIE_IF_ERR

  4. #define DIE_IF_ERR 1

<CGI Per-Run Variables>= (U->)

  1. <(cs-glib.nw) Common Mainline Variables>

The error itself is printed as HTML or HTTP text, from a template. The HTTP header can be suppressed by setting the header_printed variable to non-blank in the CGI state's HDF. The default status of 500 can also be overridden by setting the error_status variable. The text to print can also be overridden by a template by setting the error_tmpl variable, which may use the error text in error_text. If the HTML tags have already been printed, the XML will become invalid, and if they haven't, the document type will not be printed. In either case, most browsers will print the message anyway, and don't care. Note that in addition to the ability to override the header, this differs from the standard kit's cgi_neo_error in that it will HTML-escape the message.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void cgi_log_error_stdout(NEOERR *nerr)

  2. {

  3.   is_cgi = TRUE;

  4.   cgi_log_error(nerr, NULL, local_config);

  5. }

  6. void cgi_log_error(NEOERR *nerr, cgi_state_t *cgi_state, HDF *hdf)

  7. {

  8.   cgi_state_t _cgi_state;

  9.   if(!cgi_state) {

  10.     cgi_state = &_cgi_state;

  11.     cgi_state->hdf = hdf;

  12.   }

  13.   if(!*cgi_env_val("header_printed", "")) {

  14.     const char *status = cgi_env_val("error_status", NULL);

  15.     if(!status || !*status)

  16.       status = "500 Internal Server Error";

  17.     cgi_status(atoi(status));

  18.     cgi_puts("Content-type: text/html\nStatus: ");

  19.     cgi_puts(status);

  20.     cgi_puts("\n\n");

  21.   }

  22.   <(cs-glib.nw) Convert nerr to err_str>

  23.   const char *tmpl = cgi_env_val("error_tmpl", NULL);

  24.   if(tmpl && *tmpl) {

  25.     NEOERR *nerr2 = cgi_env_set("error_text", err_str.buf);

  26.     if(nerr2 == STATUS_OK)

  27.       nerr2 = tmpl_to_cgi(tmpl, cgi_state, FALSE);

  28.     if(nerr2 != STATUS_OK) {

  29.       tmpl = NULL;

  30.       nerr_ignore(&nerr2);

  31.     }

  32.   }

  33.   if(!tmpl || !*tmpl) {

  34.     cgi_puts("<html><body>An error occurred:<pre>\n");

  35.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, err_str.buf, FALSE);

  36.     cgi_puts("</pre></body></html>");

  37.   }

  38.   string_clear(&err_str);

  39. }

<Display error from CGI callback>= (<-U)

  1. cgi_log_error(nerr, cgi_state, NULL);

<CGI Support Configuration>+= (U->) [<-D->]

  1. # Set to non-blank to override message to print on errors

  2. # This is evaluated as a ClearSilver template in the CGI environment; the

  3. # text of the error message is in the error_text variable.

  4. # The default message prints:

  5. #  <html><body><h3>An error occurred while processing your request:</h3><pre>

  6. #  <?cs var:error_text ?></pre></body></html>

  7. #error_tmpl = <html><body><h3>An error occurred while processing ...

  8. # Set to non-blank to override the status to return on errors

  9. #error_status = 500 Internal Server Error

  10. # Set to non-blank to disable printing the HTTP header for error messages

  11. # This is usually set by any template which prints an HTTP header.

  12. #header_printed =

The only thing that really needs to be prepared for the CGI thread other than allocating the CGI state is to wait for a CGI request and assign the appropriate information to the FastCGI request structure. For plain CGI requests, there is no need to fill in a request at all.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. FCGX_Request req;

<Prepare for CGI thread>= (<-U)

  1. if(!is_cgi) {

  2.   FCGX_InitRequest(&cgi_state->req, 0, 0);

  3.   if(FCGX_Accept_r(&cgi_state->req) < 0) {

  4.     pthread_mutex_lock(&cgi_state_lock);

  5.     --cgi_thread_count;

  6. #if GLIB_MINOR_VERSION < 10 /* GMemChunk is deprecated */

  7.     g_chunk_free(cgi_state, cgi_state_pool);

  8. #else

  9.     g_slice_free(cgi_state_t, cgi_state);

  10. #endif

  11.     pthread_mutex_unlock(&cgi_state_lock);

  12.     break;

  13.   }

  14. }

<Free CGI state members>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. if(!is_cgi) {

  2.   FCGX_Finish_r(&cgi_state->req);

  3.   /* FCGX_Free(&cgi_state->req); */ /* freeing supposedly done by Finish */

  4. }

Support for macros in FastCGI programs is partially provided by the HDF forms of the template processing routines. However, the ones providing just file output are inappropriate. Instead, CGI output versions are provided.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cs_to_cgi(void *user, char *str)

  2. {

  3.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = user;

  4.   return cgi_puts(str) < 0 ? nerr_raise_msg_errno("Writing") : STATUS_OK;

  5. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *tmpl_to_cgi_hdf(const char *tmpl, HDF *parms, cgi_state_t *cgi_state,

  2.                         gboolean raw)

  3. {

  4.   return nerr_pass(tmpl_string_to(tmpl, parms, cs_to_cgi, cgi_state, raw));

  5. }

  6. NEOERR *tmpl_to_cgi(const char *tmpl, cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean raw)

  7. {

  8.   return nerr_pass(tmpl_to_cgi_hdf(tmpl, cgi_state->hdf, cgi_state, raw));

  9. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *tmpl_file_to_cgi_hdf(const char *tmpl, HDF *parms,

  2.                              cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean raw)

  3. {

  4.   return nerr_pass(tmpl_file_to(tmpl, parms, cs_to_cgi, cgi_state, raw));

  5. }

  6. NEOERR *tmpl_file_to_cgi(const char *tmpl, cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean raw)

  7. {

  8.   return nerr_pass(tmpl_file_to_cgi_hdf(tmpl, cgi_state->hdf, cgi_state, raw));

  9. }

CGI Parameter Parsing

Once in the thread, though, the real work starts. A function is provided to do most of the initialization work. First, the CGI kit environment must be initialized. This includes setting the function overrides that will enable FastCGI. The putenv and iterenv functions are not provided; this means that the CGI kit's debug_init for reading parameters from configuration files will not work, and the cgi_output and cgi_display functions will not work with debugging turned on. The CGI parameters will be merged with the global program-wide parameters, so a copy of those global parameters must be made to pass into the kit.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static int read_fcgi(void *parm, char *data, int len)

  2. {

  3.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = parm;

  4.   <Read data from CGI stream>

  5. }

  6. static int writef_fcgi(void *parm, const char *fmt, va_list args)

  7. {

  8.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = parm;

  9.   return cgi_vprintf(fmt, args);

  10. }

  11. static int write_fcgi(void *parm, const char *data, int len)

  12. {

  13.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = parm;

  14.   return cgi_write(data, len);

  15. }

  16. static char *getenv_fcgi(void *parm, const char *name)

  17. {

  18.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = parm;

  19.   /* NOTE: return value *must* be malloc'd */

  20.   const char *s = cgi_getenv(name);

  21.   if(s)

  22.     return strdup(s);

  23.   else

  24.     return NULL;

  25. }

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. HDF *hdf;

  2. CGI *cgi;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *init_cgi_run(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  4.   if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_init(&cgi_state->hdf)))

  5.     return nerr;

  6.   if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_copy(cgi_state->hdf, NULL, local_config)))

  7.     return nerr;

  8.   cgiwrap_init_emu(cgi_state, read_fcgi, writef_fcgi, write_fcgi, getenv_fcgi,

  9.                    NULL, NULL);

  10.   if(!nerr_op_ok(cgi_init(&cgi_state->cgi, cgi_state->hdf)))

  11.     return nerr;

  12.   cgi_state->hdf = cgi_state->cgi->hdf; /* in case it changed */

  13.   <Initialize this CGI run>

  14.   return nerr;

  15. }

<Free CGI state members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. <Perform cleanups requiring valid CGI parameters>

  2. if(cgi_state->cgi)

  3.   cgi_destroy(&cgi_state->cgi);

  4. else if(cgi_state->hdf)

  5.   hdf_destroy(&cgi_state->hdf);

For convenience, the CGI parameters and cookies are stored separately in the CGI state structure. If none were created by cgi_init from the environment, empty HDF entries will be created. A few macros are provided as well for quick access.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. HDF *cgi_parms, *cookies;

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define cgi_env_val(n, d) hdf_get_value(cgi_state->hdf, n, d)

  2. #define cgi_env_val_int(n, d) hdf_get_int64_value(cgi_state->hdf, n, d)

  3. #define cgi_env_set(n, v) hdf_set_value(cgi_state->hdf, n, v)

  4. #define cgi_env_set_int(n, v) hdf_set_int64_value(cgi_state->hdf, n, v)

  5. #define cgi_env_obj(n) hdf_get_obj(cgi_state->hdf, n)

  6. #define cgi_parm_val(n, d) hdf_get_value(cgi_state->cgi_parms, n, d)

  7. #define cgi_parm_val_int(n, d) hdf_get_int64_value(cgi_state->cgi_parms, n, d)

  8. #define cgi_parm_obj(n) hdf_get_obj(cgi_state->cgi_parms, n)

  9. #define cgi_parm_set(n, v) hdf_set_value(cgi_state->cgi_parms, n, v)

  10. #define cgi_parm_set_int(n, v) hdf_set_int64_value(cgi_state->cgi_parms, n, v)

  11. #define cgi_cookie_val(n, d) hdf_get_value(cgi_state->cookies, n, d)

  12. #define cgi_cookie_val_int(n, d) hdf_get_int64_value(cgi_state->cookies, n, d)

  13. #define cgi_cookie_obj(n) hdf_get_obj(cgi_state->cookies, n)

  14. #define cgi_cookie_set(n, v) hdf_set_value(cgi_state->cookies, n, v)

  15. #define cgi_cookie_set_int(n, v) hdf_set_int64_value(cgi_state->cookies, n, v)

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D->]

  1. const char *cgi_env_val(const char *name, const char *def);

  2. gint64 cgi_env_val_int(const char *name, gint64 def);

  3. NEOERR *cgi_env_set(const char *name, const char *value);

  4. NEOERR *cgi_env_set_int(const char *name, gint64 value);

  5. HDF *cgi_env_obj(const char *name);

  6. const char *cgi_parm_val(const char *name, const char *def);

  7. gint64 cgi_parm_val_int(const char *name, gint64 def);

  8. HDF *cgi_parm_obj(const char *name);

  9. NEOERR *cgi_parm_set(const char *name, const char *value);

  10. NEOERR *cgi_parm_set_int(const char *name, gint64 value);

  11. const char *cgi_cookie_val(const char *name, const char *def);

  12. gint64 cgi_cookie_val_int(const char *name, gint64 def);

  13. HDF *cgi_cookie_obj(const char *name);

  14. NEOERR *cgi_cookie_set(const char *name, const char *value);

  15. NEOERR *cgi_cookie_set_int(const char *name, gint64 value);

<Initialize this CGI run>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_get_node(cgi_state->hdf, "Query", &cgi_state->cgi_parms)))

  2.   return nerr;

  3. if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_get_node(cgi_state->hdf, "Cookie", &cgi_state->cookies)))

  4.   return nerr;

In addition, some looping macros are provided to support the standard method of storing a single-valued CGI parameter as just a value, and a multi-valued parameter as children.

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define for_each_cgi_parm_obj(obj, f, ...) do { \

  2.   if(hdf_obj_child(obj)) { \

  3.     for(obj = hdf_obj_child(obj); obj && nerr == STATUS_OK; \

  4.                                                     obj = hdf_obj_next(obj)) \

  5.       f(obj, __VA_ARGS__); \

  6.   } else \

  7.     f(obj, __VA_ARGS__); \

  8. } while(0)

  9. #define for_each_cgi_parm(p, f, ...) do { \

  10.   HDF *__p = cgi_parm_obj(p); \

  11.   for_each_cgi_parm_obj(__p, f, __VA_ARGS__); \

  12. } while(0)

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D->]

  1. void (*for_each_cb)(HDF *obj, ...);

  2. void for_each_cgi_parm_obj(HDF *obj, for_each_cb f, ...);

  3. void for_each_cgi_parm(const char *name, for_each_cb f, ...);

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. for_each_cb,%

There are a number of HTTP headers which the CGI kit does not turn into HDF parameters, but which are relevant. Instead of picking headers to add, all HTTP headers are added as HDF parameters. Case is converted the same way as the standard ones, and all are added under the HTTP hierarchy. The only one that will end up duplicated is the differently named HTTP_SOAPACTION translation to Soap.Action. For convenience, the HTTP headers are also stored in the CGI state directly.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. HDF *headers;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. GString *header_env = g_string_new("");

  2. /* const */ char **envp;

  3. /* NOTE: POSIX says environ should be in unistd.h, but GNU considers it */

  4. /* an extension.  It could also come from 3rd main() parm, but adding */

  5. /* that to CGI apps would cause cproto to break apps that don't use it */

  6. extern char **environ;

  7. for(envp = is_cgi ? environ : cgi_state->req.envp; *envp; envp++)

  8.   if(!strncmp(*envp, "HTTP_", 5)) {

  9.     const char *s;

  10.     char *d;

  11.     gboolean firstc = TRUE;

  12.     g_string_assign(header_env, *envp);

  13.     header_env->str[4] = '.';

  14.     for(s = d = header_env->str + 5; *s && *s != '='; s++, d++) {

  15.       if(*s == '_') {

  16.         firstc = TRUE;

  17.         d--;

  18.       } else if(firstc) {

  19.         firstc = FALSE;

  20.         *d = toupper(*s);

  21.       } else

  22.         *d = tolower(*s);

  23.     }

  24.     if(*s == '=') {

  25.       *d = 0;

  26.       if(!cgi_env_obj(header_env->str))

  27.         nerr_op(cgi_env_set(header_env->str, s + 1));

  28.     }

  29.   }

  30. g_string_free(header_env, TRUE);

  31. nerr_op(hdf_get_node(cgi_state->hdf, "HTTP", &cgi_state->headers));

  32. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  33.   return nerr;

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define cgi_header_obj(n) hdf_get_obj(cgi_state->headers, n)

  2. #define cgi_header_val(n, d) hdf_get_value(cgi_state->headers, n, d)

  3. #define cgi_header_val_int(n, d) hdf_get_int64_value(cgi_state->headers, n, d)

  4. #define cgi_header_set(n, v) hdf_set_value(cgi_state->headers, n, v)

  5. #define cgi_header_set_int(n, v) hdf_set_int64_value(cgi_state->headers, n, v)

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D->]

  1. HDF *cgi_header_obj(const char *name);

  2. const char *cgi_header_val(const char *name, const char *def_val);

  3. gint64 cgi_header_val_int(const char *name, gint64 def_val);

  4. NEOERR *cgi_header_set(const char *name, const char *val);

  5. NEOERR *cgi_header_set_int(const char *name, gint64 val);

A few other shortcuts could be set in the CGI state as well. For now, only the user ID is stored.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *userid;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cgi_state->userid = cgi_env_val("CGI.RemoteUser", NULL);

After all of the CGI parameters have been parsed, it might be useful to print them. This is only done if debugging is enabled. Although this prints an HTTP header, the header_printed variable is not set, so that the intended headers are displayed in the debugging output as well.

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(debug) {

  2.   cgi_status(200);

  3.   cgi_puts("Status: 200\nContent-type: text/html\n\n"

  4.            "<html><head><title>Debug output</title></head><body>");

  5.   cgi_dump_hdf(cgi_state);

  6. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void cgi_dump_hdf(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr;

  4.   STRING ps;

  5.   cgi_puts("CGI Parameters:<pre>\n");

  6.   string_init(&ps);

  7.   nerr = hdf_dump_str(cgi_state->hdf, "", 2, &ps);

  8.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && ps.buf)

  9.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, ps.buf, FALSE);

  10.   else

  11.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  12.   string_clear(&ps);

  13.   cgi_puts("--------</pre>\n");

  14. }

Traditional CGI programs only need to deal with a few request methods; usually just GET and POST, and maybe HEAD. However, WebDAV adds a whole bunch of new methods, so this library must support dealing with a large number of methods. In order to avoid repeated string comparisons, the method is converted into an integer code, stored in the CGI state, if it is one of the known methods.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. http_req_t req_method;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *method = cgi_env_val("CGI.RequestMethod", "GET");

  2. http_req_t req_method = http_req_id(method, strlen(method));

  3. cgi_state->req_method = req_method;

<CGI State Dependencies>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #include "cgi.h.gperf"

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #include "cgi.c.gperf"

<cgi-gperf-nc-http_req>=

  1. <Known HTTP Requests>

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. http_req_t,%

<(build.nw) makefile.rules>= [D->]

  1. cgi.h: cgi.h.gperf

  2. cgi.c: cgi.c.gperf

Methods known and possibly dealt with here are:

RFC 26164
HTTP: OPTIONS GET HEAD POST PUT DELETE TRACE CONNECT
RFC 49185
WebDAV: PROPFIND PROPPATCH MKCOL COPY MOVE LOCK UNLOCK
RFC 32536
WebDAV Versioning: REPORT VERSION-CONTROL CHECKOUT CHECKIN UNCHECKOUT MKWORKSPACE UPDATE LABEL MERGE BASELINE-CONTROL MKACTIVITY
RFC 36487
WebDAV Ordered Collections: ORDERPATCH
RFC 37448
WebDAV Access Control: ACL
RFC 44379
WebDAV Redirect References: MKREDIRECTREF UPDATEREDIRECTREF
RFC 479110
WebDAV Calendaring: MKCALENDAR
RFC 532311
WebDAV Search: SEARCH

Any methods not covered here can be added by extending <Known HTTP Requests>.

<Known HTTP Requests>= (<-U)

  1. OPTIONS GET HEAD POST PUT DELETE TRACE CONNECT

  2. PROPFIND PROPPATCH MKCOL COPY MOVE LOCK UNLOCK

  3. REPORT VERSION-CONTROL CHECKOUT CHECKIN UNCHECKOUT MKWORKSPACE UPDATE LABEL

  4. MERGE BASELINE-CONTROL MKACTIVITY

  5. ORDERPATCH

  6. ACL

  7. MKREDIRECTREF UPDATEREDIRECTREF

  8. MKCALENDAR

  9. SEARCH

Most requests take paths as their argument: either from the request URI (actually PATH_INFO), from headers, or from CGI parameters. All of these paths must be normalized before real use. One way of normalizing them is to just use the underlying file system to resolve to an absolute path. Another is to normalize just the path itself. A normalization function is provided to transform an HDF object's value into a path similar to PATH_INFO: an absolute path with the CGI program information optionally removed. This function takes the path it may be relative to as an argument; setting that argument to NULL means that the value must be either an absolute path or an absolute URL. No URL detection takes place if the path may be relative. Also, if a relative parent is provided, it must be normalized. If it is a directory, it must have a terminating slash. Otherwise, the trailing component is removed for relative references. Any further filesystem-specific normalization, such as home directory and soft link resolution, must be done by the applicaiton program.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *normalize_path_obj(HDF *obj, cgi_state_t *cgi_state,

  2.                            const char *relative_to, gboolean utf_8,

  3.                            gboolean strip_cgi_script)

  4. {

  5.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  6.   const char *oval = hdf_obj_value(obj);

  7.   

  8.   <Normalize path obj/oval UTF-8>

  9.   if(*oval != '/') {

  10.     if(relative_to) {

  11.       <Prepend relative_to to obj/oval>

  12.       /* relative_to is assumed to be already stripped */

  13.       strip_cgi_script = FALSE;

  14.     } else {

  15.       <Strip URL from obj/oval>

  16.     }

  17.   }

  18.   if(strip_cgi_script) {

  19.     <Strip CGI script from obj/oval>

  20.   }

  21.   <Strip . and .. from obj/oval>

  22.   return nerr;

  23. }

<Normalize path obj/oval UTF-8>= (<-U)

  1. if(utf_8) {

  2.   char *nv = g_utf8_normalize(oval, -1, G_NORMALIZE_DEFAULT);

  3.   if(!nv)

  4.     return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid UTF-8 path");

  5.   if(!strcmp(nv, oval))

  6.     g_free(nv);

  7.   else {

  8.     hdf_set_buf(obj, NULL, nv);

  9.     oval = nv;

  10.   }

  11. }

<Prepend relative_to to obj/oval>= (<-U)

  1. GString *full_path = g_string_new(relative_to);

  2. char *rtls = strrchr(full_path->str, '/');

  3. if(rtls)

  4.   g_string_truncate(full_path, (int)(rtls - full_path->str));

  5. g_string_append_c(full_path, '/');

  6. g_string_append(full_path, oval);

  7. hdf_set_buf(obj, NULL, g_string_free(full_path, FALSE));

<Strip URL from obj/oval>= (<-U)

  1. gboolean is_https = !!cgi_env_val("CGI.HTTPS", NULL);

  2. const char *cmpstr = cgi_header_val("Host", "localhost");

  3. int cmplen = strlen(cmpstr);

  4. if(strncmp(oval, "http", 4) || (is_https && (++oval)[4] != 's') ||

  5.    strncmp((oval += 4), "://", 3) ||

  6.    strncasecmp((oval += 3), cmpstr, cmplen))

  7.   return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid URL");

  8. oval += cmplen;

  9. if(*oval == ':') {

  10.   cmpstr = cgi_header_val("CGI.ServerPort", is_https ? "443" : "80");

  11.   cmplen = strlen(cmpstr);

  12.   if(strncasecmp(oval + 1, cmpstr, cmplen))

  13.     return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid URL");

  14.   oval += cmplen + 1;

  15. }

  16. <Strip CGI script from obj/oval>

  17. if(*oval != '/')

  18.   return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid URL");

<Strip CGI script from obj/oval>= (<-U <-U)

  1. const char *scrn = cgi_header_val("CGI.ScriptName", "");

  2. int scrlen = strlen(scrn);

  3. if(strncmp(oval, scrn, scrlen))

  4.   return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid URL");

  5. oval += scrlen;

  6. if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_set_value(obj, NULL, oval)))

  7.   return nerr;

  8. oval = hdf_obj_value(obj);

<Strip . and .. from obj/oval>= (<-U)

  1. char *s = strchr(oval, '/');

  2. if(s && (s[1] == '/' ||

  3.          (s[1] == '.' && (!s[2] || s[2] == '/' ||

  4.                           (s[2] == '.' && (!s[3] || s[3] == '/')))))) {

  5.   char *d = s;

  6.   do {

  7.     if(s[1] == '/')

  8.       s++;

  9.     else if(s[2] != '.')

  10.       s += 2;

  11.     else if(d == oval)

  12.       return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid relative path (..)");

  13.     else {

  14.       while(--d > oval && *d != '/');

  15.       s += 3;

  16.     }

  17.     while(*s && (*s != '/' || (s[1] != '/' &&

  18.                                (s[1] != '.' ||

  19.                                 (s[2] && s[2] != '/' &&

  20.                                  (s[2] != '.' || (s[3] &&

  21.                                                   s[3] != '/')))))))

  22.      *d++ = *s++;

  23.   } while(*s);

  24. }

Content Decoding

Normally, the CGI input stream is read directly, using e.g. fread. However, reading data from is not always that simple. For apache, at least, transport encoding is taken care of by the web server12 , but content encoding is not. There may be value in saving the encoded stream directly, if the CGI program will just end up serving the same data encoded the same way, but most applications want their data decoded. There are several things that can be done about this. First of all, the content encoding and content length are stored in the CGI state for quick reference. Since the content length might not be accurate due to apache's losing it with chunked transfer-encoding, execution from the command line, or other reasons, a zero length is not trusted. If the content length is zero, a single character is read from the input stream; if it wasnt end-of-file, then content length is set to -1 to indicate data is present, but of unknown length.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *body_enc;

  2. gint64 body_len;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cgi_state->body_enc = cgi_header_val("ContentEncoding", NULL);

  2. if(cgi_state->body_enc && (!*cgi_state->body_enc ||

  3.                            !strcmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "identity")))

  4.   cgi_state->body_enc = NULL;

  5. cgi_state->body_len = cgi_env_val_int("CGI.ContentLength", 0);

  6. if(!cgi_state->body_len) {

  7.   int c = is_cgi ? getchar() : FCGX_GetChar(cgi_state->req.in);

  8.   if(c != EOF) {

  9.     cgi_env_set_int("CGI.ContentLength", (cgi_state->body_len = -1));

  10.     if(is_cgi)

  11.       ungetc(c, stdin);

  12.     else

  13.       FCGX_UnGetChar(c, cgi_state->req.in);

  14.   }

  15. }

Next, the standard encoding methods should be supported. A new set of input functions and macros is used to select the decoded stream. The first call initializes the decoder, and the final cleanup cleans it up.

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define cgi_gets(s, l) cgi_decode_gets(cgi_state, s, l)

  2. #define cgi_read(s, l, rl) cgi_decode_read(cgi_state, s, l, rl)

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cgi_gets(char *buf, int length);

  2. NEOERR *cgi_read(char *buf, int length, int *retlength);

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *cgi_decode_gets(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, char *buf, int length)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr;

  4.   if(!cgi_state->body_enc) {

  5.     if(!cgi_raw_gets(buf, length))

  6.       return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error reading body");

  7.     else

  8.       return STATUS_OK;

  9.   }

  10.   <Initialize body decoder>

  11.   <Decode a string into buf/length>

  12. }

  13. NEOERR *cgi_decode_read(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, char *buf, int length,

  14.                         int *retlength)

  15. {

  16.   int ret;

  17.   NEOERR *nerr;

  18.   if(!cgi_state->body_enc) {

  19.     *retlength = ret = cgi_raw_read(buf, length);

  20.     if(ret < 0)

  21.       return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error reading body");

  22.     else

  23.       return STATUS_OK;

  24.   }

  25.   <Initialize body decoder>

  26.   <Decode data into buf/length>

  27. }

<Read data from CGI stream>= (<-U)

  1. NEOERR *nerr = cgi_read(data, len, &len);

  2. if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  3.   return len;

  4. nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  5. return -1;

The gzip, x-gzip, and deflate methods can be handled by zlib13. There is no simple library which supports the compress method, but beginning with version 2.8, libarchive14 can be used for this. This was originally tested using 2.7.902a; thus the version barrier uses this number rather than 2.8. The undefined bzip2 methods are handled by libarchive as well. Both of these methods require a separate buffer for I/O; zlib needs one for input and one for output, and libarchive allocates output buffers internally, so it only needs one for input.

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>+= [<-D->]

  1. EXTRA_LDFLAGS += -lz $(LIBAR_LDFLAGS) -larchive

  2. EXTRA_CFLAGS += $(LIBAR_CFLAGS)

<(build.nw) makefile.config>+= [<-D->]

  1. # Extra flags needed to find libarchive 2.8

  2. LIBAR_CFLAGS = -I/usr/local/include

  3. LIBAR_LDFLAGS = -L/usr/local/lib

<CGI Prerequisite Headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #include <zlib.h>

  2. #include <archive.h>

  3. #include <archive_entry.h>

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. z_stream *dec_zs;

  2. struct archive *dec_ar;

  3. char *dec_buf;

  4. #define DEC_BUF_LEN 65536

<Initialize body decoder>= (<-U)

  1. if(!cgi_state->dec_buf) {

  2.   /* decoding invalidates body length */

  3.   if(cgi_state->body_enc && cgi_state->body_len >= 0)

  4.     cgi_env_set_int("CGI.ContentLength", (cgi_state->body_len = -1));

  5.   if(!strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "gzip") ||

  6.      !strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "x-gzip") ||

  7.      !strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "deflate")) {

  8.     /* type is auto-detected by zlib, although we probably ought */

  9.     /* to verify that advertised method matches detected method */

  10.     <Initialize decoding for zlib>

  11. #if ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER >= 2007902

  12.   } else if(!strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "compress") ||

  13.             !strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "x-compress") ||

  14.             !strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "bzip2") ||

  15.             !strcasecmp(cgi_state->body_enc, "x-bzip2")) {

  16.     <Initialize decoding for libarchive>

  17. #endif

  18.   } else {

  19.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "415 Unsupported Media Type");

  20.     return nerr_raise(GENERIC_ERR, "Encoding type %s not supported",

  21.                       cgi_state->body_enc);

  22.   }

  23. }

<Initialize decoding for zlib>= (<-U)

  1. cgi_state->dec_buf = malloc(2 * DEC_BUF_LEN);

  2. if(cgi_state->dec_buf)

  3.   cgi_state->dec_zs = calloc(sizeof(*cgi_state->dec_zs), 1);

  4. if(!cgi_state->dec_zs)

  5.   return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error decoding body");

<Initialize decoding for libarchive>= (<-U)

  1. struct archive_entry *ae; /* dummy */

  2. cgi_state->dec_buf = malloc(DEC_BUF_LEN);

  3. if(cgi_state->dec_buf)

  4.   cgi_state->dec_ar = archive_read_new();

  5. ae = archive_entry_new();

  6. if(!cgi_state->dec_ar || !ae ||

  7.    archive_read_support_compression_compress(cgi_state->dec_ar) ||

  8.    archive_read_support_compression_bzip2(cgi_state->dec_ar) ||

  9.    archive_read_support_format_raw(cgi_state->dec_ar) ||

  10.    archive_read_open(cgi_state->dec_ar, cgi_state, NULL, read_cgi_for_ar, NULL) ||

  11.    archive_read_next_header2(cgi_state->dec_ar, ae)) {

  12.   if(ae)

  13.     archive_entry_free(ae);

  14.   return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error decoding body");

  15. }

<Free CGI state members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(cgi_state->dec_zs) {

  2.   inflateEnd(cgi_state->dec_zs);

  3.   free(cgi_state->dec_zs);

  4. }

  5. #if ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER >= 2007902

  6. if(cgi_state->dec_ar)

  7.   archive_read_finish(cgi_state->dec_ar);

  8. #endif

  9. if(cgi_state->dec_buf)

  10.   free(cgi_state->dec_buf);

The decoders should be run independently of the data requests, filling an output buffer as needed. This requires that an output buffer pointer and length be stored in the CGI state. Since the existence of the decoding buffer, rather than the existence of either decoder's state, is used to indicate decoding is needed, the decoder's state can be closed and freed on end of file, while still allowing the last output buffer to be used. This is really only possible with zlib, because libarchive allocates output buffers internally. Instead, libarchive decoding is cleared after the last read.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *dec_out;

  2. int dec_out_len;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *fill_decode_buffer(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   if(cgi_state->dec_zs) {

  4.     int ret = Z_OK;

  5.     z_stream *zs = cgi_state->dec_zs;

  6.     while(ret == Z_OK) {

  7.       if(!zs->avail_in) {

  8.         zs->next_in = (Bytef *)cgi_state->dec_buf;

  9.         zs->avail_in = cgi_raw_read(cgi_state->dec_buf, DEC_BUF_LEN);

  10.         if(zs->avail_in < 0)

  11.           return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error decoding body");

  12.       }

  13.       zs->next_out = (Bytef *)cgi_state->dec_buf + DEC_BUF_LEN;

  14.       zs->avail_out = DEC_BUF_LEN;

  15.       ret = inflate(zs, Z_SYNC_FLUSH);

  16.       if(zs->avail_out < DEC_BUF_LEN || ret == Z_STREAM_END) {

  17.         cgi_state->dec_out = cgi_state->dec_buf + DEC_BUF_LEN;

  18.         cgi_state->dec_out_len = DEC_BUF_LEN - zs->avail_out;

  19.         break;

  20.       }

  21.     }

  22.     if(ret == Z_STREAM_END) {

  23.       inflateEnd(zs);

  24.       free(zs);

  25.       cgi_state->dec_zs = NULL;

  26.     } else if(ret != Z_OK)

  27.       return nerr_raise_msg("Error decoding body");

  28. #if ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER >= 2007902

  29.   } else if(cgi_state->dec_ar) {

  30.     const void *outbuf;

  31.     off_t outoff;

  32.     size_t outlen;

  33.     int ret = archive_read_data_block(cgi_state->dec_ar, &outbuf, &outlen,

  34.                                       &outoff);

  35.     if(ret != ARCHIVE_OK && ret != ARCHIVE_EOF)

  36.       return nerr_raise_msg(archive_error_string(cgi_state->dec_ar));

  37.     cgi_state->dec_out = outbuf;

  38.     cgi_state->dec_out_len = outlen;

  39.     /* raw format has no gaps, so outoff can be ignored */

  40.     if(ret == ARCHIVE_EOF) {

  41.       archive_read_finish(cgi_state->dec_ar);

  42.       cgi_state->dec_ar = NULL;

  43.     }

  44. #endif

  45.   }

  46.   return STATUS_OK;

  47. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #if ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER >= 2007902

  2. ssize_t read_cgi_for_ar(struct archive *ar, void *cbdata, const void **buf)

  3. {

  4.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = cbdata;

  5.   int ret;

  6.   *buf = cgi_state->dec_buf;

  7.   ret = cgi_raw_read(cgi_state->dec_buf, DEC_BUF_LEN);

  8.   if(ret < 0)

  9.     archive_set_error(ar, errno, "Error decoding body");

  10.   return ret;

  11. }

  12. #endif

The specific action for the read function is to just return as much available data as possible, and to update the output buffer pointers.

<Get more decoded data>= (U-> U->)

  1. if(!cgi_state->dec_out_len) {

  2.   nerr = fill_decode_buffer(cgi_state);

  3.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK || !cgi_state->dec_out_len) {

  4.     if(cgi_state->dec_buf) {

  5.       free(cgi_state->dec_buf);

  6.       cgi_state->dec_buf = NULL;

  7.     }

  8.     return nerr;

  9.   }

  10. }

<Decode data into buf/length>= (<-U)

  1. *retlength = 0;

  2. if(length <= 0)

  3.   return STATUS_OK;

  4. <Get more decoded data>

  5. if(length > cgi_state->dec_out_len)

  6.   length = cgi_state->dec_out_len;

  7. *retlength = length;

  8. memcpy(buf, cgi_state->dec_out, length);

  9. cgi_state->dec_out_len -= length;

  10. cgi_state->dec_out += length;

  11. return STATUS_OK;

For getting a line, the decode buffer needs to be scanned for newlines.

<Decode a string into buf/length>= (<-U)

  1. if(length <= 0)

  2.   return STATUS_OK;

  3. *buf = 0;

  4. if(!--length)

  5.   return STATUS_OK;

  6. while(1) {

  7.   int cp_len = length;

  8.   <Get more decoded data>

  9.   if(cp_len > cgi_state->dec_out_len)

  10.     cp_len = cgi_state->dec_out_len;

  11.   length -= cp_len;

  12.   cgi_state->dec_out_len -= cp_len;

  13.   while(cp_len--)

  14.     if((*buf++ = *cgi_state->dec_out++) == '\n')

  15.       break;

  16.   *buf = 0;

  17.   cgi_state->dec_out_len += cp_len + 1;

  18.   if(cp_len >= 0 || buf[-1] == '\n')

  19.     return STATUS_OK;

  20. }

POST and PUT Uploads

In order to handle POST parameters correctly, a parsing handler could be provided to the CGI kit. There are two problems with the CGI kit's handler mechanism, though. First, the handler can be selected by content type, but only by exact matches, so POST uploads which tack on an arbitrary boundary cannot be easily intercepted. Second, the handler is run in addition to the built-in handler, rather than instead of the built-in handler.

The first problem could be worked around by handling all content types and filtering in the function, or by only adding the handler if the content type is multi-part, using the exact content type string that was passed. The second problem could be worked around by returning a dummy error, which will abort the built-in parser.

Instead of these workarounds, the cgi_parse function is avoided entirely for multi-part POST parameters. Also, in order to be more forgiving to browsers, any unrecognized content type for POST parameters is converted to application/x-www-form-urlencoded to force reading the query string from standard input15 . In fact, since the cgi_parse function doesn't do anything but upload and POST parameter parsing, it is bypassed for anything but simple POST parsing. Since the request method and content type are used to decide what to do, the content type is placed directly in the CGI state for quick access.

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *body_type;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *cgi_parse_multpart(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, const char *ctype)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  4.   <Parse multi-part CGI parameters>

  5.   return nerr;

  6. }

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cgi_state->body_type = cgi_env_val("CGI.ContentType", "");

  2. if(req_method == HTTP_REQ_POST) {

  3.   if(!strncasecmp(cgi_state->body_type, "multipart/form-data", 19)) {

  4.     if(!nerr_op_ok(cgi_parse_multpart(cgi_state, cgi_state->body_type)))

  5.       return nerr;

  6.   } else if(strcmp(cgi_state->body_type, "application/soap+xml")) {

  7.     if(strcmp(cgi_state->body_type, "application/x-www-form-urlencoded"))

  8.       hdf_set_value(cgi_state->cgi->hdf, "CGI.ContentType",

  9.                     "application/x-www-form-urlencoded");

  10.     if(!nerr_op_ok(cgi_parse(cgi_state->cgi)))

  11.       return nerr;

  12.   }

  13. }

  14. cgi_state->hdf = cgi_state->cgi->hdf; /* in case it changed */

Parsing multi-part POST parameters per RFC 238816 is straightforward:

<Parse multi-part CGI parameters>= (<-U)

  1. <Multi-part Parse Variables>

  2. <Find multi-part boundary>

  3. <Create buffer at least large enough for multi-part boundary>

  4. while(1) {

  5.   <Find next multi-part boundary and break if last>

  6.   <Parse multi-part headers until blank line>

  7.   if(!(<Found multi-part file>)) {

  8.     <Parse multi-part body as parameter>

  9.   }

  10.   <Set multi-part parameters>

  11.   if(<Found multi-part file>) {

  12.     <Parse multi-part body as file>

  13.   }

  14. }

  15. <Clean up multi-part parse>

There are two ways to read lines: read everything in a line, like g_string_fgets, or read just enough to fill a buffer, like fgets. Both have disadvantages. Reading everything has the potential to use too much memory. Reading just the amount there is room for has problems with long lines. The HTTP and MIME specifications try to keep line lengths reasonable, but there is never any guarantee. For this reason, only file reads will use a limited-length buffer. The rest will use the CGI equivalent of g_string_fgets, but with ASCII NUL support:

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static char *cgi_gets_cb(char *buf, int len, void *str)

  2. {

  3.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = str;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr = cgi_gets(buf, len);

  5.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  6.     return buf;

  7.   nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  8.   return NULL;

  9. }

  10. char *g_string_cgi_gets(GString **_buf, guint offset, cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  11. {

  12.   return g_string_gets_generic(_buf, offset, cgi_gets_cb, cgi_state, TRUE);

  13. }

Most of the time, the boundary is passed in with the content type. However, the perl CGI module allows for the boundary to be missing, and instead uses the first line read from input as the boundary. This code will do the same. However, since the first line may be part of a file, the buffer will be limited to 128 characters. 78 is the most a boundary should contain, anyway.

<Find multi-part boundary>= (<-U)

  1. char boundary_buf[128];

  2. const char *boundary = strstr(cgi_state->body_type + 19, "boundary=");

  3. if(boundary)

  4.   boundary += 9;

  5. else {

  6.   if(!cgi_gets(boundary_buf, sizeof(boundary_buf)))

  7.     return STATUS_OK;

  8.   /* in use, each boundary is preceeded by -- */

  9.   if(!memcmp(boundary_buf, "--", 2))

  10.     boundary = boundary_buf + 2;

  11.   else

  12.     return nerr_raise(NERR_PARSE, "Malformed input; no boundary");

  13. }

  14. int blen = strlen(boundary);

As is usual with this code, a GString is used to buffer the input. To make I/O more efficient, the buffer is at least 8192 bytes long.

<Create buffer at least large enough for multi-part boundary>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. GString *buf = g_string_sized_new(blen > 8192 - 7 ? blen + 7 : 8192);

  2.                                   /* 7 extra for --<b>--\r\n\0 */

<Clean up multi-part parse>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

The first thing to do in the loop is to read the next line. However, if the boundary line needed to be read, one line has already been read. Also, searching for the end of the body will usually result with the next boundary line having been read. For this reason, a line is always read before entring the loop.

<Create buffer at least large enough for multi-part boundary>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(boundary == boundary_buf + 2)

  2.   g_string_assign(buf, boundary_buf);

  3. else

  4.   if(!cgi_gets(buf->str, buf->allocated_len)) {

  5.     g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  6.     return STATUS_OK;

  7.   }

The loop should be entered with the boundary, prefixed by a double dash, in the read buffer. However, there may be some sort of corruption in the headers. In that case, the next line is read using a limited buffer read and the loop is started over. If the boundary is valid, then the final boundary is indicated by an additional trailing double dash.

<Find next multi-part boundary and break if last>= (<-U)

  1. if(memcmp(buf->str, "--", 2) ||

  2.    memcmp(buf->str + 2, boundary, blen)) {

  3.   if(!cgi_gets(buf->str, buf->allocated_len))

  4.     break; /* end of input */

  5.   continue; /* invalid boundary; find next */

  6. }

  7. if(!strncmp(buf->str + 2 + blen, "--", 2) &&

  8.    (buf->str[2 + blen + 2] == '\r' ||

  9.     buf->str[2 + blen + 2] == '\n' ||

  10.     !buf->str[2 + blen + 2]))

  11.   break; /* valid end boundary */

  12. if(buf->str[2 + blen] != '\r' &&

  13.    buf->str[2 + blen] != '\n') {

  14.   /* invalid boundary */

  15.   if(!cgi_gets(buf->str, buf->allocated_len))

  16.     break; /* end of input */

  17.   continue; /* invalid boundary; find next */

  18. }

The header consists of keywords, followed by a colon, followed by values. The values may be semicolon-separated keyword-value pairs. The only headers of interest are content-dispostion, which has keyword-value pairs as its value that include name and filename, content-transfer-encoding, and content-length. The content-type is returned by the CGI kit, so it needs to be saved as well. This will allow post-processors to deal with multipart files; otherwise such files would have to be rejected.

<Multi-part Parse Variables>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. gint64 flen = -1;

  2. char *content_type = NULL;

<Parse multi-part headers until blank line>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. while(1) {

  2.   g_string_cgi_gets(&buf, 0, cgi_state);

  3.   if(!buf->str[0] || buf->str[0] == '\r' || buf->str[0] == '\n')

  4.     break; /* blank line @ end of header */

  5.   char *c = strchr(buf->str, ':');

  6.   if(!c) /* invalid line; just ignore */

  7.     continue;

  8.   *c = 0;

  9.   if(!strcasecmp(buf->str, "content-disposition")) {

  10.     <Parse content-disposition>

  11.   } else if(!strcasecmp(buf->str, "content-transfer-encoding")) {

  12.     <Parse content-transfer-encoding>

  13.   } else if(!strcasecmp(buf->str, "content-length")) {

  14.     while(isspace(*++c));

  15.     if(isdigit(*c))

  16.       flen = strtoull(c, NULL, 10);

  17.   } else if(!strcasecmp(buf->str, "content-type")) {

  18.     while(isspace(*++c));

  19.     if(!content_type)

  20.       content_type = strdup(c);

  21.   }

  22.   /* ignore other header lines */

  23. }

<Clean up multi-part parse>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(content_type)

  2.   free(content_type);

The content-transfer-encoding field indicates encodings other than `7bit', which indicates plain text, sans the final newline. Any unknown encoding will be ignored. Note that this is another improvement over ClearSilver: ClearSilver only supports the plain encoding types.

<Multi-part Parse Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. enum { CT_ENC_PLAIN, CT_ENC_Q, CT_ENC_B, CT_ENC_INV } enct = CT_ENC_PLAIN;

<Parse content-transfer-encoding>= (<-U)

  1. while(isspace(*++c));

  2. char *t = c;

  3. while(*t && !isspace(*t))

  4.   t++;

  5. *t = 0;

  6. if(!strcasecmp(c, "7bit") || !strcasecmp(c, "8bit") || !strcasecmp(c, "binary"))

  7.   enct = CT_ENC_PLAIN;

  8. else if(!strcasecmp(c, "quoted-printable"))

  9.   enct = CT_ENC_Q;

  10. else if(!strcasecmp(c, "base64"))

  11.   enct = CT_ENC_B;

  12. else if(*c)

  13.   enct = CT_ENC_INV;

<Parse multi-part headers until blank line>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(enct == CT_ENC_INV)

  2.   continue; /* scan for next header; enctype not supported */

Parsing the multi-valued content-disposition field17 is the hardest. First it must locate semicolon-separated fields, ignoring whitespace. The first field is ignored entirely, because it is the content disposition itself. Spurious semicolons are just ignored. The field name is always literal text, so it is fairly easy to parse out. The specfic field name is checked after the full pair has been parsed. After the field name comes an equals sign, surrounded by optional whitespace. Then comes the value, which can be either a token or a quoted string. Quotes embedded in values are not always properly escaped, so an ending quote is only accepted if followed immediately by a semicolon or end of line. Since the values need to be saved, the entire header line is saved as well.

<Multi-part Parse Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. GString *content_disposition = NULL;

  2. const char *pname = NULL, *fname = NULL;

  3. const char *mdate = NULL, *cdate = NULL, *rdate = NULL;

<Clean up multi-part parse>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(content_disposition)

  2.   g_string_free(content_disposition, TRUE);

<Parse content-disposition>= (<-U)

  1. char *s, *n, *ne, *v;

  2. gboolean restore_semi = FALSE;

  3. if(!content_disposition)

  4.   content_disposition = g_string_new(buf->str);

  5. else

  6.   continue; /* multiple disposition lines not supported */

  7. for(s = strchr(content_disposition->str + 20, ';'); s && *s; ) {

  8.   while(*s == ';' || isspace(*s))

  9.     s++;

  10.   if(!*s)

  11.     break;

  12.   n = s;

  13.   /* RFC 2183 would have me filter more chars, but this is good enough */

  14.   while(isgraph(*s) && *s != ';' && *s != '=')

  15.     s++;

  16.   ne = s;

  17.   while(isspace(*s))

  18.     s++;

  19.   if(!*s)

  20.     break;

  21.   if(*s != '=')

  22.     continue;

  23.   *ne = 0;

  24.   while(isspace(*++s));

  25.   v = s;

  26.   if(*v != '"') {

  27.     while(isgraph(*++s));

  28.     ne = s;

  29.     if(*s && !isspace(*s) && *s != ';')

  30.       /* invalid token; ignore */

  31.       continue;

  32.     while(isspace(*s))

  33.       s++;

  34.     if(*s && *s != ';')

  35.       /* invalid token again; ignore */

  36.       continue;

  37.     restore_semi = *ne == ';';

  38.     *ne = 0;

  39.   } else {

  40.     ne = ++v;

  41.     for(s = v; *s; s++) {

  42.       if(*s == '\\' && s[1] && s[1] != '\r' && s[1] != '\n')

  43.         *ne = *++s;

  44.       else if(*s == '"') {

  45.         char *ss;

  46.         for(ss = s + 1; isspace(*ss); ss++);

  47.         if(!*ss || *ss == ';')

  48.           break;

  49.         *ne = *s;

  50.       } else

  51.         *ne = *s;

  52.     }

  53.     *ne = 0;

  54.   }

  55.   if(!strcasecmp(n, "name"))

  56.     pname = v;

  57.   else if(!strcasecmp(n, "filename"))

  58.     fname = v;

  59.   else if(!strcasecmp(n, "creation-date"))

  60.     cdate = v;

  61.   else if(!strcasecmp(n, "modification-date"))

  62.     mdate = v;

  63.   else if(!strcasecmp(n, "read-date"))

  64.     rdate = v;

  65.   else if(!strcasecmp(n, "size"))

  66.     if(isdigit(*v))

  67.       flen = strtoull(v, NULL, 10);

  68.   /* else ignore */

  69.   if(restore_semi) {

  70.     *ne = ';';

  71.     restore_semi = FALSE;

  72.   }

  73. }

<Found multi-part file>= (<-U)

  1. fname

Finally, the body is parsed. This must take content encoding into consideration, but otherwise includes all text up to the last end-of-line followed by a boundary line. For CGI values, the value is assumed to be small enough to fit in memory, so it is sucked into a buffer and assigned to the parameter.

<Multi-part Parse Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. GString *val = NULL;

<Clean up multi-part parse>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(val)

  2.   g_string_free(val, TRUE);

<Parse multi-part body as parameter>= (<-U)

  1. int off = 0;

  2. while(g_string_cgi_gets(&val, off, cgi_state)) {

  3.   if(val->str[off] == '-' && val->str[off + 1] == '-' &&

  4.      !strncmp(val->str + off + 2, boundary, blen))

  5.     break;

  6.     off += val->len;

  7. }

  8. if(val->len > off)

  9.   g_string_assign(buf, val->str + off);

  10. else

  11.   g_string_assign(buf, "");

  12. if(off > 0 && val->str[off - 1] == '\n')

  13.   off--;

  14. if(off > 0 && val->str[off - 1] == '\r')

  15.   off--;

  16. val->len = off;

  17. val->str[off] = 0;

  18. if(enct == CT_ENC_Q) {

  19.   val->len = decode_quoted_printable(val->str);

  20.   val->str[val->len] = 0;

  21. } else if(enct == CT_ENC_B) {

  22.   gint b64_state = 0;

  23.   guint b64_save = 0;

  24.   val->len = g_base64_decode_step(val->str, val->len, (guchar *)val->str,

  25.                                   &b64_state, &b64_save);

  26.   val->str[val->len] = 0;

  27. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. int decode_quoted_printable(char *buf)

  2. {

  3.   char *s, *d, *l;

  4.   for(d = s = buf; *s; s++) {

  5.     /* note: RFC says upper-case only, but allow lower-case since */

  6.     /* otherwise lower-case just makes it invalid */

  7.     if(*s == '=' && isxdigit(s[1]) && isxdigit(s[2])) {

  8.       *d++ = *++s & 0xf;

  9.       if(*s > '9')

  10.         *d += 10 - ('a' & 0xf);

  11.       *d <<= 4;

  12.       *d += *++s & 0xf;

  13.       if(*s > '9')

  14.         *d += 10 - ('a' & 0xf);

  15.       d++;

  16.     } else if(*s == '=' && (!s[1] || isspace(s[1]))) {

  17.       for(l = s + 1; isspace(*l) && *l != '\r' && *l != '\n'; l++);

  18.       if(!*l || *l == '\r' || *l == '\n') {

  19.         s = l;

  20.         if(s[1] == '\r' || s[1] == '\n')

  21.           s++;

  22.       } else {

  23.         /* otherwise invalid, but go ahead and retain = */

  24.         *d++ = *s;

  25.       }

  26.     } else if(*s == '\r' || *s == '\n') {

  27.       *d++ = *s;

  28.       if(s[1] == '\n' || s[1] == '\r') {

  29.         *d++ = *++s;

  30.     } else if(!isspace(*s))

  31.       /* invalid if =, but go ahead and retain */
