  32.       *d++ = *s;

  33.     } else {

  34.       /* for every space, see if it's at end of line, in which case remove */

  35.       for(l = s + 1; isspace(*l) && *l != '\r' && *l != '\n'; l++);

  36.       if(*l == '\r' || *l == '\n')

  37.         s = l;

  38.       else {

  39.         memmove(d, s, (int)(l - s));

  40.         d += (int)(l - s);

  41.         s += (int)(l - s) - 1;

  42.       }

  43.     }

  44.   }

  45.   return (int)(d - buf);

  46. }

The algorithm for setting the correct HDF values was lifted from the ClearSilver source with minor modification. The file-related attributes are added as a hierarchy under the parameter. The value of the file parameter itself is also the file name. Since the primary value is a string, NUL characters in the value and all subsequent characters are lost. If lost NUL characters are detected, the raw buffer is duplicated and assigned to the value, and a `Length' subparameter is set to the parameter length. It is up to the user to check for the presence of this subparameter if binary values are expected. In most cases, though, the user will likely silently ignore that as an error.

<Multi-part Parse Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. int unnamed_parms = 0;

  2. char nbuf[20];

<Set multi-part parameters>= (<-U)

  1. if(!pname) {

  2.   snprintf(nbuf, sizeof(nbuf), "_%d", unnamed_parms++);

  3.   pname = nbuf;

  4. }

  5. HDF *obj = cgi_parm_obj(pname);

  6. if(obj) {

  7.   /* multiple values get assigned to .0, ,1, ... */

  8.   /* but first one remains on named node, and is copied to .0 */

  9.   int i = 0;

  10.   HDF *child;

  11.   /* don't count FileName & other non-numeric parms */

  12.   for(child = hdf_obj_child(obj); child; child = hdf_obj_next(child))

  13.     if(isdigit(hdf_obj_name(child)[0]))

  14.       i++;

  15.   if(!i) {

  16.     nerr_op(hdf_set_value(obj, "0", hdf_obj_value(obj)));

  17.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  18.       return nerr;

  19.     /* note that doing an hdf_copy() would cause an infinite recursion */

  20.     /* same for soft link */

  21.     HDF *zero = hdf_get_obj(obj, "0");

  22.     for(child = hdf_obj_child(obj); child; child = hdf_obj_next(child))

  23.       if(!isdigit(hdf_obj_name(child)[0]))

  24.         if(!nerr_op_ok(hdf_set_value(zero, hdf_obj_name(child),

  25.                                      hdf_obj_value(child))))

  26.           return nerr;

  27.     i = 1;

  28.   }

  29.   sprintf(nbuf, "%d", i);

  30.   pname = nbuf;

  31. } else

  32.   /* single value gets assigned to named node */

  33.   obj = cgi_state->cgi_parms;

  34. /* pname is now parm to set, and obj is parent HDF */

  35. if(fname)

  36.   nerr_op(hdf_set_value(obj, pname, fname));

  37. else if(strlen(val->str) == val->len)

  38.   nerr_op(hdf_set_value(obj, pname, val->str));

  39. else {

  40.   char *vbuf = malloc(val->len + 1);

  41.   if(!vbuf)

  42.     nerr = nerr_raise_errno(NERR_NOMEM, "parameter too long");

  43.   else {

  44.     memcpy(vbuf, val->str, val->len);

  45.     if(nerr_op_ok(hdf_set_buf(obj, pname, vbuf))) {

  46.       obj = hdf_get_obj(obj, pname);

  47.       /* obj is ready for setting children of newly added parm */

  48.       nerr_op(hdf_set_int_value(obj, "Length", val->len));

  49.     }

  50.   }

  51. }

  52. if(nerr == STATUS_OK && fname) {

  53.   obj = hdf_get_obj(obj, pname);

  54.   /* obj is ready for setting children of newly added parm */

  55.   if(mdate)

  56.     nerr_op((hdf_set_int64_value(obj, "ModTime", parse_http_date(mdate,

  57.                                                                  FALSE))));

  58.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && cdate)

  59.     nerr_op(hdf_set_int64_value(obj, "CreationTime", parse_http_date(cdate,

  60.                                                                      FALSE)));

  61.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && rdate)

  62.     nerr_op(hdf_set_int64_value(obj, "AccessTime", parse_http_date(rdate,

  63.                                                                    FALSE)));

  64.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && content_type)

  65.     nerr_op(hdf_set_value(obj, "Type", content_type));

  66.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && flen >= 0)

  67.     hdf_set_int64_value(obj, "Length", flen);

  68. }

  69. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  70.   return nerr;

The date fields are converted to a standard UNIX GMT timestamp as per RFC 822 or RFC 2616, which references RFC 1123/822 and RFC 850. HTTP dates are a bit stricter than the MIME dates, so a flag chooses which. The timezone format requires glibc or similar extensions. This function proceeds similarly to the more generic parse_date function, but limits the acceptable formats more.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static const char const * http_date_fmts[] = {

  2.   /* RFC 1123, RFC 2616 rfc1123-date */

  3.   "%a, %d %b %Y %T %z",

  4.   /* RFC 1123 */

  5.   "%d %b %Y %T %z",

  6.   "%a, %d %b %Y %R %z",

  7.   "%d %b %Y %R %z",

  8.   /* RFC 822 */

  9.   "%a, %d %b %y %T %z",

  10.   "%d %b %y %T %z",

  11.   "%a, %d %b %y %R %z",

  12.   "%d %b %y %R %z",

  13.   /* RFC 2616 rfc850-date */

  14.   "%a, %d-%b-%y %T %z",

  15.   /* RFC 2616 asctime-date */

  16.   "TZ=GMT",

  17.   "%a %b %d %T",

  18.   NULL

  19. };

  20. time_t parse_http_date(const char *date, gboolean http_only)

  21. {

  22.   const char *e, *fmt, **fmtp;

  23.   struct tm tm_parsed;

  24.   time_t t;

  25.   const char *old_tz = NULL; /* init to shut gcc up */

  26.   gboolean set_tz = FALSE;

  27.   if(!date || !*date)

  28.     return -1;

  29.   for(fmtp = http_date_fmts, e = NULL; (!e || *e) && (fmt = *fmtp); fmtp++) {

  30.     if(!strncmp(fmt, "TZ=", 3)) {

  31.       if(!set_tz) {

  32.         pthread_mutex_lock(&tz_lock);

  33.         old_tz = getenv("TZ");

  34.         set_tz = TRUE;

  35.       }

  36.       setenv("TZ", fmt + 3, 1);

  37.       tzset();

  38.     } else {

  39.       memset(&tm_parsed, 0, sizeof(tm_parsed));

  40.       e = strptime(date, fmt, &tm_parsed);

  41.       /* HTTP requires GMT time zone */

  42.       /* guaranteed more than 3 chars; time alone is 5 chars */

  43.       if(http_only && e && !*e && strstr(fmt, "%z") &&

  44.          strcmp(e - 4, " GMT"))

  45.         e = NULL;

  46.     }

  47.   }

  48.   if(e && !*e)

  49.     t = mktime(&tm_parsed);

  50.   else

  51.     t = -1;

  52.   if(set_tz) {

  53.     if(old_tz)

  54.       setenv("TZ", old_tz, 1);

  55.     else

  56.       unsetenv("TZ");

  57.     tzset();

  58.     pthread_mutex_unlock(&tz_lock);

  59.   }

  60.   return t;

  61. }

As a last step for files, the contents are read into either a temporary file in the same way that the CGI kit does it, or, if provided, callbacks are called. The callbacks are defined in the CGI state structure rather than passed as arguments. They are placed in a substructure, though, to make storage of existing callbacks easier when chaining multiple callbacks together.

<CGI State Dependencies>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. typedef NEOERR *(*cgi_open_cb)(HDF *obj, cgi_state_t *cgi_state);

  2. typedef NEOERR *(*cgi_write_cb)(HDF *obj, cgi_state_t *cgi_state,

  3.                                       guint64 off, const void *buf, int len);

  4. typedef NEOERR *(*cgi_progress_cb)(HDF *obj, cgi_state_t *cgi_state,

  5.                                          guint64 off, int len);

  6. typedef NEOERR *(*cgi_close_cb)(HDF *obj, cgi_state_t *cgi_state,

  7.                                       NEOERR *write_errors);

  8. typedef struct {

  9.   cgi_open_cb open;

  10.   cgi_write_cb write;

  11.   cgi_progress_cb progress;

  12.   cgi_close_cb close;

  13.   void *data;

  14. } cgi_upload_cb;

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. cgi_open_cb,cgi_write_cb,cgi_progress_cb,cgi_close_cb,cgi_upload_cb,%

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cgi_upload_cb upload_cb;

<Parse multi-part body as file>= (<-U)

  1. <Open multi-part body file>

  2. if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  3.   guint64 off = 0;

  4.   gboolean eof = FALSE;

  5.   <Prepare to read multi-part body file lines>

  6.   while(nerr == STATUS_OK && <Read a multi-part body line>) {

  7.     <Break multi-part file read and set eof if boundary found>

  8.     <Decode multi-part file line>

  9.     <Write multi-part body line to file>

  10.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  11.       break;

  12.     <Prepare for next multi-part body file line>

  13.   }

  14.   if(!eof)

  15.     while(<Read a multi-part body line>) {

  16.       <Break multi-part file read and set eof if boundary found>

  17.       <Prepare for next multi-part body file line>

  18.     }

  19.   <Close multi-part body file>

  20. }

Opening the file the CGI kit way is made a little easier via the `internal use only' open_upload function. This will likely disappear in a future revision of ClearSilver, but it works for now. Just as the original code which calls this function does, the unlinking parameter (which should probably always be on anyway) must be read manually and passed into the function, and the `file descriptor' must be read as the number of files opened so far. Errors writing the file should result in an unlink anyway, so the path name is saved for later if unlinking is disabled.

<Open multi-part body file>= (<-U U->) [D->]

  1. FILE *f = NULL;

  2. char *path = NULL;

  3. if(cgi_state->upload_cb.open)

  4.   nerr_op((*cgi_state->upload_cb.open)(obj, cgi_state));

  5. else {

  6.   int unlink_it = hdf_get_int_value(cgi_state->cgi->hdf,

  7.                                     "Config.Upload.Unlink", 1);

  8.   nerr = nerr_pass_ctx(open_upload(cgi_state->cgi, unlink_it, &f),

  9.                        "Can't open file for %s upload",

  10.                         hdf_obj_name(obj));

  11.   int entryno = uListLength(cgi_state->cgi->files);

  12.   hdf_set_int_value(obj, "FileHandle", entryno);

  13.   /* rfc2388.c checks errors on uListGet, but there should never be any */

  14.   uListGet(cgi_state->cgi->files, entryno - 1, (void *)&f);

  15.   if(!unlink_it) {

  16.     uListGet(cgi_state->cgi->filenames, entryno - 1, (void *)&path);

  17.     nerr_op(hdf_set_value(obj, "FileName", path));

  18.   }

  19. }

Reading lines requires stripping off the trailing carriage return and line feed for the last line. Since the last line is only known to be the last line after the boundary is read (i.e., this code does not use content-length), the trailing characters (either a newline alone or a carriage returned followed by a newline, even though the RFC only supports the latter) are always stripped off, and then re-added to the beginning of the next line's buffer. Since the buffer length is limited, lines may span multiple buffers. The boundary line is only sensed at the start of a new line, so a flag is used to indicate that the last read was a full line. It would be nice to use the indication of chracters to prepend as a flag that the buffer starts a new line (and may therefore be a boundary), but that would skip the first line.

Just like the infinite line reader, this must find the end of the read by means other than the return value. For this reason, the buffer is always pre-filled, and the last terminator is found to determine length.

<Prepare to read multi-part body file lines>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. gboolean was_line = TRUE;

  2. int eol_len = 0;

  3. memset(buf->str, 255, buf->allocated_len);

<Read a multi-part body line>= (<-U)

  1. cgi_gets(buf->str + eol_len, buf->allocated_len - eol_len)

<Break multi-part file read and set eof if boundary found>= (<-U)

  1. /* no need to detect binary data in boundary */

  2. if(was_line && buf->str[eol_len] == '-' && buf->str[eol_len + 1] == '-' &&

  3.   !strncmp(buf->str + 2, boundary, blen))

  4.   break;

  5. char *ep;

  6. for(ep = buf->str + buf->allocated_len - 1; *ep; --ep); /* memrchr is GNU */

  7. buf->len = (int)(ep - buf->str);

  8. if(buf->len == eol_len)

  9.   break; /* ignore EOL chars at EOF as well */

  10. was_line = buf->str[buf->len - 1] == '\n';

  11. if(was_line) {

  12.   if(buf->len > 1 && buf->str[buf->len - 1] == '\r')

  13.     eol_len = 2;

  14.   else

  15.     eol_len = 1;

  16.   buf->len -= eol_len;

  17.   if(!buf->len)

  18.     continue; /* 1st 1-2 chars are already [\r]\n */

  19. }

<Prepare for next multi-part body file line>= (<-U)

  1. if(eol_len) {

  2.   buf->str[0] = '\r';

  3.   buf->str[eol_len - 1] = '\n';

  4.   buf->str[eol_len] = 0;

  5.   buf->len = eol_len;

  6. }

The CGI kit only supports plain data; there is no decoding required for that. This library also supports the standard text encoding methods. These are slightly more complicated than the decoding done for parameter values, because only one line at a time is available for decoding.

<Decode multi-part file line>= (<-U)

  1. if(enct == CT_ENC_Q) {

  2.   /* RFC states that no line shall exceed 79 chars, so assume EOL present */

  3.   /* handle line continuation here */

  4.   while(buf->len > 0 && isspace(buf->str[buf->len - 1]))

  5.     buf->len--;

  6.   if(buf->len > 0 && buf->str[buf->len - 1] == '=') {

  7.     eol_len = 0;

  8.     buf->len--;

  9.   }

  10.   buf->str[buf->len] = 0;

  11.   int init_eol = 0;

  12.   if(buf->str[0] == '\r')

  13.     init_eol = 1;

  14.   if(buf->str[init_eol] == '\n')

  15.     init_eol++;

  16.   buf->len = decode_quoted_printable(buf->str + init_eol) + init_eol;

  17.   buf->str[buf->len] = 0;

  18. } else if(enct == CT_ENC_B) {

  19.   buf->len = g_base64_decode_step(buf->str, buf->len, (guchar *)buf->str,

  20.                                   &b64_state, &b64_save);

  21.   buf->str[buf->len] = 0;

  22. }

<Prepare to read multi-part body file lines>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. gint b64_state = 0;

  2. guint b64_save = 0;

Writing the result is straightforward. Unfortunately, there is no way to control how much data has been read; accumulating a large amount into a buffer would make the writes more efficient. A progress callback is also called to replace the standard kit's upload callback; like that callback, it is called before the associated write. If a user callback was provided for opening the file, a user call back must be provided for the write, as well, since no assumption can be made that the callback data is a file descriptor.

<Write multi-part body line to file>= (<-U U->)

  1. if(cgi_state->upload_cb.progress) {

  2.   if(!nerr_op_ok((*cgi_state->upload_cb.progress)(obj, cgi_state, off,

  3.                                                   buf->len)))

  4.     break;

  5. }

  6. if(cgi_state->upload_cb.write)

  7.   nerr_op((*cgi_state->upload_cb.write)(obj, cgi_state, off, buf->str,

  8.                                         buf->len));

  9. else if(f)

  10.   if(fwrite(buf->str, buf->len, 1, f) != 1)

  11.     nerr = nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "Failed write for %s upload",

  12.                                      hdf_obj_name(obj));

Finally, the standard kit does not actually close the file. Instead, it seeks to the beginning and saves the pseudo file descriptor. This code also flushes the data to ensure it has been written. Any write errors cause the resulting file to be removed. This all is done in addition to the close callback, since it is not likely that the close callback will not also override the open callback.

<Close multi-part body file>= (<-U U->) [D->]

  1. if(f && nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  2.   if(fflush(f))

  3.     nerr = nerr_raise_errno(NERR_IO, "Failed write for %s upload",

  4.                                      hdf_obj_name(obj));

  5.   else

  6.     fseek(f, 0, SEEK_SET);

  7. }

  8. if(f && nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  9.   fclose(f);

  10.   f = NULL;

  11.   if(path)

  12.     unlink(path);

  13. }

  14. if(cgi_state->upload_cb.close)

  15.   nerr = (*cgi_state->upload_cb.close)(obj, cgi_state, nerr);

In case the standard open routine is used, but callbacks want to access the file, the file descriptor is assigned to the callback data if it was NULL. On close, the callback data is set back to NULL if it matches the file descriptor (very unlikely if it is not actually the file descriptor).

<Open multi-part body file>+= (<-U U->) [<-D]

  1. if(!cgi_state->upload_cb.data)

  2.     cgi_state->upload_cb.data = f;

<Close multi-part body file>+= (<-U U->) [<-D]

  1. if((void *)f == cgi_state->upload_cb.data)

  2.   cgi_state->upload_cb.data = NULL;

The POST method is not the only method with a body. The PUT method is normally handled by cgi_parse, but the above code disables that processing. The built-in PUT processing, like the POST processing, has a few deficiencies. There is no callback at all, and the uploaded file is placed in a common temporary directory. It also does not support any content encoding. For this implementation, the upload parameters are saved to the PUT variable as with the standard library, and the upload callbacks are used with this parameter. Since the callback has access to the method, that can be used to distinguish the cases.

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(req_method == HTTP_REQ_PUT) {

  2.   guint64 off = 0;

  3.   HDF *obj;

  4.   struct {

  5.     char *str;

  6.     int len;

  7.   } _buf, *buf = &_buf;

  8.   const char *pi = cgi_env_val("CGI.PathInfo", "");

  9.   nerr_op(cgi_env_set("PUT", pi));

  10.   if(*cgi_state->body_type)

  11.     nerr_op(cgi_env_set("PUT.Type", cgi_state->body_type));

  12.   /* this is done by cgi_decode_read as well, but that's too late for */

  13.   /* open callback */

  14.   if(cgi_state->body_enc && cgi_state->body_len >= 0)

  15.     nerr_op(cgi_env_set_int("CGI.ContentLength", (cgi_state->body_len = -1)));

  16.   nerr_op(cgi_env_set_int("PUT.Length", cgi_state->body_len));

  17.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  18.     return nerr;

  19.   obj = cgi_env_obj("PUT");

  20.   if(!(_buf.str = malloc(DEC_BUF_LEN)))

  21.     return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Error reading upload stream");

  22.   <Open multi-part body file>

  23.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  24.     free(_buf.str);

  25.     return nerr;

  26.   }

  27.   while(nerr_op_ok(cgi_read(_buf.str, DEC_BUF_LEN, &_buf.len)) && _buf.len > 0) {

  28.     <Write multi-part body line to file>

  29.   }

  30.   <Close multi-part body file>

  31. }

Common Headers

Some headers are handled differently depening on the request method. However, for headers that are sufficiently well defined by RFCs, some syntax checking and parsing can be done for any CGI program that needs it.

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. HDF *hobj; /* the header value under consideration */

  2. <Process common HTTP headers>

  3. if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  4.   cgi_env_set("error_status", "401 Bad Request");

  5.   return nerr;

  6. }

First are the ones defined by RFC 2616. Many of these require processing tokens and quoted strings.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. char *skip_http_token(const char *s)

  2. {

  3.   while(*s > 32 && !strchr("()<>@,;:\\\"/[]?={}\177", *s))

  4.     s++;

  5.   return (char *)s;

  6. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. char *skip_http_quoted_string(const char *s)

  2. {

  3.   if(*s != '"')

  4.     return NULL;

  5.   while(*++s != '"' && *s)

  6.     if(*s == '\\' && s[1])

  7.       s++;

  8.   if(*s != '"')

  9.     return NULL;

  10.   return (char *)s + 1;

  11. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. char *mangle_and_skip_http_quoted_string(char *s, char **ms)

  2. {

  3.   char *d;

  4.   if(*s != '"')

  5.     return NULL;

  6.   d = s + 1;

  7.   if(ms)

  8.     *ms = d;

  9.   while(*++s != '"' && *s) {

  10.     if(*s == '\\' && s[1])

  11.       s++;

  12.     *d++ = *s;

  13.   }

  14.   if(*s != '"')

  15.     return NULL;

  16.   *d = 0;

  17.   return s + 1;

  18. }

The Accept header takes a list of media types, with optional keyword-value pairs describing each type. The q keyword has a particular format and interpretation. Errors cause the header to be ignored rather than giving a 401 or 406 error. Each supplied content-type is added as a child to the header, and the keyword-value pairs are stored as attributes for those children. No attempt is made to sort by precedence.

<Process common HTTP headers>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Accept"))) {

  2.   char nbuf[22];

  3.   int cno = 0;

  4.   char *hv = hdf_obj_value(hobj), *ev, *vp, *vs, ec;

  5.   HDF *cobj;

  6.   while(hv) {

  7.     vs = hv;

  8.     if(*hv == '*')

  9.       ev = hv + 1;

  10.     else

  11.       ev = skip_http_token(hv);

  12.     if(ev != hv) {

  13.       vp = ev;

  14.       while(isspace(*ev))

  15.         ev++;

  16.       if(*ev == '/') {

  17.         *vp++ = '/';

  18.         while(isspace(*++ev));

  19.         if(*ev == '*')

  20.           hv = ev + 1;

  21.         else if(*vs != '*')

  22.           hv = skip_http_token(ev);

  23.         else

  24.           hv = ev;

  25.         if(hv != ev) {

  26.           if(ev != vp)

  27.             memmove(ev, vp, (int)(hv - ev));

  28.           vp += (int)(hv - ev);

  29.           ec = *vp;

  30.           sprintf(nbuf, "%d", cno++);

  31.           die_if_err(hdf_get_node(hobj, nbuf, &cobj));

  32.           *vp = 0;

  33.           hdf_set_value(cobj, NULL, vs);

  34.           *vp = ec;

  35.           while(hv) {

  36.             char *as, *ae, *avs, *ave;

  37.             while(isspace(*hv))

  38.               hv++;

  39.             if(*hv != ';')

  40.               break;

  41.             as = hv;

  42.             ae = hv = skip_http_token(hv);

  43.             if(ae != as) {

  44.               while(isspace(*hv))

  45.                 hv++;

  46.               if(*hv == '=') {

  47.                 while(isspace(*++hv));

  48.                 avs = hv;

  49.                 if(*hv == '"')

  50.                   ave = mangle_and_skip_http_quoted_string(hv, &avs);

  51.                 else {

  52.                   ave = skip_http_token(avs);

  53.                   if(ave == avs)

  54.                     ave = NULL;

  55.                 }

  56.               } else

  57.                 avs = ave = ae;

  58.               if(ave) {

  59.                 ec = *ave;

  60.                 *ave = *ae = 0;

  61.                 die_if_err(hdf_set_attr(cobj, NULL, as, avs));

  62.                 if(!strcmp(as, "q")) {

  63.                   if(*avs != '0' || *avs != '1' ||

  64.                      (avs[1] && (avs[1] != '.' ||

  65.                                  (avs[2] && !isdigit(avs[2])) ||

  66.                                  (avs[3] && !isdigit(avs[3])) ||

  67.                                  (avs[4] && !isdigit(avs[4])) ||

  68.                                  avs[5])))

  69.                     hv = NULL;

  70.                 }

  71.               } else

  72.                 hv = NULL;

  73.             } else

  74.               hv = NULL;

  75.           }

  76.         } else

  77.           hv = NULL;

  78.       } else

  79.         hv = NULL;

  80.     } else

  81.       hv = NULL;

  82.     if(hv) {

  83.       while(isspace(*hv))

  84.         hv++;

  85.       if(!*hv)

  86.         break;

  87.       if(*hv != ',') {

  88.         hv = NULL;

  89.         break;

  90.       }

  91.       while(isspace(*++hv));

  92.     }

  93.   }

  94.   if(!hv)

  95.     hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->headers, "Accept");

  96. }

The Accept-Charset header takes a list of character set identifiers, with optional q keywords to describe preference order. It is processed the same way as the Accept header, except that the character set format is different from a content type, and only the q keyword is allowed. The format for the Accept-Encoding header is the same. The format for Accept-Language is stricter, but a non-matching language is a non-matching language regardless of the reason, so they are parsed the same way as well.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("AcceptCharset"))) {

  2.   <Process priority http token list>

  3.   if(!hv)

  4.     hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->headers, "AcceptCharset");

  5. }

  6. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("AcceptEncoding"))) {

  7.   <Process priority http token list>

  8.   if(!hv)

  9.     hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->headers, "AcceptEncoding");

  10. }

  11. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("AcceptLanguage"))) {

  12.   <Process priority http token list>

  13.   if(!hv)

  14.     hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->headers, "AcceptLanguage");

  15. }

<Process priority http token list>= (<-U)

  1. char nbuf[22];

  2. int cno = 0;

  3. char *hv = hdf_obj_value(hobj), *ev, ec;

  4. HDF *cobj;

  5. while(hv) {

  6.   if(*hv == '*')

  7.     ev = hv + 1;

  8.   else

  9.     ev = skip_http_token(hv);

  10.   if(ev != hv) {

  11.     ec = *ev;

  12.     sprintf(nbuf, "%d", cno++);

  13.     die_if_err(hdf_get_node(hobj, nbuf, &cobj));

  14.     *ev = 0;

  15.     hdf_set_value(cobj, NULL, hv);

  16.     *ev = ec;

  17.     while(isspace(*hv))

  18.       hv++;

  19.     if(*hv == ';') {

  20.       while(isspace(*++hv));

  21.       if(*hv == 'q') {

  22.         while(isspace(*++hv));

  23.         if(*hv == '=') {

  24.           while(isspace(*++hv));

  25.           ev = skip_http_token(hv);

  26.           ec = *ev;

  27.           *ev = 0;

  28.           if(*hv != '0' || *hv != '1' ||

  29.              (hv[1] && (hv[1] != '.' ||

  30.                         (hv[2] && !isdigit(hv[2])) ||

  31.                         (hv[3] && !isdigit(hv[3])) ||

  32.                         (hv[4] && !isdigit(hv[4])) ||

  33.                         hv[5])))

  34.             hv = NULL;

  35.           else

  36.             die_if_err(hdf_set_attr(cobj, NULL, "q", hv));

  37.           *ev = ec;

  38.         } else

  39.           hv = NULL;

  40.       } else

  41.         hv = NULL;

  42.     }

  43.     if(hv) {

  44.       while(isspace(*hv))

  45.         hv++;

  46.       if(!*hv)

  47.         break;

  48.       if(*hv != ',') {

  49.         hv = NULL;

  50.         break;

  51.       }

  52.       while(isspace(*++hv));

  53.     }

  54.   }

  55. }

The Allow header's utility is limited, so it is left alone. The Authorization header and proxy, cache, and protocol control headers should be taken care of by the server, so they are also left alone. Entity headers may be useful for PUT requests, but they are ignored in the general case. The From, Host, and Referer fields are free-format. The application must process these headers if required.

The conditional headers are checked and adjusted. The If-Match and If-None-Match take a list of quoted strings, which are stored as children of the header parameter. The list of entity tags is split out into children of the HDF parameter after having the string quoting removed. The existence tag (*) is encoded as no children of the HDF parameter; if there are really no tags, an error 400 is returned. Although the string quoting is removed, the first character is retained as either a quote for strong tags, or a capital W for weak tags.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("IfMatch"))) {

  2.   <Set match children of hobj>

  3. }

  4. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("IfNoneMatch"))) {

  5.   <Set match children of hobj>

  6. }

<Set match children of hobj>= (<-U U->)

  1. char *v = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  2. if(!*v) {

  3.   cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  4.   die_msg("Invalid match format");

  5. }

  6. if(strcmp(v, "*")) {

  7.   char *s, *e;

  8.   int cno = 0;

  9.   char nbuf[22];

  10.   

  11.   while(1) {

  12.     s = v;

  13.     if(toupper(*v) == 'W' && v[1] == '/')

  14.       v += 2;

  15.     if(*v != '"')

  16.       break;

  17.     if(s != v)

  18.       *v = 'W';

  19.     e = ++v;

  20.     while(*v && *v != '"') {

  21.       if(*v == '\\') {

  22.         if(!v[1])

  23.           break;

  24.          ++v;

  25.       }

  26.       *e++ = *v++;

  27.     }

  28.     if(!*v) {

  29.       --v;

  30.       break;

  31.     }

  32.     sprintf(nbuf, "%d", cno++);

  33.     *e = 0;

  34.     die_if_err(hdf_set_value(hobj, nbuf, s));

  35.     while(isspace(*++v));

  36.     if(!*v || *v != ',')

  37.       break;

  38.     while(isspace(*++v));

  39.     if(!*v) {

  40.       --v;

  41.       break;

  42.     }

  43.   }

  44.   if(*v) {

  45.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  46.     die_msg("Invalid match format");

  47.   }

  48. }

The If-Modified-Since and If-Unmodified-Since take a date parameter; this is converted to its numeric equivalent. The standard says that headers with invalid dates are to be ignored, rather than rejected with a request error.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("IfModifiedSince"))) {

  2.   <Parse hobj as HTTP date>

  3. }

  4. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("IfUnmodifiedSince"))) {

  5.   <Parse hobj as HTTP date>

  6. }

<Parse hobj as HTTP date>= (<-U U->)

  1. time_t t = parse_http_date(hdf_obj_value(hobj), TRUE);

  2. if(t < 0) {

  3. #if 0

  4.   cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  5.   die_msg("Invalid header date format");

  6. #else

  7.   cgi_header_set(hdf_obj_name(hobj), NULL);

  8. #endif

  9. } else

  10.   hdf_set_int64_value(hobj, NULL, t);

The If-Range header gets either an entity tag, which is stored as a single child for consistency with the IfMatch header, or a date, which is converted to a numeric date for consistency with the If-Modified-Since header. It is to be ignored if no Range header is present.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("IfRange"))) {

  2.   const char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   if(!cgi_header_obj("Range"))

  4.     cgi_header_set("IfRange", NULL);

  5.   else {

  6.     if(*cv == '"' || (toupper(*cv) == 'W' && cv[1] == '/')) {

  7.       <Set match children of hobj>

  8.       if(hdf_obj_next(hdf_obj_child(hobj))) {

  9.         cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  10.         die_msg("Only specify one entity tag for If-Range");

  11.       }

  12.     } else {

  13.       <Parse hobj as HTTP date>

  14.     }

  15.   }

  16. }

The next supported header is the partial download specifier, Range. This takes an arbitrary named range specifier, but the RFC only defines one, so that is what is supported: the byte range. Each range is converted into a child whose name is the start of the range and whose value is the end of the range. This makes it easier to sort and merge the ranges. If multiple ranges have the same start, the highest end value is used. Note that unknown range types are ignored by not having any children, and that the RFC recommendation of returning ranges in order is violated by merging overlapping ranges. Once the children are sorted, it will become impossible to match the requested ordering.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Range"))) {

  2.   const char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   if(!strncasecmp(cv, "bytes", 5)) {

  4.     cv += 4;

  5.     while(isspace(*++cv));

  6.     while(1) {

  7.       guint64 start = 0, end = ~0; /* open range */

  8.       char nbuf[22];

  9.       HDF *ov;

  10.       gboolean got_start = FALSE, got_end = FALSE;

  11.       if(isdigit(*cv)) {

  12.         got_start = TRUE;

  13.         start = strtoull(cv, (char **)&cv, 10);

  14.         while(isspace(*cv))

  15.           cv++;

  16.       }

  17.       if(*cv == '-') {

  18.         while(isspace(*++cv));

  19.         if(isdigit(*cv)) {

  20.           got_end = TRUE;

  21.           end = strtoull(cv, (char **)&cv, 10);

  22.           while(isspace(*cv))

  23.             cv++;

  24.         }

  25.       }

  26.       if((*cv && *cv != ',') || (!got_start && !got_end) || end < start) {

  27.         cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  28.         die_msg("Invalid range specification");

  29.       }

  30.       sprintf(nbuf, "%llu", (ullong)start);

  31.       if((ov = hdf_get_obj(hobj, nbuf))) {

  32.         start = hdf_get_int64_value(hobj, nbuf, 0);

  33.         if(start < end)

  34.           die_if_err(hdf_set_int64_value(hobj, nbuf, end));

  35.       } else

  36.         die_if_err(hdf_set_int64_value(hobj, nbuf, end));

  37.     }

  38.   }

  39. }

Next are the headers described by the WebDAV RFCs. RFC 4918 describes the Depth header, which should be ignored if not needed, but otherwise must consist of one of three values. Rather than ignore it as required, the header causes an error 400 if it is not one of the three known values.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Depth"))) {

  2.   const char *v = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   if(v && strcmp(v, "0") && strcmp(v, "1") && strcasecmp(v, "infinity")) {

  4.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request"); /* 422? */

  5.     die_msg("Depth is invalid");

  6.   }

  7. }

The next header is the Destination header, which must be a so-called simple reference. This is either an absolute URI or an absolute path with no relative references (. or ..) which also normally matches the request URI as much as possible. For the Destination header, the last requirement is relaxed. For this library, URIs are expected to be relative to the same CGI program. To use this with a program that supports alternate targets, such as for thrid party copies, simply use the environment variable directly rather than the stored version, and delete it from the environment to avoid errors generated here.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Destination"))) {

  2.   nerr = normalize_path_obj(hobj, cgi_state, NULL, TRUE, TRUE);

  3.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  4.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  5.     return nerr_pass_ctx(nerr, "Destination");

  6.   }

  7. }

The RFC 4918 conditional header, If, is a bit more complex than the plain HTTP conditionals. It can specify conditions on several resources, via resource tags (the request URI by default). Multiple lists are then specified which apply to that resource. For each such list, a child is created whose value is the resource to which it applies, and whose children are the conditions which must all apply for the child to evaluate to true. The overall header evaluates to true if any of its immediate children evaluate to true, which implies that all of that child's children evaluate to true. The conditions themselves are an entity tag or a state token. The entity tags are encoded as above, except that inversion is specified by using a lower-case w for weak tags and a single quote for strong tags. State tokens are enclosed in angle brackets, so the less-than sign is retained as a prefix to distinguish them, or a greater-than sign for inverted state tokens. The only validation done on state tokens and entity tags is to verify that state tokens have a protocol separator (:).

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("If"))) {

  2.   char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   gboolean rtag_allowed = *cv == '<';

  4.   const char *path_info = cgi_header_val("CGI.PathInfo", "");

  5.   const char *res = path_info;

  6.   int orn = 0;

  7.   char nbuf[22];

  8.   while(1) {

  9.     if(rtag_allowed && *cv == '<') {

  10.       res = ++cv;

  11.       while(*cv && *cv != '>')

  12.         cv++;

  13.       if(!*cv) {

  14.         cv = NULL;

  15.         break;

  16.       }

  17.       *cv = 0;

  18.       while(isspace(*++cv));

  19.       <Check and adjust resource URI res>

  20.     }

  21.     if(*cv != '(') {

  22.       cv = NULL;

  23.       break;

  24.     }

  25.     while(isspace(*++cv));

  26.     int andn = 0;

  27.     HDF *res_obj;

  28.     sprintf(nbuf, "%d", orn++);

  29.     die_if_err(hdf_get_node(hobj, nbuf, &res_obj));

  30.     die_if_err(hdf_set_value(res_obj, NULL, res));

  31.     if(res != path_info) {

  32.       <Check and adjust resource URI res_obj/res>

  33.       path_info = res;

  34.     }

  35.     while(1) {

  36.       gboolean is_not = !strncasecmp(cv, "Not", 3);

  37.       const char *sv;

  38.       if(is_not) {

  39.         cv += 2;

  40.         while(isspace(*++cv));

  41.       }

  42.       if(*cv == '<') {

  43.         sv = cv;

  44.         if(is_not)

  45.           *cv = '>';

  46.         while(*++cv && *cv != '>');

  47.         if(*cv != '>') {

  48.           cv = NULL;

  49.           break;

  50.         }

  51.         *cv = 0;

  52.         if(!strchr(sv, ':')) {

  53.           cv = NULL;

  54.           break;

  55.         }

  56.       } else if(*cv == '[') {

  57.         sv = cv;

  58.         if(toupper(*++cv) == 'W' && cv[1] == '/')

  59.           cv += 2;

  60.         if(*cv != '"') {

  61.           cv = NULL;

  62.           break;

  63.         }

  64.         if(sv != cv) {

  65.           sv = cv;

  66.           *cv = is_not ? 'w' : 'W';

  67.         } else if(is_not)

  68.           *cv = '\'';

  69.         char *e = cv + 1;

  70.         while(*++cv && *cv != '"') {

  71.           if(*cv == '\\') {

  72.             if(!cv[1]) {

  73.               cv = NULL;

  74.               break;

  75.             }

  76.             cv++;

  77.           }

  78.           *e++ = *cv;

  79.         }

  80.         if(*cv != '"' || *++cv != ']') {

  81.           cv = NULL;

  82.           break;

  83.         }

  84.         *e = 0;

  85.       } else {

  86.         cv = NULL;

  87.         break;

  88.       }

  89.       sprintf(nbuf, "%d", andn++);

  90.       die_if_err(hdf_set_value(res_obj, nbuf, sv));

  91.       while(isspace(*++cv));

  92.       if(*cv == ')')

  93.         break;

  94.     }

  95.     if(!cv)

  96.       break;

  97.     while(isspace(*++cv));

  98.     if(!*cv)

  99.       break;

  100.   }

  101.   if(!cv) {

  102.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  103.     die_msg("Bad If syntax");

  104.   }

  105. }

The resource tags actually specify entities which must be checked for the applicable conditions. They have the simple reference conditions described for the Destination header, except that in this case, the restriction of being the same or beneath the request URI is a requirement. Or at least that is what the RFC says; in actuality, it can also match the Destination header. In fact, some samples in the RFCs indicate that the path only needs to match after normalization, including sloppy hostname matching, resolution of home directories, and so forth. For this reason, the path is only subjected to standard normalization of absolute URLs, with no further processing. This at least requires that URLs be on the same host.

<Check and adjust resource URI res_obj/res>= (<-U)

  1. cgi_url_unescape(hdf_obj_value(res_obj));

  2. die_if_err(normalize_path_obj(res_obj, cgi_state, NULL, TRUE, TRUE));

  3. res = hdf_obj_value(res_obj);

The Lock-Token header specifies a lock token, which is a URL enclosed in angle brackets. The only check is that it contains a colon.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("LockToken"))) {

  2.   const char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj), *gt;

  3.   if(*cv != '<' || !strchr(cv, ':') || !(gt = strrchr(cv, '>')) || gt[1]) {

  4.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  5.     die_msg("Invalid state token Lock-Token");

  6.   }

  7. }

The Overwrite header must match the value T or F. It is converted to upper-case.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Overwrite"))) {

  2.   char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   

  4.   if(cv[1])

  5.     cv = NULL;

  6.   else if(*cv == 't')

  7.     *cv = 'T';

  8.   else if(*cv == 'f')

  9.     *cv = 'F';

  10.   else if(*cv != 'T' && *cv != 'F')

  11.     cv = NULL;

  12.   if(!cv) {

  13.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  14.     die_msg("Overwrite must be T or F");

  15.   }

  16. }

The Timeout header consists of one or more comma-separated timeout values, which are a number of seconds or the word Infinite. If there is only one, it is simply checked for validity. If there is more than one, children are created with the values.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Timeout"))) {

  2.   char *v = hdf_obj_value(hobj), *vs, *ve;

  3.   int cno = 0;

  4.   char nbuf[22];

  5.   while(1) {

  6.     vs = v;

  7.     if(!strncasecmp(v, "Infinite", 8)) {

  8.       v += 8;

  9.     } else if(!strncasecmp(v, "Second-", 7) && isdigit(v[7])) {

  10.       v += 7;

  11.       while(isdigit(*++v));

  12.     } else

  13.       v= NULL;

  14.     if(!v)

  15.       break;

  16.     ve = v;

  17.     while(isspace(*v))

  18.       v++;

  19.     if(*v && *v != ',') {

  20.       v = NULL;

  21.       break;

  22.     }

  23.     if(cno || *v == ',') {

  24.       char c = *ve;

  25.       *ve = 0;

  26.       sprintf(nbuf, "%d", cno++);

  27.       die_if_err(hdf_set_value(hobj, nbuf, vs));

  28.       *ve = c;

  29.     }

  30.     if(*v == ',')

  31.       while(isspace(*++v));

  32.     else

  33.       break;

  34.   }

  35.   if(!v) {

  36.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request"); /* 422? */

  37.     die_msg("Timeout is invalid");

  38.   }

  39. }

RFC 3253 defines the Label header, which is an arbitray URL-encoded string.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("Label"))) {

  2.   char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   cgi_url_unescape(cv);

  4. }

Finally, RFC 4437 defines the Apply-To-Redirect-Ref header, which also takes either T or F. Since it applies universally, it is removed if it matches its default value of F.

<Process common HTTP headers>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if((hobj = cgi_header_obj("ApplyToRedirectRef"))) {

  2.   char *cv = hdf_obj_value(hobj);

  3.   

  4.   if(cv[1])

  5.     cv = NULL;

  6.   else if(*cv == 't')

  7.     *cv = 'T';

  8.   else if(*cv == 'f')

  9.     *cv = 'F';

  10.   else if(*cv != 'T' && *cv != 'F')

  11.     cv = NULL;

  12.   if(!cv) {

  13.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  14.     die_msg("Apply-To-Redirect-Ref must be T or F");

  15.   } else if(*cv == 'F')

  16.     cgi_header_set("AplyToRedirectRef", NULL);

  17. }

XML Parameter Bodies

Another group of requests that take bodies is the set of WebDAV requests. These take XML bodies and special headers instead of plain CGI request parameters. What methods take what parameters, and how they are interpreted, is determined by which RFCs the underlying CGI supports. For this reason, if the method is anything but PUT, POST, HEAD, or GET, and the content type is XML, the XML is just sucked verbatim into an XML parse tree stored in the CGI state. This means that POST parameters with SOAP requests must be parsed manually after CGI initialization. The parsing is done using libxml218 using the document-at-once parser19. While incremental (xmlreader) mode would probably minimize the extra storage required for the XML tree, the size of the trees should be fairly small, anyway, and HDF is not much better for excess storage minimization (60-112 bytes per node vs. 60-120 bytes per node). A separate upload limit parameter is provided to limit incoming XML requests.

<CGI Support Configuration>+= (U->) [<-D]

  1. # If set, limit XML request bodies (not PUT or POST) to this size, in bytes

  2. #max_xml_body = 100000

<CGI Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. guint64 max_xml_body;

<Perform global CGI support initialization>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. max_xml_body = getconf_int("max_xml_body", 100000);

  2. xmlInitParser();

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>+= [<-D->]

  1. EXTRA_CFLAGS += $(shell xml2-config --cflags)

  2. EXTRA_LDFLAGS += $(shell xml2-config --libs)

<CGI Prerequisite Headers>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. #include <libxml/parser.h>

  2. #include <libxml/xmlerror.h>

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. xmlDocPtr xmlbody;

  2. guint64 xmllen;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. /* actually, content-type should be text/xml or application/xml */

  2. /* but we are not required to be that picky */

  3. if(cgi_state->body_len && strstr(cgi_state->body_type, "/xml") &&

  4.    req_method != HTTP_REQ_GET &&

  5.    req_method != HTTP_REQ_POST &&

  6.    req_method != HTTP_REQ_PUT &&

  7.    req_method != HTTP_REQ_HEAD) {

  8.   xmlDocPtr xml = xmlReadIO(xml_read_cgi, NULL, cgi_state, NULL, NULL,

  9.                             XML_PARSE_NOENT | XML_PARSE_NONET |

  10.                             XML_PARSE_NOWARNING | XML_PARSE_NOERROR |

  11.                             XML_PARSE_NOCDATA | XML_PARSE_COMPACT);

  12.   if(!xml) {

  13.     xmlErrorPtr err = xmlGetLastError();

  14.     if(err && err->code != XML_ERR_OK && err->code != XML_ERR_NO_MEMORY &&

  15.        err->code != XML_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR &&

  16.        !cgi_env_val("error_status", NULL))

  17.       cgi_env_set("error_status", "400 Bad Request");

  18.     if(err && err->message) {

  19.       nerr = nerr_raise_msg_errno(err->message);

  20.       return nerr_pass_ctx(nerr, "Unable to parse body");

  21.     } else

  22.       return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Unable to parse body");

  23.   }

  24.   cgi_state->xmlbody = xml;

  25. }

<Free CGI state members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(cgi_state->xmlbody)

  2.   xmlFreeDoc(cgi_state->xmlbody);

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. int xml_read_cgi(void *context, char *buf, int len)

  2. {

  3.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = context;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr;

  5.   if(cgi_state->xmllen + len > max_xml_body) {

  6.     cgi_env_set("error_status", "413 Request Entity Too Large");

  7.     errno = ENOMEM;

  8.     return -1;

  9.   }

  10.   nerr = cgi_read(buf, len, &len);

  11.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  12.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  13.     return -1;

  14.   }

  15.   return len;

  16. }

Now that the XML parameters have been processed, it might be nice to print them if debugging is enabled.

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(debug && cgi_state->xmlbody) {

  2.   xmlChar *mem;

  3.   int size;

  4.   cgi_puts("<pre>XML:\n");

  5.   xmlIndentTreeOutput = TRUE;

  6.   xmlDocDumpFormatMemory(cgi_state->xmlbody, &mem, &size, TRUE);

  7.   if(mem) {

  8.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, (const char *)mem, FALSE);

  9.     xmlFree(mem);

  10.   }

  11.   cgi_puts("--------\n</pre>\n");

  12. }

The WebDAV RFCs specify what constitutes valid XML bodies for the WebDAV requests, so they are validated here. That does mean this code will need to be modified if the RFCs change. Validating the XML with a DTD is impossible. Although a DTD-like specification is given in the RFCs, there are requirements which cannot be specified in the DTD language. For example, when specifying multiple elements as children, the DTD imposes an order, but WebDAV does not impose any ordering. Therefore, all checking is just done manually. Empty XML should probably be considered invalid, but instead it is treated as a missing body.

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. gboolean valid;

  2. xmlNodePtr node = NULL; /* init to shut gcc up */

  3. xmlNsPtr dav_ns = NULL; /* cache for DAV: namespace */

  4. if(!cgi_state->xmlbody || !(node = cgi_state->xmlbody->children))

  5.   valid = TRUE <unless method requires XML body>;

  6. else if(!cgi_state->xmlbody && cgi_state->body_len)

  7.   valid = TRUE <unless method requires no body or XML body>;

  8. else

  9.   valid = TRUE;

  10. if(valid && cgi_state->body_len)

  11.   valid = TRUE <unless method requires no body>;

  12. if(!valid) {

  13.   cgi_env_set("error_status", "415 Unsupported Media Type");

  14.   return nerr_raise_msg("Body not supported for this method");

  15. } else if(cgi_state->xmlbody)

  16.   switch(req_method) {

  17.     <Check WebDAV XML body>

  18.     default:

  19.       break; /* ignore unknown methods */

  20.   }

  21. if(!valid) {

  22.   cgi_env_set("error_status", "422 Unprocessable Entity"); /* RFC 4918 */

  23.   return nerr_raise_msg("XML Invalid");

  24. }

XML tag names are converted to integer constants to be stored in the _private field of the XML nodes. Name comparisons other than that cannot be cached.

<cgi-gperf-xml_name>=

  1. <XML validator names>

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. xml_name_t,%

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define xml_str_id(s) xml_name_id((const char *)s, strlen((const char *)s))

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. xml_name_t xml_tag(xmlNodePtr node)

  2. {

  3.   if(!node->_private)

  4.     node->_private = (void *)(guint64)xml_str_id(node->name);

  5.   return (xml_name_t)(guint64)node->_private;

  6. }

Also, since most comparisons will be done in a single namespace, the namespace comparison can be done by comparing namespace pointers rather than the name itself. If the identifier being used changes from one tag to the next, though, only a direct name comparison can be used. Since there may be further checks against the DAV: namespace, it is stored in the CGI state as well. Although unset namespaces are technically not allowed, attributes should inherit the namespace from the tag, but do not in libxml2. Instead, if a NULL namespace is detected, it is always set to the cache.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. gboolean check_ns(xmlNodePtr node, xml_name_t ns, xmlNsPtr *nscache)

  2. {

  3.   if(nscache && *nscache && node->ns == *nscache)

  4.     return TRUE;

  5.   if(!node->ns || !node->ns->href)

  6.     return nscache && (node->ns = *nscache);

  7.   if(xml_str_id(node->ns->href) != ns)

  8.     return FALSE;

  9.   if(nscache)

  10.     *nscache = node->ns;

  11.   return TRUE;

  12. }

<XML validator names>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. DAV:

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define DAV_NS XML_NAME_DAV_

<CGI State Members>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. xmlNsPtr dav_ns;

<Initialize this CGI run>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. cgi_state->dav_ns = dav_ns;

Blanks and comments are mostly irrelevant, and get in the way. Comments never need to be saved, so they are just dropped. Just in case a processing instruction creeps through, they can be dropped as well. Blanks can be dropped everywhere except in property values: even if the XML declares that whitespace is not relevant, it is always relevant in property values. This means that things cannot be cleaned recursively very easily, but that is probably not necessary, anyway. Instead, a function to return the children with the ignorable elements stripped out is provided. Since comments may split text segments, any consecutive text segments resulting from the deletion are merged.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. xmlNodePtr xml_strip_children(xmlNodePtr node, gboolean strip_blanks)

  2. {

  3.   xmlNodePtr first = node->children, next;

  4.   for(node = first; node; node = next) {

  5.     next = node->next;

  6.     switch(node->type) {

  7.       case XML_TEXT_NODE:

  8.         if(!strip_blanks || !xmlIsBlankNode(node))

  9.           break;

  10.         /* fall through */

  11.       case XML_PI_NODE: /* processing instruction */

  12.       case XML_COMMENT_NODE:

  13.         if(first == node)

  14.           first = next;

  15.         xmlUnlinkNode(node);

  16.         xmlFreeNode(node);

  17.         if(next && next->prev &&

  18.            xmlNodeIsText(next) && xmlNodeIsText(next->prev) && 

  19.            (!strip_blanks || !xmlIsBlankNode(next))) {

  20.           xmlTextMerge(next->prev, next);

  21.           node = next;

  22.           next = node->next;

  23.           xmlUnlinkNode(node);

  24.           xmlFreeNode(node);

  25.         }

  26.         break;

  27.       default:

  28.         break;

  29.     }

  30.   }

  31.   return first;

  32. }

<CGI Support Global Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define xml_child(n) xml_strip_children(n, TRUE)

For properties only, a recursive function is provided to strip comments and processing instructions.

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void xml_clean_prop(xmlNodePtr node)

  2. {

  3.   for(node = xml_strip_children(node, FALSE); node; node = node->next)

  4.     xml_clean_prop(node);

  5. }

The PROPFIND request takes an optional body containing exactly one propfind element.

<webdav.dtd>= [D->]

  1. <!-- PROPFIND method, optional body with exactly one propfind -->

  2. <!ELEMENT propfind ( propname | (allprop, include?) | prop ) >

  3.   <!ELEMENT propname EMPTY >

  4.   <!ELEMENT allprop EMPTY >

  5.   <!ELEMENT include ANY >

  6.     <!-- children must be only empty tags -->

  7.   <!ELEMENT prop ANY >

  8.     <!-- children must be only empty tags -->

<XML validator names>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. propfind propname allprop include prop

<unless method requires no body or XML body>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. && req_method != HTTP_REQ_PROPFIND

<Check WebDAV XML body>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. case HTTP_REQ_PROPFIND:

  2.   if(node->next || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  3.      xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_PROPFIND || !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) ||

  4.      !(node = xml_child(node)) || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  5.      !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  6.     valid = FALSE;

  7.   if(valid) {

  8.     xml_name_t tn = xml_tag(node);

  9.     if(tn == XML_NAME_ALLPROP) {

  10.       /* allprop + optional include */

  11.       valid = !xml_child(node);

  12.       if(node->next && node->next->type == XML_ELEMENT_NODE &&

  13.          xml_tag(node->next) == XML_NAME_INCLUDE &&

  14.          check_ns(node->next, DAV_NS, &dav_ns)) {

  15.         node = node->next;

  16.         valid = valid && check_prop(node, FALSE);

  17.       }

  18.       valid = valid && !node->next;

  19.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_INCLUDE)

  20.       /* include + allprop */

  21.       valid = node->next && !node->next->next && !xml_child(node->next) &&

  22.               node->next->type == XML_ELEMENT_NODE &&

  23.               xml_tag(node->next) == XML_NAME_ALLPROP &&

  24.               check_ns(node->next, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) && check_prop(node, FALSE);

  25.     else if(tn == XML_NAME_PROP)

  26.       valid = !node->next && check_prop(node, FALSE);

  27.     else if(tn == XML_NAME_PROPNAME)

  28.       valid = !node->next && !xml_child(node);

  29.   }

  30.   break;

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static gboolean check_prop(xmlNodePtr node, gboolean has_val)

  2. {

  3.   if(!xml_child(node))

  4.     return FALSE;

  5.   for(node = node->children; node; node = node->next)

  6.     if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || (!has_val && xml_child(node)) ||

  7.        !node->ns || !node->ns->href)

  8.       return FALSE;

  9.   return TRUE;

  10. }

The PROPPATCH method requires an XML body with exactly one propertyupdate element.

<webdav.dtd>+= [<-D->]

  1. <!-- PROPPATCH method, required XML body, exactly one propertyupdate -->

  2. <!ELEMENT propertyupdate (remove | set)+ >

  3.   <!ELEMENT remove (prop) >

  4.       <!ELEMENT prop ANY >

  5.         <!-- children must be only empty tags -->

  6.    <!ELEMENT set (prop) >

  7.       <!ELEMENT prop ANY >

  8.         <!-- children must be tags with valid XML values -->

<XML validator names>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. propertyupdate remove set

<unless method requires XML body>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. && req_method != HTTP_REQ_PROPPATCH

<Check WebDAV XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. case HTTP_REQ_PROPPATCH:

  2.   /* exactly one child element called propertyupdate, with at least one child */

  3.   if(node->next || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  4.      xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_PROPERTYUPDATE || !xml_child(node) ||

  5.      !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  6.     valid = FALSE;

  7.   for(node = node->children; node && valid; node = node->next) {

  8.     xmlNodePtr c;

  9.     gboolean no_val = FALSE; /* init to shut gcc up */

  10.     xml_name_t tn;

  11.     /* one or more set/reset nodes */

  12.     if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  13.       valid = FALSE;

  14.     else if((tn = xml_tag(node)) == XML_NAME_REMOVE)

  15.       no_val = TRUE;

  16.     else if(tn == XML_NAME_SET)

  17.       no_val = FALSE;

  18.     else

  19.       valid = FALSE;

  20.     /* with a single prop child whose children are property tags */

  21.     if(valid && (!(c = xml_child(node)) || c->next ||

  22.                  c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  23.                  !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) ||

  24.                  xml_tag(c) != XML_NAME_PROP || !check_prop(c, !no_val)))

  25.       valid = FALSE;

  26.   }

  27.   break;

The LOCK method takes an optional body with exactly one lockinfo element.

<webdav.dtd>+= [<-D->]

  1. <!-- LOCK method, optional body, exactly one lockinfo (def: refresh) -->

  2. <!ELEMENT lockinfo (lockscope, locktype, owner?)  >

  3.   <!ELEMENT lockscope (exclusive | shared) >

  4.     <!ELEMENT exclusive EMPTY >  <!-- empty tag flag (what a waste) -->

  5.     <!ELEMENT shared EMPTY > <!-- empty tag flag -->

  6.   <!ELEMENT locktype (write) >

  7.     <!ELEMENT write EMPTY > <!-- empty tag flag -->

  8.   <!ELEMENT owner ANY > <!-- preserve value verbatim like a property -->

<XML validator names>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. lockinfo lockscope locktype owner exclusive shared write

<unless method requires no body or XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. && req_method != HTTP_REQ_LOCK

<Check WebDAV XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. case HTTP_REQ_LOCK:

  2.   /* exactly one child element called lockinfo, with at least one child */

  3.   if(node->next || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !xml_child(node) ||

  4.      xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_LOCKINFO || !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  5.     valid = FALSE;

  6.   if(valid) {

  7.     gboolean got_ls = FALSE, got_lt = FALSE, got_o = FALSE;

  8.     for(node = node->children; node && valid; node = node->next) {

  9.       xmlNodePtr c;

  10.       xml_name_t tn;

  11.       if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !(c = xml_child(node)) ||

  12.          !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  13.         valid = FALSE;

  14.       else if((tn = xml_tag(node)) == XML_NAME_LOCKSCOPE) {

  15.         valid = !got_ls;

  16.         got_ls = TRUE;

  17.         if(c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || c->next || xml_child(c) ||

  18.            !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) ||

  19.            ((tn = xml_tag(c)) != XML_NAME_EXCLUSIVE && tn != XML_NAME_SHARED))

  20.           valid = FALSE;

  21.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_LOCKTYPE) {

  22.         valid = !got_lt;

  23.         got_lt = TRUE;

  24.         if(c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || c->next || xml_child(c) ||

  25.            xml_tag(c) != XML_NAME_WRITE || !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  26.           valid = FALSE;

  27.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_OWNER) {

  28.         valid = !got_o;

  29.         got_o = TRUE;

  30.       } else

  31.         valid = FALSE;

  32.     }

  33.     if(!got_ls || !got_lt)

  34.       valid = FALSE;

  35.   }

  36.   break;

The SEARCH method requires a body with exactly one element which is either searchrequest or query-schema-discovery. Each child is an element whose name is that of a supported search method; the only search method which is checked for validity is the basicsearch method. It is up to the application to validate and throw errors for unsupported search methods. The specification is unclear on how to handle multiple search methods in a single request, but the implication is that only one should be supported, so that is what is enforced here.

<webdav.dtd>+= [<-D->]

  1. <!-- SEARCH method, required body with searchrequest or query-schema-discovery -->

  2. <!ELEMENT searchrequest ANY > <!-- one child whose name determines grammar -->

  3.   <basicsearch DTD>

  4. <!ELEMENT query-schema-discovery ANY>

  5.   <!-- child is query grammar and scope -->

  6.   <!ELEMENT basicsearch   (from) >

<basicsearch DTD>= (<-U)

  1. <!ELEMENT basicsearch   (select, from, where?, orderby?, limit?) >

  2.   <!ELEMENT select        (allprop | prop) >

  3.     <!-- props are just tags, and allprop is a flag -->

  4.   <!ELEMENT from          (scope+) >

  5.     <!ELEMENT scope         (href, depth, include-versions?) >

  6.     <!ELEMENT include-versions EMPTY >

  7.   <!-- where -->

  8.     <!ENTITY % all_ops      "%comp_ops; | %log_ops; | %special_ops; |

  9.                              %string_ops; | %content_ops;">

  10.     <!ENTITY % comp_ops     "eq | lt | gt| lte | gte">

  11.     <!ENTITY % log_ops      "and | or | not">

  12.     <!ENTITY % special_ops  "is-collection | is-defined |

  13.                              language-defined | language-matches">

  14.     <!ENTITY % string_ops   "like">

  15.     <!ENTITY % content_ops  "contains">

  16.   <!ELEMENT where         ( %all_ops; ) >

  17.       <!ELEMENT and           ( %all_ops; )+ >

  18.       <!ELEMENT or            ( %all_ops; )+ >

  19.       <!ELEMENT not           ( %all_ops; ) >

  20.       <!ELEMENT lt            (prop, (literal|typed-literal)) >

  21.         <!ATTLIST lt            caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  22.       <!ELEMENT lte           (prop, (literal|typed-literal)) >

  23.         <!ATTLIST lte           caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  24.       <!ELEMENT gt           (prop, (literal|typed-literal)) >

  25.         <!ATTLIST gt           caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  26.       <!ELEMENT gte           (prop, (literal|typed-literal)) >

  27.         <!ATTLIST gte           caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  28.       <!ELEMENT eq           (prop, (literal|typed-literal)) >

  29.         <!ATTLIST eq           caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  30.       <!ELEMENT literal       (#PCDATA)>

  31.       <!ELEMENT typed-literal (#PCDATA)>

  32.         <!ATTLIST typed-literal xsi:type CDATA #IMPLIED>

  33.       <!ELEMENT is-collection EMPTY >

  34.       <!ELEMENT is-defined    (prop) >

  35.       <!ELEMENT language-defined    (prop) >

  36.       <!ELEMENT language-matches    (prop, literal) >

  37.       <!ELEMENT like          (prop, literal) >

  38.         <!ATTLIST like          caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  39.       <!ELEMENT contains      (#PCDATA)>

  40.   <!ELEMENT orderby       (order+) >

  41.     <!ELEMENT order         ((prop | score), (ascending | descending)?)>

  42.       <!ATTLIST order         caseless   (yes|no) #IMPLIED>

  43.       <!ELEMENT ascending     EMPTY>

  44.       <!ELEMENT descending    EMPTY>

  45.   <!ELEMENT limit         (nresults) >

  46.     <!ELEMENT nresults      (#PCDATA) >

<XML validator names>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. searchrequest query-schema-discovery basicsearch select from scope href

  2. depth 0 1 infinity include-versions where and or not lt caseless yes no lte

  3. gt gte eq literal typed-literal is-collection is-defined language-defined

  4. language-matches like contains orderby order score ascending descending

  5. limit nresults

<unless method requires XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. && req_method != HTTP_REQ_SEARCH

<Check WebDAV XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. case HTTP_REQ_SEARCH: {

  2.   /* exactly one child element called searchrequest or query-schema-discovery,

  3.      with at least one child */

  4.   xml_name_t tn;

  5.   if(node->next || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  6.      ((tn = xml_tag(node)) != XML_NAME_SEARCHREQUEST &&

  7.       tn != XML_NAME_QUERY_SCHEMA_DISCOVERY) ||

  8.      !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) || !xml_child(node) ||

  9.      node->children->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE)

  10.     valid = FALSE;

  11.   gboolean is_search = valid && tn == XML_NAME_SEARCHREQUEST;

  12.   node = node->children;

  13.   /* searchrequest has exactly one child element specifying search */

  14.   /* not sure if query-schema-discovery should support >1 child element */

  15.   valid = valid && !node->next; /* not sure this is made clear in RFC */

  16.   /* make it a loop in case above condition is removed */

  17.   for( ; node; node = node->next) {

  18.     xmlNodePtr c;

  19.     if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !(c = xml_child(node))) {

  20.       valid = FALSE;

  21.       break;

  22.     }

  23.     /* name check is done after ns check so _private isn't set if it isn't */

  24.     /* DAV:basicsearch; this allows the client to avoid check_ns */

  25.     if(!check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) ||

  26.        xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_BASICSEARCH)

  27.       continue;

  28.     gboolean got_sel, got_from, got_where, got_oby, got_limit;

  29.     got_sel = got_where = got_oby = got_limit = !is_search;

  30.     got_from = FALSE;

  31.     for(; c && valid; c = c->next) {

  32.       xmlNodePtr subc;

  33.       if(!check_ns(c, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) || !(subc = xml_child(c)) ||

  34.          subc->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !check_ns(subc, DAV_NS, &dav_ns)) {

  35.         valid = FALSE;

  36.         break;

  37.       }

  38.       if((tn = xml_tag(c)) == XML_NAME_SELECT) {

  39.         valid = !got_sel && !subc->next;

  40.         got_sel = TRUE;

  41.         if((tn = xml_tag(subc)) == XML_NAME_ALLPROP)

  42.           valid = valid && !xml_child(subc);

  43.         else if(tn == XML_NAME_PROP)

  44.           valid = check_prop(subc, FALSE);

  45.         else

  46.           valid = FALSE;

  47.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_FROM) {

  48.         valid = !got_from;

  49.         got_from = TRUE;

  50.         xmlNodePtr scope;

  51.         for(; subc && valid; subc = subc->next) {

  52.           valid = subc->type == XML_ELEMENT_NODE && (scope = xml_child(subc)) &&

  53.                   xml_tag(subc) == XML_NAME_SCOPE &&

  54.                   check_ns(subc, DAV_NS, &dav_ns);

  55.           gboolean got_href = FALSE, got_depth = FALSE, got_incv = FALSE;

  56.           for(; scope && valid; scope = scope->next) {

  57.             if(!check_ns(scope, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  58.               valid = FALSE;

  59.             else if((tn = xml_tag(scope)) == XML_NAME_HREF) {

  60.               valid = !got_href && xml_child(scope) && !scope->children->next &&

  61.                       xmlNodeIsText(scope->children);

  62.               got_href = TRUE;

  63.             } else if(tn == XML_NAME_DEPTH) {

  64.               valid = !got_depth;

  65.               got_depth = TRUE;

  66.               xmlNodePtr val;

  67.               if(valid && (val = xml_child(scope)))

  68.                 valid = !val->next && xmlNodeIsText(val) &&

  69.                         ((tn = xml_str_id(val->content)) == XML_NAME_0 ||

  70.                          tn == XML_NAME_1 || tn == XML_NAME_INFINITY);

  71.             } else if(tn == XML_NAME_INCLUDE_VERSIONS) {

  72.               valid = !got_incv && !xml_child(scope);

  73.               got_incv = TRUE;

  74.             } else

  75.               valid = FALSE;

  76.           }

  77.           if(!got_href || !got_depth)

  78.             valid = FALSE;

  79.         }

  80.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_WHERE) {

  81.         valid = !got_where && check_where_ops(subc, &dav_ns);

  82.         got_where = TRUE;

  83.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_ORDERBY) {

  84.         valid = !got_oby;

  85.         got_oby = TRUE;

  86.         for(; subc && valid; subc = subc->next) {

  87.           xmlNodePtr order;

  88.           if(!xml_child(subc) || xml_tag(subc) != XML_NAME_ORDER ||

  89.              !check_ns(subc, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  90.             valid = FALSE;

  91.           else {

  92.             gboolean got_prop = FALSE, got_asc = FALSE;

  93.             for(order = xml_child(subc); order; order = order->next) {

  94.               if(!check_ns(order, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  95.                 valid = FALSE;

  96.               else if((tn = xml_tag(order)) == XML_NAME_PROP) {

  97.                 valid = !got_prop && check_prop(order, FALSE);

  98.                 got_prop = TRUE;

  99.               } else if(tn == XML_NAME_SCORE) {

  100.                 valid = !got_prop && xml_child(order) &&

  101.                         !order->children->next &&

  102.                         xmlNodeIsText(order->children);

  103.                 got_prop = TRUE;

  104.                 if(valid) {

  105.                   const char *s = (const char *)order->children->content;

  106.                   for(; *s; s++)

  107.                     if(!isdigit(*s))

  108.                       valid = FALSE;

  109.                 }

  110.               } else if(tn == XML_NAME_ASCENDING ||

  111.                         tn == XML_NAME_DESCENDING) {

  112.                 valid = !got_asc && !xml_child(order);

  113.                 got_asc = TRUE;

  114.               } else

  115.                 valid = FALSE;

  116.             }

  117.           }

  118.           if(valid)

  119.             valid = check_caseless_attr(subc, &dav_ns);

  120.         }

  121.       } else if(tn == XML_NAME_LIMIT) {

  122.         valid = !got_limit && !subc->next && xml_child(subc) &&

  123.                 !subc->children->next && xmlNodeIsText(subc->children) &&

  124.                 xml_tag(subc) == XML_NAME_NRESULTS &&

  125.                 check_ns(subc, DAV_NS, &dav_ns);

  126.         got_limit = TRUE;

  127.         const char *s;

  128.         for(s = (const char *)subc->children->content; *s; s++)

  129.           if(!isdigit(*s))

  130.             valid = FALSE;

  131.       } else

  132.         valid = FALSE;

  133.     }

  134.     if(!got_sel || !got_from)

  135.       valid = FALSE;

  136.   }

  137.   break;

  138. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static gboolean check_caseless_attr(xmlNodePtr node, xmlNsPtr *nsc)

  2. {

  3.   xmlAttrPtr attrs;

  4.   gboolean valid = TRUE;

  5.   xml_name_t tn;

  6.   for(attrs = node->properties; attrs && valid; attrs = attrs->next)

  7.     if(xml_tag((xmlNodePtr)attrs) == XML_NAME_CASELESS &&

  8.        check_ns((xmlNodePtr)attrs, DAV_NS, nsc))

  9.       valid = attrs->children && !attrs->children->next &&

  10.               xmlNodeIsText(attrs->children) &&

  11.               ((tn = xml_str_id(attrs->children->content)) == XML_NAME_NO ||

  12.                tn == XML_NAME_YES);

  13.   return valid;

  14. }

<CGI Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static gboolean check_where_ops(xmlNodePtr node, xmlNsPtr *nsc)

  2. {

  3.   xmlNodePtr c;

  4.   xml_name_t tn;

  5.   if(!node)

  6.     return FALSE;

  7.   for(; node; node = node->next) {

  8.     if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, nsc))

  9.       return FALSE;

  10.     c = xml_child(node);

  11.     tn = xml_tag(node);

  12.     /* comp_ops */

  13.     if(tn == XML_NAME_EQ  || tn == XML_NAME_LT || tn == XML_NAME_GT ||

  14.        tn == XML_NAME_LTE || tn == XML_NAME_GTE) {

  15.       if(!c || !c->next || c->next->next || c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  16.          c->next->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, nsc) ||

  17.          !check_ns(c->next, DAV_NS, nsc))

  18.         return FALSE;

  19.       xmlNodePtr p;

  20.       if((tn = xml_tag(c)) == XML_NAME_PROP) {

  21.         p = c;

  22.         c = c->next;

  23.         tn = xml_tag(c);

  24.       } else {

  25.         p = c->next;

  26.         if(xml_tag(p) != XML_NAME_PROP)

  27.           return FALSE;

  28.       }

  29.       if(!xml_child(p) || p->children->next || !check_prop(p, FALSE))

  30.         return FALSE;

  31.       if((xml_child(c) && (c->children->next || !xmlNodeIsText(c->children))) ||

  32.          (tn != XML_NAME_LITERAL && tn != XML_NAME_TYPED_LITERAL) ||

  33.          !check_caseless_attr(node, nsc))

  34.         return FALSE;

  35.     /* log_ops */

  36.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_AND || tn == XML_NAME_OR) {

  37.       if(!check_where_ops(c, nsc))

  38.         return FALSE;

  39.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_NOT) {

  40.       if(!c || c->next || !check_where_ops(c, nsc))

  41.         return FALSE;

  42.     /* special_ops */

  43.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_IS_COLLECTION) {

  44.       if(c)

  45.         return FALSE;

  46.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_IS_DEFINED || tn == XML_NAME_LANGUAGE_DEFINED) {

  47.       if(!c || c->next || !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, nsc) ||

  48.          !(c = xml_child(c)) || c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  49.          !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, nsc) || xml_tag(c) != XML_NAME_PROP ||

  50.          !check_prop(c, FALSE))

  51.         return FALSE;

  52.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_LANGUAGE_MATCHES) {

  53.       <Check c for prop and literal>

  54.     /* string_ops */

  55.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_LIKE) {

  56.       <Check c for prop and literal>

  57.       if(!check_caseless_attr(node, nsc))

  58.         return FALSE;

  59.     /* content_ops */

  60.     } else if(tn == XML_NAME_CONTAINS) {

  61.       if(c && (c->next || !xmlNodeIsText(c)))

  62.         return FALSE;

  63.     } else

  64.       return FALSE;

  65.   }

  66.   return TRUE;

  67. }

<Check c for prop and literal>= (<-U)

  1. if(!c || !xml_child(c) || c->children->next || !c->next ||

  2.    !xml_child(c->next) || c->next->children->next || c->next->next ||

  3.    !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, nsc) || !check_ns(c->next->next, DAV_NS, nsc))

  4.   return FALSE;

  5. if((tn = xml_tag(c)) == XML_NAME_LITERAL) {

  6.   if(!xmlNodeIsText(c->children))

  7.     return FALSE;

  8.   c = c->next;

  9.   tn = xml_tag(c);

  10. }

  11. if(tn != XML_NAME_PROP || !check_prop(c, FALSE))

  12.   return FALSE;

  13. if((c = c->next) && (xml_tag(c) != XML_NAME_LITERAL ||

  14.                      !xmlNodeIsText(c->children)))

  15.   return FALSE;

The ACL method requires an XML body with exactly one acl element.

<webdav.dtd>+= [<-D->]

  1. <!-- ACL method, required body with single acl element -->

  2. <!ELEMENT acl (ace*) >

  3.   <!ELEMENT ace ((principal | invert), (grant|deny))>

  4.     <!ELEMENT principal (href | all | authenticated | unauthenticated |

  5.                          property | self)>

  6.       <!ELEMENT all EMPTY>

  7.       <!ELEMENT authenticated EMPTY>

  8.       <!ELEMENT unauthenticated EMPTY>

  9.       <!ELEMENT property ANY>

  10.         <!-- child is exactly one property name -->

  11.       <!ELEMENT self EMPTY>

  12.     <!ELEMENT invert principal>

  13.     <!ELEMENT grant (privilege+)>

  14.     <!ELEMENT deny (privilege+)>

  15.       <!ELEMENT privilege ANY> <!-- actually, only valid empty priv tags -->

  16.         <!ELEMENT read EMPTY>

  17.         <!ELEMENT write EMPTY>

  18.         <!ELEMENT write-properties EMPTY>

  19.         <!ELEMENT write-content EMPTY>

  20.         <!ELEMENT unlock EMPTY>

  21.         <!ELEMENT read-acl EMPTY>

  22.         <!ELEMENT read-current-user-privilege-set EMPTY>

  23.         <!ELEMENT write-acl EMPTY>

  24.         <!ELEMENT bind EMPTY>

  25.         <!ELEMENT unbind EMPTY>

  26.         <!ELEMENT all EMPTY>

<XML validator names>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. acl ace principal invert grant deny all authenticated unauthenticated

  2. property self privilege read write-properties write-content unlock

  3. read-acl read-current-user-privilege-set write-acl bind unbind

<Check WebDAV XML body>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. case HTTP_REQ_ACL:

  2.   /* exactly one child element called acl, with zero or more ace children */

  3.   if(node->next || node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  4.      xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_ACL || !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  5.     valid = FALSE;

  6.   else

  7.     for(node = xml_child(node); node && valid; node = node->next) {

  8.       xmlNodePtr c;

  9.       /* 2 children: [!]principal, grant|deny */

  10.       if(node->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !(c = xml_child(node)) ||

  11.          !c->next || c->next->next || c->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  12.          c->next->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  13.          !check_ns(node, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) || xml_tag(node) != XML_NAME_ACE ||

  14.          !check_ns(c, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) || !check_ns(c->next, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  15.         valid = FALSE;

  16.       else {

  17.         gboolean got_g = FALSE;

  18.         xmlNodePtr p = NULL;

  19.         xml_name_t tn;

  20.         for(; c && valid; c = c->next) {

  21.           if(!xml_child(c))

  22.             valid = FALSE;

  23.           else if((tn = xml_tag(c)) == XML_NAME_INVERT) {

  24.             if(p || c->children->next || !xml_child(c->children) ||

  25.                c->children->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  26.                !check_ns(c->children, DAV_NS, &dav_ns) ||

  27.                xml_tag(c->children) != XML_NAME_PRINCIPAL)

  28.               valid = FALSE;

  29.             else

  30.               p = c->children->children;

  31.           } else if(tn == XML_NAME_PRINCIPAL) {

  32.             if(p)

  33.               valid = FALSE;

  34.             else

  35.               p = c->children;

  36.           } else if(tn == XML_NAME_GRANT || tn == XML_NAME_DENY) {

  37.             valid = !got_g;

  38.             got_g = TRUE;

  39.             xmlNodePtr priv;

  40.             for(priv = c->children; priv && valid; priv = priv->next)

  41.               /* each privilege tag has a single empty child tag */

  42.               /* each child tag can be anything, just like a property */

  43.               if(priv->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE || !xml_child(priv) ||

  44.                  priv->children->next || !check_prop(priv, FALSE) ||

  45.                  xml_tag(priv) != XML_NAME_PRIVILEGE ||

  46.                  !check_ns(priv, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  47.                 valid = FALSE;

  48.             continue;

  49.           } else

  50.             valid = FALSE;

  51.           if(valid) { /* finish principal processing */

  52.             if(p->next || p->type != XML_ELEMENT_NODE ||

  53.                !check_ns(p, DAV_NS, &dav_ns))

  54.               valid = FALSE;

  55.             else if((tn = xml_tag(p)) == XML_NAME_HREF)

  56.               valid = xml_child(p) && !p->children->next &&

  57.                       xmlNodeIsText(p->children);

  58.             else if(tn == XML_NAME_ALL || tn == XML_NAME_AUTHENTICATED ||

  59.                     tn == XML_NAME_UNAUTHENTICATED || tn == XML_NAME_SELF)

  60.               valid = !p->children;

  61.             else if(tn == XML_NAME_PROPERTY)

  62.               valid = xml_child(p) && !p->children->next && check_prop(p, FALSE);

  63.             else

  64.               valid = FALSE;

  65.           }

  66.         }

  67.         if(!got_g || !p)

  68.           valid = FALSE;

  69.       }

  70.     }

  71.   break;
