  15.   each:parm = CGI.SessionParms ?><?cs

  16.     call:add_session_parm("", parm, first) ?><?cs

  17.     set:first = 0 ?><?cs

  18.   /each ?><?cs

  19. /def ?><?cs

To actually set the session ID, the parameters are checked first, and if the parameters do not indicate a valid session, a new session is created. If this function is called multiple times, the session already in progress is retained with no further action.

<CGI Session Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *update_cgi_session(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr;

  4.   if(cgi_state->sessionid)

  5.     return STATUS_OK;

  6.   <Check CGI session parameters>

  7.   if(cgi_state->sessionid) {

  8.     <Verify CGI session returning STATUS_OK if OK>

  9.   }

  10.   if(cgi_state->sessionid) {

  11.     nerr = update_session_state(NULL, NULL, NULL, cgi_state); /* delete session */

  12.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  13.   }

  14.   <Create new CGI session>

  15.   return nerr;

  16. }

The session parameter can come from the cookies or the CGI parameters.

<Check CGI session parameters>= (<-U)

  1. cgi_state->sessionid = cgi_cookie_val("ses.id", NULL);

  2. if(!cgi_state->sessionid)

  3.   cgi_state->sessionid = cgi_parm_val("ses.id", NULL);

  4. if(cgi_state->sessionid) {

  5.   cgi_state->sessionid = strdup(cgi_state->sessionid);

  6.   if(!cgi_state->sessionid)

  7.     return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_NOMEM, "Session");

  8. }

  9. gboolean userid_from_session = FALSE;

  10. if(!cgi_state->userid && cgi_state->sessionid) {

  11.   cgi_state->userid = cgi_cookie_val("ses.un", NULL);

  12.   if(!cgi_state->userid)

  13.     cgi_state->userid = cgi_parm_val("ses.un", NULL);

  14.   userid_from_session = TRUE;

  15. }

To verify a session ID, the session parameters are read from the file and the user location is verified. No lock needs to be retained, because the user identification information should never change.

<Verify CGI session returning STATUS_OK if OK>= (<-U)

  1. nerr = read_session_state("Session", NULL, TRUE, cgi_state);

  2. if(nerr == STATUS_OK && !validate_session(cgi_state))

  3.   nerr = nerr_raise_msg("Invalid session");

  4. if(nerr == STATUS_OK && userid_from_session && cgi_state->userid)

  5.   nerr = cgi_env_set("CGI.RemoteUser", cgi_state->userid);

  6. if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  7.   if(debug) {

  8.     <(cs-glib.nw) Convert nerr to err_str>

  9.     cgi_puts("<pre>");

  10.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, err_str.buf, FALSE);

  11.     cgi_puts("</pre>");

  12.     string_clear(&err_str);

  13.   } else

  14.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  15.   if(cgi_state->session)

  16.     hdf_destroy(&cgi_state->session);

  17. } else

  18.   return STATUS_OK;

To create a session ID, the user location becomes the session state, and a new state is created. If the user ID changes after this, the state must be updated.

<Create new CGI session>= (<-U)

  1. if(userid_from_session)

  2.   cgi_state->userid = NULL;

  3. nerr = set_session_validation(cgi_state);

  4. if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  5.   nerr = create_session_state(cgi_state);

To destroy a session, the file is removed. No attempt is made to clear the cookies, because the fact that they are invalid will make them be ignored anyway. On the other hand, if the caller really wants to try to clear the cookies, the appropriate flag can be set.

<CGI Session Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. void logout_cgi_session(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean print_cookies)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr;

  4.   nerr = update_session_state(NULL, NULL, NULL, cgi_state);

  5.   nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  6.   if(print_cookies) {

  7.     nerr_op(cgi_cookie_clear(cgi_state->cgi, "ses.id", NULL, "/"));

  8.     nerr_op(cgi_cookie_clear(cgi_state->cgi, "ses.un", NULL, "/"));

  9.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  10.   }

  11. }

Database Session Support

Since the session support is intended to work with databases as well, a sample implementation using ODBC21

<(cs-glib.nw) Library cs-supt Members>+= [<-D->]

  1. db_session.o

<db_session.c>=

  1. <(build.nw) Common C Header>

  2. <CGI Database Session Variables>

  3. <CGI Database Session Functions>

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>+= [<-D->]

  1. #define _OBJC_OBJC_H_ 1 /* suppress iodbc BOOL */

  2. #include <sql.h>

  3. #include <sqlext.h>

<(build.nw) makefile.config>+= [<-D]

  1. # CFLAGS for ODBC

  2. ODBC_INC=

  3. # ODBC library

  4. ODBC_LIB=-lodbc

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>+= [<-D->]

  1. EXTRA_CFLAGS += $(ODBC_INC)

  2. EXTRA_LDFLAGS += $(ODBC_LIB)

In order to remain as database-neutral as possible, some efficiencies provided by various databases must be avoided. These include auto-incrementing integer fields and foreign key constraints with cascading deletes. The only feature which is required is transaction support, and even that is limited as much as possible. Also, in order to allow non-session access to the database, some database support is provided in a separate header file, and some required functions are also exported.

<dbase.h>=

  1. #ifndef _DBASE_H

  2. #define _DBASE_H

  3. <Database Support Definitions>

  4. #endif

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>+= [<-D->]

  1. #include "dbase.h"

In particular, the ODBC connection parameters are made available, along with some functions to use those parameters, assuming a local variable named conn holds a pointer to them.

<Database Support Definitions>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. typedef struct db_conn {

  2.   SQLHDBC dbc;

  3.   SQLHSTMT stmt;

  4.   <CGI Database Session Parameters>

  5. } db_conn;

<(build.nw) Known Data Types>+= [<-D->]

  1. db_conn,%

<Database Support Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #define db_exec(s)  SQLExecDirect(conn->stmt, (SQLCHAR *)s, SQL_NTS)

  2. #define db_prep(s)  SQLPrepare(conn->stmt, (SQLCHAR *)s, SQL_NTS)

  3. #define db_trans(t) SQLEndTran(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, conn->dbc, t)

  4. #define db_commit() do { \

  5.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) { \

  6.     ret = db_trans(SQL_COMMIT); \

  7.     if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) \

  8.       dbcerr = TRUE; \

  9.   } \

  10. } while(0)

  11. #define db_commit_keeperr() do { \

  12.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) \

  13.     db_commit(); \

  14.   else \

  15.     db_trans(SQL_COMMIT); \

  16. } while(0)

  17. #define db_next() SQLFreeStmt(conn->stmt, SQL_CLOSE);

  18. #define db_bind64(p, i) \

  19.   SQLBindParameter(conn->stmt, p, SQL_PARAM_INPUT, SQL_C_UBIGINT, SQL_BIGINT, \

  20.                    0, 0, &i, 0, NULL)

  21. #define db_bindsl(p, s, l) \

  22.   SQLBindParameter(conn->stmt, p, SQL_PARAM_INPUT, SQL_C_CHAR, SQL_VARCHAR, \

  23.                    l, 0, (void *)s, 0, &l)

  24. extern SQLLEN db_nullen;

  25. #define db_bindnull(p) \

  26.   SQLBindParameter(conn->stmt, p, SQL_PARAM_INPUT, SQL_C_CHAR, SQL_VARCHAR, \

  27.                    0, 0, NULL, 0, &db_nullen)

  28. #define db_binds(p, s)     (s) == NULL ? db_bindnull(p) : \

  29.   SQLBindParameter(conn->stmt, p, SQL_PARAM_INPUT, SQL_C_CHAR, SQL_VARCHAR, \

  30.                    0, 0, (void *)s, 0, NULL)

<CGI Database Session Variables>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. SQLLEN db_nullen = SQL_NULL_DATA;

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D->]

  1. SQLRETURN db_exec(const char *sql);

  2. SQLRETURN db_prep(const char *sql);

  3. SQLRETURN db_trans(SQLSMALLINT type);

  4. void db_commit(void);

  5. void db_commit_keeperr(void);

  6. SQLRETURN db_next(void);

  7. SQLRETURN db_bind64(int param, guint64 &val);

  8. SQLRETURN db_bindsl(int param, const char *str, SQLLEN len);

  9. SQLRETURN db_bindnull(int param);

  10. SQLRETURN db_binds(int param, const char *str);

In addition, debugging may be enabled. This is all session-specific and should normally not be needed, so it is enabled by compile directive.

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. #ifdef DEBUG_DBSESS

  2. SQLRETURN debug_sqlendtran(db_conn *conn, SQLSMALLINT c)

  3. {

  4.   SQLRETURN ret = SQLEndTran(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, conn->dbc, c);

  5.   SQLExecDirect(conn->stmt, (SQLCHAR *)"select * from sessval", SQL_NTS);

  6.   puts("commiting; new values:");

  7.   while(SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLFetch(conn->stmt))) {

  8.     guint64 id, parent;

  9.     char name[33];

  10.     char value[1025];

  11.     SQLLEN vallen;

  12.     SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &id, 0, NULL);

  13.     SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 2, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &parent, 0, NULL);

  14.     SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 3, SQL_C_CHAR, name, sizeof(name), NULL);

  15.     SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 4, SQL_C_CHAR, value, sizeof(value), &vallen);

  16.     if(vallen == SQL_NULL_DATA)

  17.       strcpy(value, "*NULL*");

  18.     printf("%08d %08d %32s %s\n", (int)id, (int)parent, name, value);

  19.   }

  20.   db_next();

  21.   puts("-----");

  22.   fflush(stdout);

  23.   return ret;

  24. }

  25. static SQLRETURN debug_execdirect(db_conn *conn, const SQLCHAR *s)

  26. {

  27.   printf("SQLR: %s\n", s);

  28.   fflush(stdout);

  29.   return db_exec(s);

  30. }

  31. static SQLRETURN debug_prep(db_conn *conn, const SQLCHAR *s)

  32. {

  33.   printf("SQLP: %s\n", s);

  34.   fflush(stdout);

  35.   return db_prep(s);

  36. }

  37. static SQLRETURN debug_bind(SQLHSTMT st, int n, int t2, int t3, int l,

  38.                             void *v, SQLLEN *lp)

  39. {

  40.   if(t2 == SQL_C_CHAR)

  41.     printf("bind %d: %s\n", n, v ? (char *)v : "*NULL*");

  42.   else

  43.     printf("bind %d: %llu\n", n, (ullong)*(guint64 *)v);

  44.   fflush(stdout);

  45.   return SQLBindParameter(st, n, SQL_PARAM_INPUT, t2, t3,

  46.                           l, 0, v, 0, lp);

  47. }

  48. #define SQLEndTran(a,b,c) debug_sqlendtran(conn, c)

  49. #define SQLExecDirect(st, sql, l) debug_execdirect(conn, sql)

  50. #define SQLPrepare(st, sql, l) debug_prep(conn, sql)

  51. #define SQLBindParameter(st, n, t1, t2, t3, l, p, v, ol, lp) \

  52.    debug_bind(st, n, t2, t3, l, v, lp)

  53. #endif

Creating tables is not always possible, and may require additional steps (like creating a database to store the table), so a separate script is provided. This is a sample script, and may need to be edited for the specific database to be used.

<(build.nw) Plain Files>+= [<-D->]

  1. sessdbcreate.sql \

The names for the session variables can be controlled, so leaving them at a relatively short length, such as 32, is not unreasonable. However, the values are supplied by the user, so it is not possible to force an arbitrary limit. For some databaseses, this is not an issue: they can store and manipulate strings of arbitrary length in any field. Others treat long strings as binary objects, though, and disallow searching and other forms of manipulation. For this reason a separate table is used to store extension chains for the values. Searching by value would have to be done in two steps: using the database to search on the primary table's value, and then searching the remainder manually. The database cannot be relied on to append strings of indefinite length, so it cannot be used directly. A pointer is stored to the parent record as well, to make deletes (especially with cascading) easier. This column must be created after the parent table or the reference will not get created.

<sessdbcreate.sql>= [D->]

  1. create table sessvalext (

  2.   id     bigint primary key not null unique,

  3.   ext    bigint references sessvalext on delete cascade,

  4.   -- parent bigint;

  5.   -- make this a large text field of any arbitrary type

  6.   -- probably best to use text in postgres & sqlite

  7.   value  varchar(32768) not null

  8. );

Everything is managed with one session table, since the API provides no special fields which would make a separate session table more useful. Each value has of course a name and an optional value. Children are linked in via the parent field; rather than using the name as the parent key, a separate integer id field is used. Uniqueness in the hierarchy is enforced via a uniqueness constraint on the name and parent fields, but the constraint is not relied upon.

<sessdbcreate.sql>+= [<-D->]

  1. create table sessval (

  2.   id     bigint primary key not null unique,

  3.   parent bigint not null references sessval on delete cascade,

  4.   name   varchar(32) not null,

  5.   value  varchar(126),

  6.   valext bigint references sessvalext,

  7.   unique (parent, name)

  8. );

  9. alter table sessvalext add parent bigint references sessval on delete cascade;

  10. -- create index sessval_fk on sessval (parent);

  11. -- create index sessval_uk on sessval (parent, name);

Since auto-incrementing fields are non-portable, new id values could either be the largest current value plus one, or they could come from a manually incremented field. The former enables a race condition wherein a record is identified, but before an additional operation is performed, other processess delete the record and create a new one with the same id but different values, so the latter is used. By incementing the field within a transaction, a unique identifier can be obtained every time. This does limit the total number of record insertions to the maximum integer value, but this can be alleviated by occasionally dropping and recreating the table during maintenance periods. Any database which does not support transactions of this sort cannot be used.

Rather than creating a new table with a field meant for the automatic increment function, a dummy entry is used. This could either use the value field for the counter, which would require integer-to-string conversions more frequently than necessary, or it could use the id field itself as the counter, always providing a value and then updating to the next available value. The latter option would probably be more efficient, but using the value field is easier to implement. The first value is always the root of all other entries, and its value is always the last inserted id.

The SQL requires a type cast, so the underlying data type must be known. For most databases, this will the the SQL standard bigint type. For databases which do not support this type, another type can be configured. Also, even though it is possible to query the length of the value field from ODBC, the queried length may be inaccurate, and it is easier to just get the length from configuration.

<sessdbcreate.sql>+= [<-D->]

  1. insert into sessval (id, parent, name, value) values(1,1,1,1);

<Session Value Support Configuration>= (U->)

  1. # The SQL data type used for database table keys

  2. #id_field_type = bigint

  3. # The maximum length of a session value before extension

  4. # 0 means there is no maximum

  5. #sessval_length = 126

  6. # The maximum length of an extension before further extension

  7. # 0 means there is no maximum

  8. #strext_length = 32768

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *id_field_type = "bigint";

  2. static guint64 sessval_length = 126;

  3. guint64 strext_length = 32768;

<Database Support Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. extern const char *id_field_type;

  2. extern guint64 strext_length;

<CGI Database Session Functions>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. NEOERR *db_get_next_id(db_conn *conn, const char *table, guint64 *newid)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  5.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  6.   GString *query = g_string_new("");

  7.   g_string_printf(query, "update %s set value = cast(value as %s) + 1"

  8.                          " where id = 1", table, id_field_type);

  9.   ret = db_exec(query->str);

  10.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  11.     db_next();

  12.     g_string_truncate(query, 0);

  13.     g_string_printf(query, "select value from %s where id = 1", table);

  14.     ret = db_exec(query->str);

  15.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  16.       ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  17.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  18.       ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, newid, sizeof(*newid), NULL);

  19.   }

  20.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  21.     <Set nerr for ODBC error>

  22.   }

  23.   db_next();

  24.   db_commit();

  25.   g_string_free(query, TRUE);

  26.   return nerr;

  27. }

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *create_sessval(db_conn *conn, guint64 parent, const char *name,

  2.                               const char *val, guint64 *newid)

  3. {

  4.   SQLRETURN ret;

  5.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  6.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  7.   SQLLEN vlen = val ? strlen(val) : 0, vlen_small = vlen;

  8.   if(vlen > sessval_length)

  9.     vlen_small = sessval_length;

  10.   nerr_op(db_get_next_id(conn, "sessval", newid));

  11.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  12.     return nerr;

  13.   char tname[22];

  14.   if(!name) {

  15.     sprintf(tname, ".%llu", (ullong)*newid);

  16.     name = tname;

  17.   }

  18.   ret = db_prep("insert into sessval (id, parent, name, value) "

  19.                 "values (?, ?, ?, ?)");

  20.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  21.     ret = db_bind64(1, *newid);

  22.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  23.     ret = db_bind64(2, parent);

  24.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  25.     ret = db_binds(3, name);

  26.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  27.     ret = vlen ? db_bindsl(4, val, vlen_small) : db_bindnull(4);

  28.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  29.     ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  30.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  31.     <Set nerr for ODBC error>

  32.   }

  33.   db_next();

  34.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && vlen > sessval_length) {

  35.     guint64 strext;

  36.     nerr_op(db_store_string_ext(conn, "sessvalext", *newid,

  37.                                 val + sessval_length,

  38.                                 vlen - sessval_length, &strext));

  39.     if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  40.       ret = db_prep("update sessval set valext = ? where id = ?");

  41.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  42.         ret = db_bind64(1, strext);

  43.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  44.         ret = db_bind64(2, *newid);

  45.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  46.         ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  47.       if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  48.         <Set nerr for ODBC error>

  49.       }

  50.     }

  51.   }

  52.   db_commit();

  53.   return nerr;

  54. }

Similarly, string extensions are done by using a special ID at the start of the table. Since other tables may potentially take advantage of string extentions, the actual table name is passed in as a parameter.

<sessdbcreate.sql>+= [<-D]

  1. insert into sessvalext (id, value) values(1,1);

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *db_store_string_ext(db_conn *conn, const char *table, guint64 parent,

  2.                             const char *ext, SQLLEN len, guint64 *id)

  3. {

  4.   SQLRETURN ret;

  5.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  6.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  7.   guint64 strext = 0;

  8.   if(len > strext_length) {

  9.     nerr_op(db_store_string_ext(conn, table, parent, ext + strext_length,

  10.                                 len - strext_length, &strext));

  11.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  12.       return nerr;

  13.     len = strext_length;

  14.   }

  15.   nerr_op(db_get_next_id(conn, table, id));

  16.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  17.     GString *query = g_string_new("");

  18.     g_string_printf(query, "insert into %s (id, ext, parent, value) "

  19.                            "values (?, ?, ?, ?)", table);

  20.     ret = db_prep(query->str);

  21.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  22.       ret = db_bind64(1, *id);

  23.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  24.       if(strext)

  25.         ret = db_bind64(2, strext);

  26.       else

  27.         ret = db_bindnull(2);

  28.     }

  29.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  30.       db_bind64(3, parent);

  31.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  32.       ret = db_bindsl(4, ext, len);

  33.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  34.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  35.     if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  36.       <Set nerr for ODBC error>

  37.     }

  38.     db_next();

  39.     db_commit();

  40.   }

  41.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK && strext)

  42.     db_delete_strext(conn, table, strext);

  43.   return nerr;

  44. }

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void db_delete_strext(db_conn *conn, const char *table, guint64 strext)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret = 0;

  4.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  5.   guint64 strext_next = 0;

  6.   GString *query1 = g_string_new(""), *query2 = g_string_new("");

  7.   g_string_printf(query1, "select id from %s where ext = ?", table);

  8.   g_string_printf(query2, "delete from %s where id = ?", table);

  9.   while(strext) {

  10.     if(!dbcascade) {

  11.       ret = db_prep(query1->str);

  12.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  13.         ret = db_bind64(1, strext);

  14.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  15.         ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  16.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  17.         ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  18.         if(ret == SQL_NO_DATA) {

  19.           ret = SQL_SUCCESS;

  20.           strext_next = 0;

  21.         } else if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  22.           SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &strext_next,

  23.                      sizeof(strext_next), NULL);

  24.       }

  25.       db_next();

  26.     }

  27.     ret = db_prep(query2->str);

  28.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  29.       ret = db_bind64(1, strext);

  30.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  31.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  32.     db_next();

  33.     strext = strext_next;

  34.   }

  35.   g_string_free(query1, TRUE);

  36.   g_string_free(query2, TRUE);

  37.   db_commit();

  38. }

Connecting to the database is then just a matter of providing the correct connection string. This can include user ID and password, so only one configuration parameter is needed.

<CGI Database Session Support Configuration>= (U-> U->) [D->]

  1. # ODBC Database connection string; blank to disable

  2. # Format is generally DSN=<dsn>[; UID=<username>; PWD=<password>]

  3. # Or apparently also FILEDSN=<filename>

  4. #dbconnect =

  5. <Session Value Support Configuration>

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static SQLHENV henv = SQL_NULL_HENV;

  2. static const char *dbconnect = NULL;

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void init_db_cgi_session(void)

  2. {

  3.   <Set up database connection>

  4. }

<Set up database connection>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. SQLRETURN ret;

  2. dbconnect = getconf("dbconnect", NULL);

  3. if(!dbconnect || !*dbconnect)

  4.   return;

  5. /* use connection pool */

  6. ret = SQLSetEnvAttr(SQL_NULL_HANDLE, SQL_ATTR_CONNECTION_POOLING,

  7.                                      (SQLPOINTER)SQL_CP_ONE_PER_DRIVER, 0);

  8. <Ignore ODBC ret>

  9. ret = SQLAllocHandle(SQL_HANDLE_ENV, SQL_NULL_HANDLE, &henv);

  10. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  11.   ret = SQLSetEnvAttr(henv, SQL_ATTR_ODBC_VERSION,

  12.                             (SQLPOINTER)SQL_OV_ODBC3, 0);

  13. if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  14.   <Print ODBC env error>

  15.   exit(1);

  16. }

  17. id_field_type = getconf("id_field_type", id_field_type);

  18. sessval_length = getconf_int("sessval_length", sessval_length);

  19. strext_length = getconf_int("strext_length", strext_length);

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *open_db(db_conn *conn)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret;

  4.   if(!dbconnect || !*dbconnect)

  5.     return nerr_raise_msg("No database connection string specified");

  6.   ret = SQLAllocHandle(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, henv, &conn->dbc);

  7.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  8.     ret = SQLDriverConnect(conn->dbc, 0, (SQLCHAR *)dbconnect, SQL_NTS, NULL,

  9.                            0, NULL, SQL_DRIVER_NOPROMPT);

  10.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  11.     /* use explicit commit */

  12.     ret = SQLSetConnectAttr(conn->dbc, SQL_AUTOCOMMIT,

  13.                                        (SQLPOINTER)SQL_AUTOCOMMIT_OFF,

  14.                                        SQL_IS_INTEGER);

  15.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  16.       ret = SQLAllocHandle(SQL_HANDLE_STMT, conn->dbc, &conn->stmt);

  17.   }

  18.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  19.     return STATUS_OK;

  20.   <Return converted ODBC error>

  21. }

  22. void close_db(db_conn *conn)

  23. {

  24.   if(conn->stmt) {

  25.     SQLCancel(conn->stmt);

  26.     db_next();

  27.     SQLFreeHandle(SQL_HANDLE_STMT, conn->stmt);

  28.   }

  29.   if(conn->dbc) {

  30.     SQLEndTran(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, conn->dbc, SQL_ROLLBACK);

  31.     SQLFreeHandle(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, conn->dbc);

  32.   }

  33.   memset(conn, 0, sizeof(*conn));

  34. }

ODBC has its own error reporting mechanism. Errors are not accumulated between calls; instead they are stored in the various handles. Fortunately, there is no need to explicitly free them. A function is required to gather all the parts of the message together, though. Some versions of unixODBC crash when retrieving anything but the first message when used with sqliteodbc. Since I can't research what versions may cause problems, the loop is stopped after the first iteration with any unixODBC version.

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *odbc_msg(SQLSMALLINT htype, SQLHANDLE h)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret = SQL_SUCCESS;

  4.   static pthread_mutex_t lock = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER;

  5.   static SQLCHAR state[7];

  6.   SQLINTEGER rc;

  7.   static SQLCHAR msg[1024];

  8.   SQLSMALLINT len;

  9.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  10.   int i;

  11.   pthread_mutex_lock(&lock);

  12.   for(i = 1; SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret); i++) {

  13.     ret = SQLGetDiagRec(htype, h, i, state, &rc, msg, sizeof(msg), &len);

  14.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  15.       nerr = nerr == STATUS_OK ?

  16.           nerr_raise(GENERIC_ERR, "ODBC[%d-%s]: %s", rc, state, msg) :

  17.           nerr_pass_ctx(nerr, "ODBC[%d-%s]: %s", rc, state, msg);

  18. #ifdef SQL_ATTR_UNIXODBC_VERSION

  19.     break;

  20. #endif

  21.   }

  22.   pthread_mutex_unlock(&lock);

  23.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  24.     nerr = nerr_raise(GENERIC_ERR, "Unknown ODBC error");

  25.   return nerr;

  26. }

<Database Support Definitions>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. #define db_err(dbcerr) nerr_pass(odbc_msg(dbcerr ? SQL_HANDLE_DBC : \

  2.                                                    SQL_HANDLE_STMT, \

  3.                                           dbcerr ? conn->dbc : conn->stmt))

<(build.nw) C Prototypes>+= [<-D]

  1. NEOERR *db_err(gboolean dbcerr);

<Ignore ODBC ret>= (<-U)

  1. ret = SQL_SUCCESS;

<Print ODBC env error>= (<-U)

  1. die_if_err(nerr_pass(odbc_msg(SQL_HANDLE_ENV, henv)));

<Return converted ODBC error>= (<-U)

  1. return db_err(!conn->stmt);

<Set nerr for ODBC error>= (<-U <-U <-U U->)

  1. nerr = db_err(dbcerr);

In addition to calling the initialization functions, the individual session operations must be defined and overridden. If they are already overridden, the session initialization does nothing.

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *db_create_session(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  4.   <Create session using database>

  5.   return nerr;

  6. }

  7. static NEOERR *db_read_session(const char *name, const char *child,

  8.                                HDF *target, gboolean recursive,

  9.                                cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  10. {

  11.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  12.   <Read session using database>

  13.   return nerr;

  14. }

  15. static NEOERR *db_update_session(const char *root_name, HDF *root,

  16.                                  HDF **unique_root, cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  17. {

  18.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  19.   <Update session using database>

  20.   return nerr;

  21. }

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static cgi_cleanup_cb prev_cleanup;

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. NEOERR *prepare_db_session(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  4.   if(henv != SQL_NULL_HENV && !cgi_state->session_cb_data) {

  5.     cgi_state->session_cb_data = calloc(1, sizeof(db_conn));

  6.     if(!cgi_state->session_cb_data)

  7.       return nerr_raise_errno(NERR_NOMEM, "Session support");

  8.     nerr = open_db(cgi_state->session_cb_data);

  9.     if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  10.       cgi_state->create_session = db_create_session;

  11.       cgi_state->read_session = db_read_session;

  12.       cgi_state->update_session = db_update_session;

  13.       prev_cleanup = cgi_state->cleanup;

  14.       cgi_state->cleanup = finish_db_session;

  15.     } else {

  16.       close_db(cgi_state->session_cb_data);

  17.       free(cgi_state->session_cb_data);

  18.       cgi_state->session_cb_data = NULL;

  19.     }

  20.   }

  21.   return nerr;

  22. }

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. void finish_db_session(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   close_db(cgi_state->session_cb_data);

  4.   cgi_state->create_session = NULL;

  5.   cgi_state->read_session = NULL;

  6.   cgi_state->update_session = NULL;

  7.   cgi_state->session_cb_data = NULL;

  8.   if(prev_cleanup)

  9.     (*prev_cleanup)(cgi_state);

  10. }

A session is created by adding a new child of the root, and relying on the uniqueness constraint on the name to ensure that a unique name is generated. This is done by updating the name to a new random name until the uniqueness constraint has been satisfied. Session names are similar to the file mode: a date stamp followed by a few random printable characters. There is no need to put a great deal of effort into making this secure; the GLib thread-safe global random number generator is used for this.

<CGI Database Session Parameters>= (<-U)

  1. guint64 root_id;

<Create session using database>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. char sessid[2+8+6+1];

  2. guint64 newid;

  3. db_conn *conn = cgi_state->session_cb_data;

  4. SQLRETURN ret;

  5. gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  6. nerr_op(create_sessval(conn, 1, NULL, NULL, &newid));

  7. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  8.   return nerr;

  9. while(1) {

  10.   int i;

  11.   char c;

  12.   time_t now;

  13.   time(&now);

  14.   sprintf(sessid, "CS%08X", (int)now);

  15.   for(i = 0; i < 6; i++) {

  16.     do {

  17.       c = g_random_int_range(48, 122);

  18.     } while(!isalnum(c));

  19.     sessid[i + 10] = c;

  20.   }

  21.   sessid[16] = 0;

  22.   ret = db_prep("update sessval set name = ? where id = ?");

  23.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  24.     return db_err(FALSE);

  25.   ret = db_binds(1, sessid);

  26.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  27.     ret = db_bind64(2, newid);

  28.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  29.     char code[7];

  30.     ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  31.     if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret) &&

  32.        SQLGetDiagField(SQL_HANDLE_STMT, conn->stmt, 1, SQL_DIAG_SQLSTATE,

  33.                        code, sizeof(code), NULL) == SQL_SUCCESS &&

  34.        !strcmp(code, "23000")) { /* 23000 == integrity constraint */

  35.       db_next();

  36.       continue;

  37.     }

  38.   }

  39.   db_commit();

  40.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  41.     <Set nerr for ODBC error>

  42.   }

  43.   db_next();

  44.   break;

  45. }

  46. conn->root_id = newid;

  47. cgi_state->sessionid = g_strdup(sessid);

Rather than always using the sesion name to find an ID, the root is stored in the state as soon as it is known. If the session is newly created, it is known after creation. Otherwise, it needs to be queried.

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *set_root_id(db_conn *conn, const char *name)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr;

  5.   if(conn->root_id)

  6.     return STATUS_OK;

  7.   ret = db_prep("select id from sessval where name = ? and parent = 1");

  8.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  9.     ret = db_binds(1, name);

  10.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  11.     ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  12.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  13.     ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  14.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  15.     ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &conn->root_id,

  16.                      sizeof(conn->root_id), NULL);

  17.   nerr = SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret) ? STATUS_OK : db_err(FALSE);

  18.   db_next();

  19.   return nerr;

  20. }

<Read session using database>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. db_conn *conn = cgi_state->session_cb_data;

  2. nerr = set_root_id(conn, cgi_state->sessionid);

  3. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  4.   return nerr;

<Update session using database>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. db_conn *conn = cgi_state->session_cb_data;

  2. nerr = set_root_id(conn, cgi_state->sessionid);

  3. if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  4.   if(!root)

  5.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  6.   return nerr;

  7. }

Reading a value from the session requires following the hierarchical path. When searching for a single value, no recursion is necessary. If only a partial path is found, and the remander should still be created, partial can be non-NULL to point to what still needs to be created. Otherwise, a zero id indicates that it was not found.

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *db_nodeid(db_conn *conn, guint64 root, const char *name,

  2.                          guint64 *id, const char **partial)

  3. {

  4.   char *s, *e;

  5.   SQLRETURN ret;

  6.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  7.   char *modname;

  8.   *id = root;

  9.   if(!name || !*name)

  10.     return STATUS_OK;

  11.   if(*name == '.')

  12.     return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid node name");

  13.   modname = s = strdup(name);

  14.   if(!modname)

  15.     return nerr_raise_msg_errno("No memory for scan");

  16.   while(1) {

  17.     e = strchr(s, '.');

  18.     if(e)

  19.       *e = 0;

  20.     ret = db_prep("select id from sessval where parent = ? and name = ?");

  21.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  22.       ret = db_bind64(1, *id);

  23.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  24.       ret = db_binds(2, s);

  25.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  26.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  27.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  28.       ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  29.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  30.       ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, id, sizeof(*id), NULL);

  31.     else if(ret == SQL_NO_DATA) {

  32.       db_next();

  33.       if(partial)

  34.         *partial = name + (int)(s - modname);

  35.       else

  36.         *id = 0;

  37.       free(modname);

  38.       return STATUS_OK;

  39.     }

  40.     if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  41.       nerr = db_err(FALSE);

  42.       db_next();

  43.       free(modname);

  44.       return nerr;

  45.     }

  46.     db_next();

  47.     if(!e)

  48.       break;

  49.     s = e + 1;

  50.     if(!*s || *s == '.') {

  51.       free(modname);

  52.       return nerr_raise_msg("Invalid node name");

  53.     }

  54.   }

  55.   free(modname);

  56.   return STATUS_OK;

  57. }

Immediate recursion is not possible when sharing a single statement handle, so recursion is done by following the HDF after reading. The HDF routines will be allocating strings and other information anyway, so only a single shared buffer is used to read the values. Each call reads only a single value and the names of all of the children. In order to emulate the non-recursive read mode, a counter is passed in to indicate the maximum recursion depth, if non-negative.

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *db_readtree(db_conn *conn, guint64 root, const char *name,

  2.                            HDF *hdf, int recurse, GString **_buf)

  3. {

  4.   SQLRETURN ret;

  5.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  6.   GString *buf = NULL;

  7.   if(name) {

  8.     nerr = db_nodeid(conn, root, name, &root, NULL);

  9.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK || !root)

  10.       return nerr;

  11.   }

  12.   if(!_buf) {

  13.     _buf = &buf;

  14.     buf = g_string_sized_new(80);

  15.   }

  16.   <Set hdf's value from database>

  17.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && recurse) {

  18.     <Insert children of hdf from database>

  19.   }

  20.   if(buf)

  21.     g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  22.   return nerr;

  23. }

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. SQLRETURN SQLGetGString(HSTMT *stmt, int pno, GString *buf)

  2. {

  3.   SQLLEN lenret;

  4.   SQLRETURN ret;

  5.   ret = SQLGetData(stmt, 1, SQL_C_CHAR, buf->str + buf->len,

  6.                    buf->allocated_len - buf->len, &lenret);

  7.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  8.     return ret;

  9.   if(lenret != SQL_NULL_DATA) {

  10.     if(lenret + buf->len > buf->allocated_len - 1) {

  11.       int olen = buf->allocated_len - 1 - buf->len;

  12.       g_string_set_size(buf, lenret + buf->len + 1);

  13.       ret = SQLGetData(stmt, 1, SQL_C_CHAR, buf->str + olen,

  14.                        buf->allocated_len - olen, NULL);

  15.     }

  16.     buf->len += lenret;

  17.   }

  18.   return SQL_SUCCESS;

  19. }

<Set hdf's value from database>= (<-U)

  1. ret = db_prep("select value, valext from sessval where id = ?");

  2. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  3.   ret = db_bind64(1, root);

  4. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  5.   ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  6. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  7.   ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  8. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  9.   guint64 extid;

  10.   SQLLEN lenret;

  11.   g_string_truncate(*_buf, 0);

  12.   ret = SQLGetGString(conn->stmt, 1, *_buf);

  13.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  14.     ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 2, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &extid, sizeof(extid),

  15.                      &lenret);

  16.     while(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret) && lenret != SQL_NULL_DATA) {

  17.       db_next();

  18.       ret = db_prep("select value, ext from sessvalext where id = ?");

  19.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  20.         ret = db_bind64(1, extid);

  21.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  22.         ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  23.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  24.         ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  25.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  26.         ret = SQLGetGString(conn->stmt, 1, *_buf);

  27.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  28.         ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 2, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &extid, sizeof(extid),

  29.                          &lenret);

  30.     }

  31.   }

  32.   if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  33.     nerr = db_err(FALSE);

  34.   else if((*_buf)->len)

  35.     nerr = hdf_set_value(hdf, NULL, (*_buf)->str);

  36. } else if(ret != SQL_NO_DATA)

  37.   nerr = db_err(FALSE);

  38. db_next();

<Insert children of hdf from database>= (<-U)

  1. HDF *c;

  2. ret = db_prep("select name from sessval where parent = ?");

  3. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  4.   ret = db_bind64(1, root);

  5. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  6.   ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  7. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  8.   while(1) {

  9.     ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  10.     if(ret == SQL_NO_DATA) {

  11.       ret = SQL_SUCCESS;

  12.       break;

  13.     }

  14.     g_string_truncate(*_buf, 0);

  15.     ret = SQLGetGString(conn->stmt, 1, *_buf);

  16.     if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  17.       break;

  18.     nerr = hdf_get_node(hdf, (*_buf)->str, &c);

  19.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  20.       break;

  21.   }

  22. }

  23. if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  24.   nerr = db_err(FALSE);

  25. db_next();

  26. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  27.   return nerr;

  28. for(c = hdf_obj_child(hdf); c; c = hdf_obj_next(c))

  29.   db_readtree(conn, root, hdf_obj_name(c), c,

  30.               recurse > 0 ? recurse - 1 : recurse, _buf);

Since the wrapper already clears the HDF as needed, the reader now only needs to call the recursive function to read the database.

<Read session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. guint64 root_id = conn->root_id;

  2. if(child) {

  3.   nerr = db_nodeid(conn, root_id, name, &root_id, NULL);

  4.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK || !root_id)

  5.     return nerr;

  6.   name = child;

  7. }

  8. nerr = db_readtree(conn, root_id, name, target, recursive ? -1 : 1, NULL);

  9. if(!name)

  10.   cgi_state->session = target;

  11. if(debug) {

  12.   cgi_printf("<pre>Read Session %s:\n", name ? name : cgi_state->sessionid);

  13.   STRING ps;

  14.   string_init(&ps);

  15.   nerr = hdf_dump_str(target, "", 2, &ps);

  16.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && ps.buf)

  17.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, ps.buf, FALSE);

  18.   else

  19.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  20.   string_clear(&ps);

  21.   cgi_puts("--------\n</pre>\n");

  22. }

Updating consists both of inserting new values and removing old values. The simpler of the two is removal, so that is covered first. With cascade deletes, no recursion is necessary. Since cascade deletes cannot be guaranteed, the deletion function recurses by reading an array of child IDs from the database, and then deleting those before trying to delete the current node. It first changes the name of the node being operated on to avoid additional nodes being created mid-operation. This still isn't guaranteed to work; this code will always have a small race condition when deleting nodes. For a small potential relief of this, the node is renamed before deletion. Its ID could still already be read into another process, though, so this is not a complete cure.

<CGI Database Session Support Configuration>+= (U-> U->) [<-D]

  1. # Set to non-blank if the CGI session table supports cascading deletes

  2. #dbcascade =

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static gboolean dbcascade = FALSE;

<Set up database connection>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(*getconf("dbcascade", ""))

  2.   dbcascade = TRUE;

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static NEOERR *destroy_node(db_conn *conn, guint64 root_id)

  2. {

  3.   SQLRETURN ret;

  4.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  5.   gboolean did_delete;

  6.   while(1) {

  7.     if(!dbcascade) {

  8.       /* rename to reduce chance of problems (ignore error) */

  9.       char tname[22];

  10.       sprintf(tname, ".%llu", (ullong)root_id);

  11.       ret = db_prep("update sessval set name = ? where id = ?");

  12.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  13.         ret = db_binds(1, tname);

  14.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  15.         ret = db_bind64(2, root_id);

  16.       if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  17.         ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  18.       db_next()

  19.     }

  20.     ret = db_prep("delete from sessval where id = ?");

  21.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  22.       ret = db_bind64(1, root_id);

  23.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  24.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  25.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  26.       db_next();

  27.       if(dbcascade) {

  28.         db_commit();

  29.         return STATUS_OK;

  30.       }

  31.       did_delete = TRUE;

  32.     }

  33.     if(dbcascade) {

  34.       NEOERR *nerr = db_err(FALSE);

  35.       db_next();

  36.       return nerr;

  37.     }

  38.     db_next();

  39.     ret = db_prep("delete from sessvalext where parent = ?");

  40.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  41.       ret = db_bind64(1, root_id);

  42.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  43.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  44.     db_next();

  45.     GArray *children = g_array_new(FALSE, FALSE, sizeof(guint64));

  46.     ret = db_prep("select id from sessval where parent = ?");

  47.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  48.       ret = db_bind64(1, root_id);

  49.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  50.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  51.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  52.       while(1) {

  53.         guint64 cid;

  54.         ret = SQLFetch(conn->stmt);

  55.         if(ret == SQL_NO_DATA) {

  56.           ret = SQL_SUCCESS;

  57.           break;

  58.         }

  59.         if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  60.           break;

  61.         ret = SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &cid, sizeof(cid), NULL);

  62.         if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  63.           break;

  64.         g_array_append_val(children, cid);

  65.       }

  66.       db_next();

  67.     }

  68.     while(children->len) {

  69.       destroy_node(conn, g_array_index(children, guint64, children->len - 1));

  70.       g_array_remove_index(children, children->len - 1);

  71.     }

  72.     g_array_free(children, TRUE);

  73.     if(did_delete) {

  74.       db_commit();

  75.       return STATUS_OK;

  76.     }

  77.   }

  78. }

<Update session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(!root) {

  2.   guint64 root_id;

  3.   nerr = db_nodeid(conn, conn->root_id, root_name, &root_id, NULL);

  4.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK || !root_id)

  5.     return nerr;

  6.   return destroy_node(conn, root_id);

  7. }

Inserting requires deleting first as well, but first the root node for insertion must be found and possibly created. This creates another race condition wherein other readers may try to read an incomplete entry. This race condition is alleviated by using a temporary name for the new node(s), and even parenting it to one, until it is ready to be linked into the whole. Any unneeded new nodes after all have been inserted can simply be deleted. As a shortcut, an attempt is made to directly update a node without children; if this fails, then the long-form insertion procedure is followed.

<Update session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. SQLRETURN ret;

  2. if(!hdf_obj_child(root)) {

  3.   guint64 udn;

  4.   SQLLEN nrows;

  5.   const char *val = hdf_obj_value(root);

  6.   if(val && !*val)

  7.     val = NULL;

  8.   if((!val || strlen(val) <= sessval_length) &&

  9.      nerr_op_ok(db_nodeid(conn, conn->root_id, root_name, &udn, NULL)) && udn) {

  10.     ret = db_prep("delete from sessvalext where parent = ?");

  11.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  12.       ret = db_bind64(1, udn);

  13.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  14.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  15.     db_next();

  16.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  17.       ret = db_prep("update sessval set value = ? where id = ? and name = ?");

  18.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  19.       ret = db_binds(1, val);

  20.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  21.       ret = db_bind64(2, udn);

  22.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  23.       val = strrchr(root_name, '.');

  24.       if(!val)

  25.         val = root_name;

  26.       else

  27.         val = val + 1;

  28.       ret = db_binds(3, val);

  29.     }

  30.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  31.       ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  32.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret) &&

  33.        SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLRowCount(conn->stmt, &nrows)) &&

  34.        nrows == 1) {

  35.       db_next();

  36.       db_trans(SQL_COMMIT);

  37.       return STATUS_OK;

  38.     }

  39.   }

  40. }

The top node is the only one that is treated specially; all others can be inserted below it recursively without worrying about anything being yanked out in mid-stream. If the insertion point is the root node, a new session is being created, so there is also no need for any extra hoop jumping.

<CGI Database Session Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. static NEOERR *insert_children(db_conn *conn, guint64 id, HDF *hdf)

  2. {

  3.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  4.   guint64 cid;

  5.   for(hdf = hdf_obj_child(hdf); hdf; hdf = hdf_obj_next(hdf)) {

  6.     nerr_op(create_sessval(conn, id, hdf_obj_name(hdf), hdf_obj_value(hdf),

  7.                            &cid));

  8.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  9.       return nerr;

  10.     if(hdf_obj_child(hdf)) {

  11.       nerr = insert_children(conn, cid, hdf);

  12.       if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  13.         return nerr;

  14.     }

  15.   }

  16.   return STATUS_OK;

  17. }

<Update session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. guint64 inserted_vals;

  2. if(root_name) {

  3.   nerr_op(create_sessval(conn, 1, NULL, hdf_obj_value(root), &inserted_vals));

  4.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  5.     return nerr;

  6. } else

  7.   inserted_vals = conn->root_id;

  8. nerr = insert_children(conn, inserted_vals, root);

  9. if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  10.   NEOERR *nerr2 = destroy_node(conn, inserted_vals);

  11.   nerr_ignore(&nerr2);

  12.   return nerr;

  13. }

  14. if(!root_name)

  15.   return nerr;

<Create session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  2.   nerr = insert_children(conn, conn->root_id, cgi_state->session);

  3. if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  4.   NEOERR *nerr2 = destroy_node(conn, conn->root_id);

  5.   nerr_ignore(&nerr2);

  6. }

The actual insertion is done by scanning for the insertion point, and inserting. This leaves open a race where a hierarchy could be in the process of being deleted as it is scanned; this is bypassed by placing the scan in a loop and ensuring that the name does not change while it is being updated.

<Update session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. GString *buf = g_string_sized_new(80);

  2. while(1) {

  3.   guint64 lastroot;

  4.   const char *createstr, *s = NULL, *e; /* s init to shut gcc up */

  5.   gboolean dbcerr = FALSE;

  6.   nerr = db_nodeid(conn, conn->root_id, root_name, &lastroot, &createstr);

  7.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  8.     NEOERR *nerr2 = destroy_node(conn, inserted_vals);

  9.     nerr_ignore(&nerr2);

  10.     g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  11.     return nerr;

  12.   }

  13.   if(!createstr && !unique_root) {

  14.     nerr = destroy_node(conn, lastroot);

  15.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  16.     continue;

  17.   }

  18.   if(createstr) {

  19.     for(s = createstr; (e = strchr(s, '.')); s = e + 1) {

  20.       g_string_truncate(buf, 0);

  21.       g_string_append_len(buf, s, (int)(e - s));

  22.       nerr_op(create_sessval(conn, lastroot, buf->str, NULL, &lastroot));

  23.       if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  24.         break;

  25.     }

  26.     if(nerr == STATUS_OK && unique_root)

  27.       nerr_op(create_sessval(conn, lastroot, s, NULL, &lastroot));

  28.   }

  29.   char unbuf[22];

  30.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && unique_root) {

  31.     sprintf(unbuf, "%llu", (ullong)inserted_vals);

  32.     s = unbuf;

  33.   }

  34.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  35.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  36.     continue;

  37.   }

  38.   ret = db_prep("update sessval set parent = ? where id = ?");

  39.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  40.     ret = db_bind64(1, lastroot);

  41.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  42.     ret = db_bind64(2, inserted_vals);

  43.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  44.     ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  45.   db_next();

  46.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  47.     ret = db_prep("update sessval set name = ? where id = ?");

  48.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  49.     ret = db_binds(1, s);

  50.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  51.     ret = db_bind64(2, inserted_vals);

  52.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  53.     ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  54.   db_next();

  55.   if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  56.     db_commit();

  57.     return STATUS_OK;

  58.   }

  59.   SQLEndTran(SQL_HANDLE_DBC, conn->dbc, SQL_ROLLBACK);

  60.   sleep(1);

  61. }

Like almost everything else, cleaning up old sessions is much harder than with the simple files. The expiration date needs to be stored somewhere, for one. The value for the session root is a convenient, currently unused spot. The database itself cannot be relied upon to do proper date translation, so all operations with this date stamp must use the raw number of seconds since the UNIX epoch. Since the root session is always read before updating, only root reads and creates will update this timestamp.

<Read session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(!name && nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  2.   SQLRETURN ret;

  3.   <Update root timestamp in database>

  4. }

<Create session using database>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. <Update root timestamp in database>

<Update root timestamp in database>= (<-U <-U)

  1. guint64 tval;

  2. time_t now;

  3. time(&now);

  4. tval = (guint64)now;

  5. ret = db_prep("update sessval set value = ? where id = ?");

  6. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  7.   ret = db_bind64(1, tval);

  8. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  9.   ret = db_bind64(2, conn->root_id);

  10. if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  11.   ret = SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  12. db_next();

  13. db_trans(SQL_COMMIT);

To clean up then, is to search for root nodes with an old timestamp. Root nodes without any timestamp may be left-over garbage as well, so if these are found two scans in a row, they are removed as well. It is still possible that two scans complete before a temporary node is used correctly, but it is sufficiently unlikely that no additional effort will be made to correct this race condition.

<(build.nw) C Executables>+= [<-D]

  1. delete_old_db_sessions \

<delete_old_db_sessions.c>=

  1. <(build.nw) Common C Header>

  2. const char *config_root = "/etc";

  3. const char *config_path = "db_session.conf";

  4. <(cs-glib.nw) Help Function>

  5. SQLHENV henv;

  6. const char *dbconnect;

  7. int main(int argc, const char **argv)

  8. {

  9.   <(cs-glib.nw) Common Mainline Variables>

  10.   <(cs-glib.nw) Read configuration>

  11.   clean_db_sessions();

  12.   return 0;

  13. }

<delete_old_db_sessions Description>=

  1. Keep session table clean

<delete_old_db_sessions Configuration>=

  1. <CGI Database Session Support Configuration>

  2. # How long to wait before next expired session check (seconds)

  3. #clean_interval=60

  4. # How long to wait before expiring sessions (seconds)

  5. #expire_time=1200

<CGI Database Session Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. void clean_db_sessions(void)

  2. {

  3.   db_conn _conn, *conn;

  4.   NEOERR *nerr;

  5.   SQLRETURN ret;

  6.   int interval = getconf_int("clean_interval", 60);

  7.   int expire_time = getconf_int("expire_time", 20*60);

  8.   GArray *null_ids = NULL, *del_ids = NULL;

  9.   if(expire_time < 0)

  10.     expire_time = 0;

  11.   if(interval > expire_time)

  12.     interval = expire_time;

  13.   if(interval < 5)

  14.     interval = 5;

  15.   init_db_cgi_session();

  16.   if(henv == SQL_NULL_HENV)

  17.     die_msg("Specify a database connection string");

  18.   conn = &_conn;

  19.   memset(conn, 0, sizeof(*conn));

  20.   die_if_err(open_db(conn));

  21.   GString *query = g_string_new("");

  22.   g_string_printf(query, "%s from sessval " \

  23.                       "where parent = 1 and id <> 1 and value is not null " \

  24.                         "and cast(value as %s) < ?",

  25.                   dbcascade ? "delete" : "select id", id_field_type);

  26.   while(1) {

  27.     time_t now;

  28.     guint64 exp_ts;

  29.     time(&now);

  30.     exp_ts = now - expire_time;

  31.     ret = db_prep(query->str);

  32.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  33.       ret = db_bind64(1, exp_ts);

  34.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret))

  35.       SQLExecute(conn->stmt);

  36.     if(!dbcascade && SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  37.       guint64 id;

  38.       while(SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLFetch(conn->stmt))) {

  39.         if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &id,

  40.                                      sizeof(id), NULL)))

  41.           continue;

  42.         if(!del_ids)

  43.           del_ids = g_array_new(FALSE, FALSE, sizeof(guint64));

  44.         g_array_append_val(del_ids, id);

  45.       }

  46.       db_next();

  47.       if(del_ids)

  48.         while(del_ids->len) {

  49.           id = g_array_index(del_ids, guint64, del_ids->len - 1);

  50.           g_array_remove_index(del_ids, del_ids->len - 1);

  51.           nerr = destroy_node(conn, id);

  52.           nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  53.         }

  54.     } else

  55.       db_next();

  56.     ret = db_exec("select id from sessval where parent = 1 and value is null");

  57.     if(SQL_SUCCEEDED(ret)) {

  58.       GArray *prev_null_ids = null_ids;

  59.       guint64 id;

  60.       null_ids = NULL;

  61.       while(SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLFetch(conn->stmt))) {

  62.         if(!SQL_SUCCEEDED(SQLGetData(conn->stmt, 1, SQL_C_UBIGINT, &id,

  63.                                      sizeof(id), NULL)))

  64.           continue;

  65.         if(!null_ids)

  66.           null_ids = g_array_new(FALSE, FALSE, sizeof(guint64));

  67.         g_array_append_val(null_ids, id);

  68.       }

  69.       db_next();

  70.       if(prev_null_ids && null_ids) {

  71.         int i, j;

  72.         for(i = 0; i < null_ids->len; i++) {

  73.           id = g_array_index(null_ids, guint64, i);

  74.           for(j = 0; j < prev_null_ids->len; j++)

  75.             if(id == g_array_index(prev_null_ids, guint64, j)) {

  76.               nerr = destroy_node(conn, id);

  77.               g_array_remove_index_fast(prev_null_ids, j);

  78.               if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  79.                 g_array_remove_index_fast(null_ids, i);

  80.                 i--;

  81.               }

  82.               nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  83.               break;

  84.             }

  85.         }

  86.       }

  87.       if(prev_null_ids)

  88.         g_array_free(prev_null_ids, TRUE);

  89.     } else

  90.       db_next();

  91.     sleep(interval);

  92.   }

  93. }

CAS Authentication

The Central Authentication Service (CAS) is in use at Indiana Univeristy for university-wide login. CAS uses a single web server for authentication of other web sites. IU's CAS conforms mostly to version 1 of the protocol22; the only known issue is that the service parameter cannot be URL-encoded. The IU server also takes an additional parameter (cas_svc) to indicate the authentication realm.

There is an Apache module for CAS authentication, but it shares many of the limitations of CAS itself. The primary limitation is that CAS does not support POST parameters. If authentcation fails during a POST request, all parameters are lost. The CAS module is also marked as deprecated on the official CAS site.

Instead, code provided here will save the CGI parameters in the session state and restore them when CAS returns. This still loses uploads, as saving the uploaded file in the session state would only work for very small file uploads. Also, clients that issue requests other than GET, HEAD, and POST may be confused by the redirection, so these are not supported, either. However, it does help the most common case. In addition, it is possible to query the status of CAS authentication without forcing the authentication to take place, so that can be used for the unsupported methods and uploads before simply rejecting the request.

<CAS Support Configuration>= (U->) [D->]

  1. # The CAS server URL; must end in a slash

  2. # CAS is disabled if this is blank.

  3. #cas_url =

  4. # The CAS service type

  5. # This is not used if blank

  6. #cas_svc =

<cas.c>=

  1. <(build.nw) Common C Header>

  2. static const char *cas_url;

  3. static const char *cas_svc;

  4. <CAS Support Variables>

  5. <CAS Support Functions>

  6. void init_cas(void)

  7. {

  8.   cas_url = getconf("cas_url", NULL);

  9.   if(cas_url && !*cas_url)

  10.     cas_url = NULL;

  11.   if(cas_url) {

  12.     cas_svc = getconf("cas_svc", NULL);

  13.     if(cas_svc && !*cas_svc)

  14.       cas_svc = NULL;

  15.     <Initialize CAS globals>

  16.   }

  17.   init_cgi_session();

  18. }

  19. NEOERR *check_cas(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean *needs_redirect)

  20. {

  21.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  22.   *needs_redirect = FALSE;

  23.   <Check CAS credentials and return STATUS_OK if OK>

  24.   return nerr;

  25. }

  26. NEOERR *cas_redirect(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  27. {

  28.   NEOERR *nerr = STATUS_OK;

  29.   <Redirect to CAS>

  30.   return nerr;

  31. }

  32. NEOERR *update_cas(cgi_state_t *cgi_state, gboolean *did_redirect)

  33. {

  34.   NEOERR *nerr = check_cas(cgi_state, did_redirect);

  35.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK && *did_redirect)

  36.     nerr = cas_redirect(cgi_state);

  37.   return nerr;

  38. }

<(cs-glib.nw) Library cs-supt Members>+= [<-D]

  1. cas.o

To obtain CAS credentials, the CGI application must first obtain a ticket by redirecting the browser to the CAS site, which will then redirect back to the CGI application when credentials are obtained. This cannot be done using wget, curl or something like that from the CGI application, because it relies on cookies in the user's browser to support persistent logins. It also presents a unified login user interface when persistent credentials are not already present. To perform the redirect, the CGI application's URL must be passed to CAS. This is computed using the CGI environment.

<CAS Support Functions>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. char *compute_myurl(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   GString *buf;

  4.   <Compute my URL into buf>

  5.   char *ret = buf->str;

  6.   g_string_free(buf, FALSE);

  7.   if(debug) {

  8.     cgi_puts("My URL: ");

  9.     cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, ret, FALSE);

  10.     cgi_puts("<br>\n");

  11.   }

  12.   return ret;

  13. }

<Compute my URL into buf>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. buf = g_string_new(cgi_env_val("CGI.HTTPS", NULL) ? "https" : "http");

  2. g_string_append(buf, "://");

  3. g_string_append(buf, cgi_header_val("Host", "localhost"));

  4. g_string_append(buf, cgi_env_val("CGI.RequestURI", "/"));

Since the parameters are saved in the session, the URL passed to CAS has all parameters stripped off.

<Compute my URL into buf>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. char *s = strchr(buf->str, '?');

  2. if(s) {

  3.   *s = 0;

  4.   buf->len = (int)(s - buf->str);

  5. }

This is replaced by a pointer to the saved parameters. Parameters are saved in the session under cas_parms, under a unqiue parent name. This is only done if there are any parameters to save, so the existence of the CAS ticket is presumed to mean that this is a return from a parameterless run.

<Compute my URL into buf>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *pno = cgi_parm_val("cas.pno", NULL);

  2. if(pno) {

  3.   g_string_append(buf, "?cas.pno=");

  4.   g_string_append(buf, pno);

  5. } else if(hdf_obj_child(cgi_state->cgi_parms) &&

  6.           !cgi_parm_val("casticket", NULL)) {

  7.   HDF *pno_obj;

  8.   NEOERR *nerr = update_session_state("cas_parms", cgi_state->cgi_parms,

  9.                                       &pno_obj, cgi_state);

  10.   if(nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  11.     g_string_append(buf, "?cas.pno=");

  12.     g_string_append(buf, hdf_obj_name(pno_obj));

  13.     hdf_destroy(&pno_obj);

  14.   } else if(debug)

  15.     die_if_err(nerr);

  16.   else {

  17.     nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  18.     g_string_free(buf, TRUE);

  19.     return NULL;

  20.   }

  21. }

Some requests take parameters from the headers, as well. In particular, conditional requests and range requests are signaled by headers. In order to support these, known relevant headers are stored in the CGI parameters. The request method itself is relevant as well, so it is also stored in the CGI parameters. This means that no like-named CGI parameters may exist, and that the parameter restoration must store the parameters back into the appropriate header HDF parameters. For this purpose, the _HTTP_ hierarchy is reserved.

<CAS Support Variables>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. const char * const save_headers[] = {

  2.   <HTTP Headers to Save on CAS Redirect>

  3.   NULL

  4. };

<HTTP Headers to Save on CAS Redirect>= (<-U)

  1. "If",

  2. "IfMatch",

  3. "IfModifiedSince",

  4. "IfNoneMatch",

  5. "IfRange",

  6. "IfUnmodifiedSince",

  7. "Range",

<Redirect to CAS>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. HDF *http_headers = cgi_env_obj("HTTP");

  2. HDF *cgi_headers = NULL;

  3. if(http_headers) {

  4.   const char * const * h, *v;

  5.   for(h = save_headers; *h; h++)

  6.     if((v = hdf_get_value(http_headers, *h, NULL))) {

  7.       if(!cgi_headers)

  8.         nerr_op(hdf_get_node(cgi_state->cgi_parms, "_HTTP_", &cgi_headers));

  9.       nerr_op(hdf_set_value(cgi_headers, *h, v));

  10.     }

  11. }

  12. if(nerr != STATUS_OK)

  13.   return nerr;

Also, if the request method is not GET or POST, the request method itself is a parameter which is lost. Normally, the request will simply be dropped, but for this library, the method will be saved just like the HTTP headers.

<Redirect to CAS>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. if(cgi_state->req_method != HTTP_REQ_GET &&

  2.    cgi_state->req_method != HTTP_REQ_POST &&

  3.    !nerr_op_ok(cgi_parm_set("_HTTP_._Request",

  4.                             cgi_env_val("CGI.RequestMethod", NULL))))

  5.   return nerr;

In addition to the pointer to the parameters, the session information itself must be given.

<Compute my URL into buf>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. g_string_append_session_cgi_parms(cgi_state, !pno, buf, TRUE);

File uploads are lost in the process, unless their state is adequately saved in the standard parameter hierarchy. For standard uploads, this can be accomplished by setting Config.Upload.Unlink to zero.

<Initialize CAS globals>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. hdf_set_int_value(local_config, "Config.Upload.Unlink", 0);

This will leave a lot of temporary files lying around, though, so a directory cleaner similar to the state cleaner is recommended (maybe even the state cleaner itself). In addition, the per-run cleanup routine can scan for files and remove them.

<Perform cleanups requiring valid CGI parameters>= (<-U)

  1. if(!hdf_get_int_value(cgi_state->hdf, "Config.Upload.Unlink", 1)) {

  2.   HDF *parm, *subparm;

  3.   const char *fn;

  4.   for(parm = hdf_obj_child(cgi_state->cgi_parms); parm;

  5.                                                   parm = hdf_obj_next(parm)) {

  6.     for(subparm = hdf_obj_child(parm); subparm; subparm = hdf_obj_next(subparm))

  7.       if((fn = hdf_get_value(subparm, "FileName", NULL)))

  8.         unlink(fn);

  9.     if((fn = hdf_get_value(parm, "FileName", NULL)))

  10.       unlink(fn);

  11.   }

  12. }

The redirect itself is done using the CGI kit redirection built-in. The return code indicates that the CGI application should do no rendering of its own.

<Redirect to CAS>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. /* note: IU CAS does not expect/support URL-encoding */

  2. char *myurl = compute_myurl(cgi_state);

  3. #if 0

  4. if(myurl) {

  5.   char *s;

  6.   cgi_url_escape(myurl, &s);

  7.   free(myurl);

  8.   myurl = s;

  9. }

  10. #endif

  11. if(!myurl)

  12.   return nerr_raise_msg_errno("Can't compute return URL");

  13. cgi_status(302);

  14. print_session_cookie(cgi_state, FALSE);

  15. if(cas_svc)

  16.   cgi_redirect_uri(cgi_state->cgi, "%slogin?cassvc=%s&casurl=%s",

  17.                    cas_url, cas_svc, myurl);

  18. else

  19.   cgi_redirect_uri(cgi_state->cgi, "%slogin?casurl=%s", cas_url, myurl);

  20. free(myurl);

When the redirection returns, the casticket parameter is added by CAS to indicate at least partially successful login. It is then up to the CGI application to validate that ticket and turn it into a user ID, by yet again calling the CAS server. This time, though, the user's browser does not need to be involved. The ticket itself is sent to the CAS server, which will stamp the ticket as invalid, and reply with text indicating whether or not it was valid before stamping.

To perform that callback, libcurl23 is used. Since it uses SSL, a certificate authority might also need to be specified. Note that the SSL libary used by curl should probably match any other SSL libraries against which the program is linked; otherwise the program may freeze on initial contact.

<(build.nw) Common C Includes>+= [<-D]

  1. #include <curl/curl.h>

<(build.nw) makefile.vars>+= [<-D]

  1. EXTRA_CFLAGS += $(shell curl-config --cflags)

  2. EXTRA_LDFLAGS += $(shell curl-config --libs)

<CAS Support Configuration>+= (U->) [<-D->]

  1. # The SSL Certificate Authority file to use with CAS

  2. # If blank, use a reasonable default system CA file

  3. #cas_ca =

<CAS Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static const char *cas_ca = NULL;

<Initialize CAS globals>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. cas_ca = getconf("cas_ca", NULL);

  2. curl_global_init(CURL_GLOBAL_ALL);

Setup for validation starts the same way as setup for redirection: a suitable URL is built. The only difference is that the operation changes (from login to validate) and the CAS ticket (cas_ticket) is appended.

<Validate CAS ticket with cURL>= (U->) [D->]

  1. GString *val_url = g_string_new(cas_url);

  2. GString *val_ret = NULL;

  3. g_string_append(val_url, "validate?");

  4. if(cas_svc) {

  5.   g_string_append(val_url, "cassvc=");

  6.   g_string_append(val_url, cas_svc);

  7.   g_string_append_c(val_url, '&');

  8. }

  9. g_string_append(val_url, "casticket=");

  10. /* IU CAS doesn't support URL-encoding */

  11. g_string_append/*_uri_escaped*/(val_url, cas_ticket);

  12. g_string_append(val_url, "&casurl=");

  13. char *myurl = compute_myurl(cgi_state);

  14. g_string_append/*_uri_escaped*/(val_url, myurl);

  15. free(myurl);

  16. if(debug) {

  17.   cgi_puts("Validating with ");

  18.   cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, val_url->str, FALSE);

  19.   cgi_puts("<br>\n");

  20. }

Then, the cURL setup itself is done. The results will be retrieved into memory, specifically into a GString buffer.

<Validate CAS ticket with cURL>+= (U->) [<-D]

  1. CURL *valhandle = curl_easy_init();

  2. if(valhandle) {

  3.   curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_URL, val_url->str);

  4.   if(cas_ca)

  5.     curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_CAINFO, cas_ca);

  6.   curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER, 1);

  7.   <Finish setting up cURL validation>

  8.   if(!curl_easy_perform(valhandle) && val_ret && val_ret->len) {

  9.     if(debug) {

  10.       cgi_puts("validation result:\n");

  11.       cgi_puts_html_escape(cgi_state, val_ret->str, FALSE);

  12.       cgi_puts("<br>\n");

  13.     }

  14.     <Check cURL validation results>

  15.   }

  16.   curl_easy_cleanup(valhandle);

  17. }

  18. g_string_free(val_url, TRUE);

Retrieval into a buffer requires the use of a write callback. Just in case, the progress indication is turned off as well. That way, no output will be generated on the standard streams.

<Finish setting up cURL validation>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_WRITEFUNCTION, (curl_write_callback)write_gstr);

  2. curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_WRITEDATA, &val_ret);

  3. curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_NOPROGRESS, 1);

<CAS Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. static ssize_t write_gstr(void *ptr, size_t size, size_t nmemb, void *_str)

  2. {

  3.   GString **str = _str;

  4.   size *= nmemb;

  5.   if(!size)

  6.     return 0;

  7.   if(*str)

  8.     g_string_append_len(*str, ptr, size);

  9.   else

  10.     *str = g_string_new_len(ptr, size);

  11.   return nmemb;

  12. }

If debugging is enabled, the CURL debug output should be printed to the CGI stream. This requires setting up another callback.

<Finish setting up cURL validation>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(debug) {

  2.   curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_VERBOSE, 1);

  3.   curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_DEBUGFUNCTION, cgi_curl_debug);

  4.   curl_easy_setopt(valhandle, CURLOPT_DEBUGDATA, cgi_state);

  5. }

<CAS Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. int cgi_curl_debug(CURL *curl, curl_infotype it, char *buf, size_t len,

  2.                    void *cbdata)

  3. {

  4.   cgi_state_t *cgi_state = cbdata;

  5.   const char *its;

  6.   switch(it) {

  7.     case CURLINFO_TEXT:

  8.     default:

  9.       its = "info";

  10.       break;

  11.     case CURLINFO_HEADER_IN:

  12.       its = "head";

  13.       break;

  14.     case CURLINFO_HEADER_OUT:

  15.       its = "hout";

  16.       break;

  17.     case CURLINFO_DATA_IN:

  18.       its = "rdat";

  19.       break;

  20.     case CURLINFO_DATA_OUT:

  21.       its = "wdat";

  22.       break;

  23.   }

  24.   cgi_printf("curl%s: %.*s<br>\n", its, (int)len, buf);

  25.   return 0;

  26. }

The buffer contents from the validation should be two lines of plain text. The first line is either `yes' or `no', indicating whether or not the ticket was valid. The second line is either blank or the name of the user authenticated by the ticket. Once the `yes' has been confirmed, and the user ID has been verified to be plain text, the user ID is copied into the CGI state. That's all there is to CAS authentication, at least version one as implemented at IU.

<Check cURL validation results>= (<-U)

  1. char *s = val_ret->str;

  2. /* first line == yes means valid */

  3. if(!memcmp(s, "yes\r\n", 5)) {

  4.   /* second line == user ID */

  5.   s += 5;

  6.   int i;

  7.   char name_valid = 1;

  8.   for(i = 0 ; s[i] && s[i] != '\r' && s[i] != '\n'; i++)

  9.     if(!isalnum(s[i])) {

  10.       name_valid = 0;

  11.       break;

  12.     }

  13.   s[i] = 0;

  14.   if(name_valid)

  15.     cas_userid = s;

  16. }

Before any of this can begin, though, the CGI environment must be parsed. This is done using the session initializer. The full session support is only necessary to support CAS, so if CAS is disabled, the session support could be disabled as well, but it is intended that the CAS calls completely replace the session calls, so the session call is always used. Nonetheless, if the CAS URL isn't specified, then nothing else needs to be done.

<Check CAS credentials and return STATUS_OK if OK>= (<-U) [D->]

  1. nerr = update_cgi_session(cgi_state);

  2. if(nerr != STATUS_OK || !cgi_state->sessionid)

  3.   return nerr;

  4. if(!cas_url)

  5.   return STATUS_OK;

  6. nerr = read_session_state("cas", NULL, FALSE, cgi_state);

  7. nerr_ignore(&nerr);

This is a rather expensive process, so the credentials are retained for a while before doing another redirect. The credentials are saved in the session information (cas.userid). Even though the process is expensive, eventually the credentials should be re-verified. This is done on a configurable interval. When the user ID is saved in the session, the current date plus the expiration interval is stored with it (cas.exp).

<CAS Support Configuration>+= (U->) [<-D]

  1. # The maximum seconds between ticket renewals

  2. # Note that multiple hosts verifying the same ticket must have synchronized

  3. # clocks

  4. # Setting this too short (e.g. 0) will force continual renewals

  5. #cas_renew_interval = 600

<CAS Support Variables>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. static guint cas_renew_interval;

<Initialize CAS globals>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. cas_renew_interval = getconf_int("cas_renew_interval", 600);

<Check CAS credentials and return STATUS_OK if OK>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *cas_userid = cgi_session_val("cas.userid", NULL);

  2. if(cas_userid && cgi_state->userid && !strcmp(cgi_state->userid, cas_userid)) {

  3.   time_t expiration = cgi_session_val_int("cas.exp", -1);

  4.   if(expiration >= 0) {

  5.     time_t now;

  6.     time(&now);

  7.     if(now < expiration)

  8.         return STATUS_OK;

  9.   }

  10. }

<Check CAS credentials and return STATUS_OK if OK>+= (<-U) [<-D->]

  1. const char *cas_ticket = cgi_parm_val("casticket", NULL);

  2. if(cas_ticket) {

  3.   <Validate CAS ticket with cURL>

  4.   if(cas_userid) {

  5.     <Update session user from CAS user>

  6.   }

  7.   if(val_ret)

  8.     g_string_free(val_ret, TRUE);

  9. }

In addition to setting the user information, a successful CAS logon must also restore any saved CGI parameters. After it does so, it removes them from the session state.

<Update session user from CAS user>= (<-U)

  1. nerr_op(cgi_session_set("cas.userid", cas_userid));

  2. if(cas_renew_interval) {

  3.   char nbuf[22];

  4.   time_t now;

  5.   time(&now);

  6.   now += cas_renew_interval;

  7.   snprintf(nbuf, sizeof(nbuf), "%llu", (ullong)now);

  8.   cgi_session_set("cas.exp", nbuf);

  9. }

  10. nerr_op(cgi_session_set("Session.RemoteUser", cas_userid));

  11. nerr_op(update_session_state("Session.RemoteUser",

  12.                              cgi_session_obj("Session.RemoteUser"), NULL,

  13.                              cgi_state));

  14. nerr_op(cgi_env_set("CGI.RemoteUser", cas_userid));

  15. if(nerr == STATUS_OK)

  16.   cas_userid = cgi_state->userid = cgi_env_val("CGI.RemoteUser", NULL);

  17. else

  18.   cas_userid = NULL; /* may as well try again; no memory this time */

  19. const char *pno = cgi_parm_val("cas.pno", NULL);

  20. if(pno && nerr == STATUS_OK)

  21.   nerr = read_session_state("cas_parms", pno, TRUE, cgi_state);

  22. if(pno && nerr == STATUS_OK) {

  23.   HDF *parms = cgi_session_obj("cas_parms"), *obj = NULL;

  24.   if(parms)

  25.     obj = hdf_get_obj(parms, pno);

  26.   if(obj) {

  27.     HDF *head = hdf_get_obj(obj, "_HTTP_");

  28.     if(head) {

  29.       const char *req;

  30.       nerr_op(hdf_copy(cgi_state->hdf, "HTTP", obj));

  31.       if((req = cgi_env_val("HTTP._Request", NULL))) {

  32.         nerr_op(cgi_env_set("CGI.RequestMethod", req));

  33.         cgi_state->req_method = http_req_id(req, strlen(req));

  34.       }

  35.       hdf_remove_tree(obj, "_HTTP_");

  36.     }

  37.     hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->hdf, "Query");

  38.     nerr_op(hdf_copy(cgi_state->hdf, "Query", obj));

  39.     if(nerr != STATUS_OK) {

  40.       nerr_ignore(&nerr);

  41.       hdf_remove_tree(cgi_state->hdf, "Query");

  42.     }

  43.     nerr = update_session_state("cas_parms", NULL, &obj, cgi_state);

  44.     if(debug) {

  45.       cgi_puts("Restored ");

  46.       cgi_dump_hdf(cgi_state);

  47.     }

  48.   }

  49. }

  50. nerr_op(update_session_state("cas", cgi_session_obj("cas"), NULL, cgi_state));

  51. nerr_ignore(&nerr);

Finally, if and only if any of that failed, a new redirect must be initiated. On the other hand, if it succeeded, the standard remote user parameter is updated.

<Check CAS credentials and return STATUS_OK if OK>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. if(cas_userid)

  2.   return STATUS_OK;

  3. *needs_redirect = TRUE;

  4. return STATUS_OK;

One other operation that has been neglected here is the logout operation. For this, the user is once again redirected to CAS. First, though, the session must be destroyed.

<CAS Support Functions>+= (<-U) [<-D]

  1. gboolean logout_cas(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  2. {

  3.   if(cas_url) {

  4.     cgi_status(302);

  5.     logout_cgi_session(cgi_state, TRUE);

  6.     cgi_redirect_uri(cgi_state->cgi, "%slogout", cas_url);

  7.     return TRUE;

  8.   }

  9.   return FALSE;

  10. }

Sample Program

A very small test program is provided here to exercise the code a little bit. It uses a template for the body, but a hard-coded header.

<(build.nw) C Test Support Executables>=

  1. test.cgi \

<test.cgi.c>=

  1. <(build.nw) Common C Header>

  2. <CGI Message Overrides>

  3. const char *tmpl;

  4. static NEOERR *do_cgi(cgi_state_t *cgi_state)

  5. {

  6.   <CGI Per-Run Variables>

  7.   die_if_err(init_cgi_run(cgi_state));

  8.   die_if_err(prepare_db_session(cgi_state));

  9.   gboolean did_redirect;

  10.   nerr = update_cas(cgi_state, &did_redirect);

  11.   if(nerr != STATUS_OK || did_redirect)

  12.     return nerr;

  13.   if(cgi_parm_val("action.logout", NULL)) {

  14.     if(logout_cas(cgi_state))

  15.       return STATUS_OK; /* redirects */

  16.     cgi_status(200);

  17.     cgi_puts("Status: 200\n");

  18.     logout_cgi_session(cgi_state, TRUE);

  19.     cgi_puts("Content-type: text/plain\n\nGood bye.");

  20.     return STATUS_OK;
